divide him inventorially would dizzy th’arithmetic of memory, and yet
but yaw neither, in respect of his quick sail. But, in the verity of
extolment, I take him to be a soul of great article and his infusion of
such dearth and rareness as, to make true diction of him, his semblable
is his mirror and who else would trace him his umbrage, nothing more.
nouns: definement perdition th’arithmetic memory respect sail verity soul article infusion dearth rareness diction mirror umbrage
adjectives: quick extolment great such true semblable more
verbs: suffer know divide dizzy take make trace

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
The concernancy, sir? Why do we wrap the gentleman in our more rawer
breath?

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
Is’t not possible to understand in another tongue? You will do’t, sir,
really.

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
His purse is empty already, all’s golden words are spent.

title: hamlet
text:
OSRIC.
I mean, sir, for his weapon; but in the imputation laid on him, by them
in his meed he’s unfellowed.

title: hamlet
text:
OSRIC.
The King, sir, hath wager’d with him six Barbary horses, against the
which he has imponed, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards,
with their assigns, as girdle, hangers, and so. Three of the carriages,
in faith, are very dear to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most
delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.
nouns: horse rapier poniard assign girdle hanger carriage faith hilt carriage conceit
adjectives: barbary french dear fancy responsive most delicate liberal

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
The phrase would be more german to the matter if we could carry cannon
by our sides. I would it might be hangers till then. But on. Six
Barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three
liberal conceited carriages: that’s the French bet against the Danish.
Why is this all imponed, as you call it?
nouns: phrase matter cannon side hanger horse sword assign carriage bet

title: hamlet
text:
OSRIC.
The King, sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between you and him, he
shall not exceed you three hits. He hath laid on twelve for nine. And
it would come to immediate trial if your lordship would vouchsafe the
answer.
nouns: dozen pass hit trial lordship answer
verbs: lay exceed hath lay come vouchsafe

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Sir, I will walk here in the hall. If it please his Majesty, it is the
breathing time of day with me. Let the foils be brought, the gentleman
willing, and the King hold his purpose, I will win for him if I can; if
not, I will gain nothing but my shame and the odd hits.
nouns: hall breathing time day foil gentleman purpose shame hit
verbs: walk please let bring hold win gain

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
He did comply with his dug before he suck’d it. Thus has he,—and many
more of the same bevy that I know the drossy age dotes on,— only got
the tune of the time and outward habit of encounter; a kind of yeasty
collection, which carries them through and through the most fanned and
winnowed opinions; and do but blow them to their trial, the bubbles are
out.
nouns: dug bevy age tune time habit encounter kind collection opinion trial bubble
adjectives: many more same drossy outward yeasty
verbs: comply suck’d know dote get carry fan winnow blow

title: hamlet
text:
LORD.
My lord, his Majesty commended him to you by young Osric, who brings
back to him that you attend him in the hall. He sends to know if your
pleasure hold to play with Laertes or that you will take longer time.
nouns: lord hall pleasure hold laerte time
verbs: commend bring attend send know play take

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
I am constant to my purposes, they follow the King’s pleasure. If his
fitness speaks, mine is ready. Now or whensoever, provided I be so able
as now.
nouns: purpose pleasure fitness speak mine whensoever

title: hamlet
text:
LORD.
The Queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment to Laertes
before you fall to play.

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
I do not think so. Since he went into France, I have been in continual
practice. I shall win at the odds. But thou wouldst not think how ill
all’s here about my heart: but it is no matter.

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
It is but foolery; but it is such a kind of gain-giving as would
perhaps trouble a woman.

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
If your mind dislike anything, obey it. I will forestall their repair
hither, and say you are not fit.

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Not a whit, we defy augury. There’s a special providence in the fall of
a sparrow. If it be now, ’tis not to come; if it be not to come, it
will be now; if it be not now, yet it will come. The readiness is all.
Since no man has aught of what he leaves, what is’t to leave betimes?
nouns: whit augury providence fall sparrow readiness man aught betime
verbs: defy ’ be tis come be come be come leave is’t leave

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Give me your pardon, sir. I have done you wrong;
But pardon’t as you are a gentleman.
This presence knows, and you must needs have heard,
How I am punish’d with sore distraction.
What I have done
That might your nature, honour, and exception
Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madness.
Was’t Hamlet wrong’d Laertes? Never Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himself be ta’en away,
And when he’s not himself does wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it.
Who does it, then? His madness. If’t be so,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wrong’d;
His madness is poor Hamlet’s enemy.
Sir, in this audience,
Let my disclaiming from a purpos’d evil
Free me so far in your most generous thoughts
That I have shot my arrow o’er the house
And hurt my brother.
nouns: pardon gentleman presence distraction nature honour exception madness wrong’d madness faction madness enemy audience disclaiming purpos’d thought arrow o’er house brother
adjectives: wrong pardon’t sore awake wrong wrong’d poor evil generous
verbs: give do know need hear do ’ deny let free shoot hurt

title: hamlet
text:
LAERTES.
I am satisfied in nature,
Whose motive in this case should stir me most
To my revenge. But in my terms of honour
I stand aloof, and will no reconcilement
Till by some elder masters of known honour
I have a voice and precedent of peace
To keep my name ungor’d. But till that time
I do receive your offer’d love like love,
And will not wrong it.
nouns: laertes nature motive case revenge term honour master honour voice precedent peace name ungor’d time offer’d love love
verbs: stir stand reconcilement know keep receive wrong

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
I’ll be your foil, Laertes; in mine ignorance
Your skill shall like a star i’ th’ darkest night,
Stick fiery off indeed.
nouns: foil mine ignorance skill star i th night fiery

title: hamlet
text:
KING.
Give them the foils, young Osric. Cousin Hamlet,
You know the wager?

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Very well, my lord.
Your Grace has laid the odds o’ the weaker side.

title: hamlet
text:
LAERTES.
This is too heavy. Let me see another.

title: hamlet
text:
KING.
Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.
If Hamlet give the first or second hit,
Or quit in answer of the third exchange,
Let all the battlements their ordnance fire;
The King shall drink to Hamlet’s better breath,
And in the cup an union shall he throw
Richer than that which four successive kings
In Denmark’s crown have worn. Give me the cups;
And let the kettle to the trumpet speak,
The trumpet to the cannoneer without,
The cannons to the heavens, the heavens to earth,
‘Now the King drinks to Hamlet.’ Come, begin.
And you, the judges, bear a wary eye.
nouns: king stoup wine table hit answer exchange battlement ordnance fire breath cup union king crown cup kettle trumpet speak trumpet cannoneer cannon heaven heaven earth judge eye
adjectives: first second third well successive wary
verbs: set give quit let drink throw wear give let drink come begin bear

title: hamlet
text: [_Trumpets sound, and cannon shot off within._]

title: hamlet
text:
QUEEN.
He’s fat, and scant of breath.
Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub thy brows.
The Queen carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet.

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Come for the third, Laertes. You do but dally.
I pray you pass with your best violence.
I am afeard you make a wanton of me.

title: hamlet
text:
LAERTES.
Why, as a woodcock to my own springe, Osric.
I am justly kill’d with mine own treachery.

title: hamlet
text:
QUEEN.
No, no, the drink, the drink! O my dear Hamlet!
The drink, the drink! I am poison’d.

title: hamlet
text:
LAERTES.
It is here, Hamlet. Hamlet, thou art slain.
No medicine in the world can do thee good.
In thee there is not half an hour of life;
The treacherous instrument is in thy hand,
Unbated and envenom’d. The foul practice
Hath turn’d itself on me. Lo, here I lie,
Never to rise again. Thy mother’s poison’d.
I can no more. The King, the King’s to blame.
nouns: laertes art medicine world thee hour life instrument hand envenom’d practice turn’d mother poison’d

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damned Dane,
Drink off this potion. Is thy union here?
Follow my mother.

title: hamlet
text:
LAERTES.
He is justly serv’d.
It is a poison temper’d by himself.
Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.
Mine and my father’s death come not upon thee,
Nor thine on me.
nouns: laertes poison temper’d forgiveness father death thine

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
Heaven make thee free of it! I follow thee.
I am dead, Horatio. Wretched Queen, adieu.
You that look pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes or audience to this act,
Had I but time,—as this fell sergeant, death,
Is strict in his arrest,—O, I could tell you,—
But let it be. Horatio, I am dead,
Thou liv’st; report me and my cause aright
To the unsatisfied.
nouns: chance mute audience act sergeant death arrest,—o cause aright
adjectives: free dead adieu pale fell strict dead unsatisfied
verbs: make follow look tremble tell let report

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
Never believe it.
I am more an antique Roman than a Dane.
Here’s yet some liquor left.

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
As th’art a man,
Give me the cup. Let go; by Heaven, I’ll have’t.
O good Horatio, what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me.
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity awhile,
And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain,
To tell my story.
nouns: th’art man cup name thing thou heart thee felicity world breath pain story
verbs: give let go wound stand live didst hold draw tell

title: hamlet
text:
OSRIC.
Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland,
To the ambassadors of England gives
This warlike volley.

title: hamlet
text:
HAMLET.
O, I die, Horatio.
The potent poison quite o’er-crows my spirit:
I cannot live to hear the news from England,
But I do prophesy th’election lights
On Fortinbras. He has my dying voice.
So tell him, with the occurrents more and less,
Which have solicited. The rest is silence.
nouns: poison o’er spirit news th’election light voice occurrent rest silence
verbs: die crow live hear prophesy die tell solicit

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
Now cracks a noble heart. Good night, sweet prince,
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.
Why does the drum come hither?
nouns: heart night prince flight angel rest drum hither

title: hamlet
text:
FORTINBRAS.
This quarry cries on havoc. O proud death,
What feast is toward in thine eternal cell,
That thou so many princes at a shot
So bloodily hast struck?
nouns: quarry havoc death feast thine cell thou prince shot

title: hamlet
text:
FIRST AMBASSADOR.
The sight is dismal;
And our affairs from England come too late.
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing,
To tell him his commandment is fulfill’d,
That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
Where should we have our thanks?
nouns: ambassador sight affair ear hearing commandment thank

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
Not from his mouth,
Had it th’ability of life to thank you.
He never gave commandment for their death.
But since, so jump upon this bloody question,
You from the Polack wars, and you from England
Are here arriv’d, give order that these bodies
High on a stage be placed to the view,
And let me speak to th’ yet unknowing world
How these things came about. So shall you hear
Of carnal, bloody and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgements, casual slaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning and forc’d cause,
And, in this upshot, purposes mistook
Fall’n on the inventors’ heads. All this can I
Truly deliver.
nouns: mouth th’ability life commandment death question war order body stage view world thing act judgement slaughter death cause upshot purpose inventor head
adjectives: bloody high carnal bloody unnatural accidental casual cunning
verbs: thank give jump give place let speak th unknowe come hear put deliver

title: hamlet
text:
FORTINBRAS.
Let us haste to hear it,
And call the noblest to the audience.
For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.
I have some rights of memory in this kingdom,
Which now to claim my vantage doth invite me.
nouns: audience sorrow fortune right memory kingdom vantage doth
verbs: let haste hear call embrace claim invite

title: hamlet
text:
HORATIO.
Of that I shall have also cause to speak,
And from his mouth whose voice will draw on more.
But let this same be presently perform’d,
Even while men’s minds are wild, lest more mischance
On plots and errors happen.
nouns: mouth voice man mind mischance plot error

title: hamlet
text:
FORTINBRAS.
Let four captains
Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage,
For he was likely, had he been put on,
To have prov’d most royally; and for his passage,
The soldiers’ music and the rites of war
Speak loudly for him.
Take up the bodies. Such a sight as this
Becomes the field, but here shows much amiss.
Go, bid the soldiers shoot.
nouns: captain soldier stage prov’d passage soldier music rite war body sight field soldier
verbs: let put speak take become show go bid shoot

title: lear
text: *** START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE TRAGEDY OF KING LEAR ***

title: lear
text:
LEAR, King of Britain.
GONERIL, eldest daughter to Lear.
REGAN, second daughter to Lear.
CORDELIA, youngest daughter to Lear.
DUKE of ALBANY, married to Goneril.
DUKE of CORNWALL, married to Regan.
KING of FRANCE.
DUKE of BURGUNDY.
EARL of GLOUCESTER.
EDGAR, elder son to Gloucester.
EDMUND, younger bastard son to Gloucester.
EARL of KENT.
FOOL.
OSWALD, steward to Goneril.
CURAN, a Courtier.
OLD MAN, Tenant to Gloucester.
Physician.
An Officer employed by Edmund.
Gentleman, attendant on Cordelia.
A Herald.
Servants to Cornwall.
nouns: daughter daughter CORDELIA daughter son bastard son CURAN attendant servant

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Sir, this young fellow’s mother could; whereupon she grew
round-wombed, and had indeed, sir, a son for her cradle ere she
had a husband for her bed. Do you smell a fault?
nouns: fellow mother son cradle ere husband bed fault

title: lear
text:
KENT.
I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
But I have a son, sir, by order of law, some year elder than
this, who yet is no dearer in my account: though this knave came
something saucily to the world before he was sent for, yet was
his mother fair; there was good sport at his making, and the
whoreson must be acknowledged. Do you know this noble gentleman,
Edmund?
nouns: son order law year dearer account world mother sport making whoreson gentleman

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
My Lord of Kent: remember him hereafter as my honourable friend.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Meantime we shall express our darker purpose.
Give me the map there. Know that we have divided
In three our kingdom: and ’tis our fast intent
To shake all cares and business from our age;
Conferring them on younger strengths, while we
Unburden’d crawl toward death. Our son of Cornwall,
And you, our no less loving son of Albany,
We have this hour a constant will to publish
Our daughters’ several dowers, that future strife
May be prevented now. The princes, France and Burgundy,
Great rivals in our youngest daughter’s love,
Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn,
And here are to be answer’d. Tell me, my daughters,—
Since now we will divest us both of rule,
Interest of territory, cares of state,—
Which of you shall we say doth love us most?
That we our largest bounty may extend
Where nature doth with merit challenge.—Goneril,
Our eldest born, speak first.
nouns: purpose map kingdom intent care business age strength crawl death son son hour will daughter dower strife prince rival daughter love court sojourn daughter rule interest territory care state doth bounty nature merit
adjectives: dark fast young unburden’d constant several future great young amorous large doth eld
verbs: express give know divide tis shake confer love publish prevent make tell divest say love extend bear speak

title: lear
nouns: word matter space liberty life grace health beauty honour child e’er love breath speech manner
adjectives: more eyesight valu’d rich rare less much poor unable
verbs: GONERIL love wield find make love

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
[_Aside._] What shall Cordelia speak? Love, and be silent.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Of all these bounds, even from this line to this,
With shadowy forests and with champains rich’d,
With plenteous rivers and wide-skirted meads,
We make thee lady: to thine and Albany’s issue
Be this perpetual.—What says our second daughter,
Our dearest Regan, wife of Cornwall? Speak.
nouns: bound line forest champain river mead lady thine issue daughter wife

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Sir, I am made of the self mettle as my sister,
And prize me at her worth. In my true heart
I find she names my very deed of love;
Only she comes too short, that I profess
Myself an enemy to all other joys
Which the most precious square of sense possesses,
And find I am alone felicitate
In your dear highness’ love.
nouns: self mettle sister heart deed love enemy joy square sense possesse highness love
adjectives: worth true short other precious felicitate dear
verbs: make prize find name come profess find

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
[_Aside._] Then poor Cordelia,
And yet not so; since, I am sure, my love’s
More ponderous than my tongue.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
To thee and thine hereditary ever
Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom;
No less in space, validity, and pleasure
Than that conferr’d on Goneril.—Now, our joy,
Although the last and least; to whose young love
The vines of France and milk of Burgundy
Strive to be interess’d; what can you say to draw
A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak.
nouns: thine third kingdom space validity pleasure joy love vine milk sister
adjectives: hereditary ample fair last least young opulent
verbs: remain conferr’d strive say draw speak

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Unhappy that I am, I cannot heave
My heart into my mouth: I love your majesty
According to my bond; no more nor less.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
How, how, Cordelia? Mend your speech a little,
Lest you may mar your fortunes.

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Good my lord,
You have begot me, bred me, lov’d me: I
Return those duties back as are right fit,
Obey you, love you, and most honour you.
Why have my sisters husbands if they say
They love you all? Haply, when I shall wed,
That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry
Half my love with him, half my care and duty:
Sure I shall never marry like my sisters,
To love my father all.
nouns: CORDELIA duty sister husband hand plight love care duty sister father
verbs: beget breed return obey love honour say love take carry marry love

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Let it be so, thy truth then be thy dower:
For, by the sacred radiance of the sun,
The mysteries of Hecate and the night;
By all the operation of the orbs,
From whom we do exist and cease to be;
Here I disclaim all my paternal care,
Propinquity and property of blood,
And as a stranger to my heart and me
Hold thee from this for ever. The barbarous Scythian,
Or he that makes his generation messes
To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom
Be as well neighbour’d, pitied, and reliev’d,
As thou my sometime daughter.
nouns: truth dower radiance sun mystery night operation orb care propinquity property blood stranger heart generation appetite bosom neighbour’d reliev’d thou daughter
verbs: let exist cease disclaim hold make mess gorge pity

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Peace, Kent!
Come not between the dragon and his wrath.
I lov’d her most, and thought to set my rest
On her kind nursery. [_To Cordelia._] Hence and avoid my sight!
So be my grave my peace, as here I give
Her father’s heart from her! Call France. Who stirs?
Call Burgundy! Cornwall and Albany,
With my two daughters’ dowers digest this third:
Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her.
I do invest you jointly with my power,
Pre-eminence, and all the large effects
That troop with majesty. Ourself, by monthly course,
With reservation of an hundred knights,
By you to be sustain’d, shall our abode
Make with you by due turn. Only we shall retain
The name, and all the addition to a king; the sway,
Revenue, execution of the rest,
Beloved sons, be yours; which to confirm,
This coronet part between you.
 [_Giving the crown._]
nouns: dragon wrath rest nursery sight grave peace father heart daughter dower third pride plainness power Pre - eminence effect troop course reservation knight abode turn name addition king sway execution rest son your coronet part crown
adjectives: most kind large monthly due beloved
verbs: come think set avoid give call stir call digest let call marry invest make retain confirm give

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Royal Lear,
Whom I have ever honour’d as my king,
Lov’d as my father, as my master follow’d,
As my great patron thought on in my prayers.—

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
The bow is bent and drawn; make from the shaft.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Let it fall rather, though the fork invade
The region of my heart: be Kent unmannerly
When Lear is mad. What wouldst thou do, old man?
Think’st thou that duty shall have dread to speak,
When power to flattery bows? To plainness honour’s bound
When majesty falls to folly. Reverse thy state;
And in thy best consideration check
This hideous rashness: answer my life my judgement,
Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least;
Nor are those empty-hearted, whose low sounds
Reverb no hollowness.
nouns: fork region heart thou man duty dread power bow honour folly state consideration rashness life judgement daughter reverb hollowness
adjectives: kent unmannerly mad wouldst old majesty good hideous young least empty hearted low
verbs: let fall invade speak flattery plainness bind fall reverse check answer Thy love sound

title: lear
text:
KENT.
See better, Lear; and let me still remain
The true blank of thine eye.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Kill thy physician, and the fee bestow
Upon the foul disease. Revoke thy gift,
Or, whilst I can vent clamour from my throat,
I’ll tell thee thou dost evil.
nouns: physician fee disease gift clamour throat evil
verbs: kill bestow revoke vent tell dost

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Hear me, recreant! on thine allegiance, hear me!
Since thou hast sought to make us break our vows,
Which we durst never yet, and with strain’d pride
To come betwixt our sentences and our power,
Which nor our nature, nor our place can bear,
Our potency made good, take thy reward.
Five days we do allot thee for provision,
To shield thee from disasters of the world;
And on the sixth to turn thy hated back
Upon our kingdom: if, on the next day following,
Thy banish’d trunk be found in our dominions,
The moment is thy death. Away! By Jupiter,
This shall not be revok’d.
nouns: recreant thine allegiance vow pride sentence power nature place potency reward day provision disaster world kingdom day banish’d trunk dominion moment death revok’d
verbs: hear hear seek make break durst come bear make take allot shield turn hate follow find

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Fare thee well, King: sith thus thou wilt appear,
Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here.
[_To Cordelia._] The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid,
That justly think’st and hast most rightly said!
[_To Goneril and Regan._] And your large speeches may your deeds
approve,
That good effects may spring from words of love.
Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu;
He’ll shape his old course in a country new.
nouns: banishment god shelter hast speech deed effect word love o prince course country
adjectives: dear large good adieu old new
verbs: fare appear live take say approve spring bid shape

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Here’s France and Burgundy, my noble lord.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
My Lord of Burgundy,
We first address toward you, who with this king
Hath rivall’d for our daughter: what in the least
Will you require in present dower with her,
Or cease your quest of love?
nouns: king rivall’d daughter dower quest love

title: lear
text:
BURGUNDY.
Most royal majesty,
I crave no more than hath your highness offer’d,
Nor will you tender less.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Right noble Burgundy,
When she was dear to us, we did hold her so;
But now her price is fall’n. Sir, there she stands:
If aught within that little-seeming substance,
Or all of it, with our displeasure piec’d,
And nothing more, may fitly like your grace,
She’s there, and she is yours.
nouns: price aught substance displeasure piec’d grace

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Will you, with those infirmities she owes,
Unfriended, new adopted to our hate,
Dower’d with our curse, and stranger’d with our oath,
Take her or leave her?

title: lear
lear
text:
LEAR.
Then leave her, sir; for, by the power that made me,
I tell you all her wealth. [_To France_] For you, great king,
I would not from your love make such a stray
To match you where I hate; therefore beseech you
T’avert your liking a more worthier way
Than on a wretch whom nature is asham’d
Almost t’acknowledge hers.
nouns: power wealth king love stray beseech way wretch nature asham’d t’acknowledge
verbs: leave make tell make match hate T’avert like

title: lear
text:
FRANCE.
This is most strange,
That she, who even but now was your best object,
The argument of your praise, balm of your age,
The best, the dearest, should in this trice of time
Commit a thing so monstrous, to dismantle
So many folds of favour. Sure her offence
Must be of such unnatural degree
That monsters it, or your fore-vouch’d affection
Fall into taint; which to believe of her
Must be a faith that reason without miracle
Should never plant in me.
nouns: object argument praise balm age dearest trice time thing fold favour offence degree fore affection taint faith reason miracle
adjectives: strange good good monstrous many such unnatural
verbs: commit dismantle monster fall believe plant

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
I yet beseech your majesty,
If for I want that glib and oily art
To speak and purpose not; since what I well intend,
I’ll do’t before I speak,—that you make known
It is no vicious blot, murder, or foulness,
No unchaste action or dishonour’d step,
That hath depriv’d me of your grace and favour;
But even for want of that for which I am richer,
A still soliciting eye, and such a tongue
As I am glad I have not, though not to have it
Hath lost me in your liking.
nouns: CORDELIA majesty art do’t blot murder foulness action dishonour’d step grace favour want eye tongue liking
adjectives: glib oily vicious unchaste rich glad
verbs: beseech want speak purpose intend speak,—that make know hath depriv’d solicit lose

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Better thou hadst
Not been born than not to have pleas’d me better.

title: lear
text:
FRANCE.
Is it but this?—a tardiness in nature
Which often leaves the history unspoke
That it intends to do? My lord of Burgundy,
What say you to the lady? Love’s not love
When it is mingled with regards that stands
Aloof from the entire point. Will you have her?
She is herself a dowry.
nouns: tardiness nature history lord lady love regard point dowry
verbs: leave intend say ’ love mingle stand

title: lear
text:
BURGUNDY.
I am sorry, then, you have so lost a father
That you must lose a husband.

title: lear
text:
FRANCE.
Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being poor;
Most choice forsaken; and most lov’d, despis’d!
Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon:
Be it lawful, I take up what’s cast away.
Gods, gods! ’Tis strange that from their cold’st neglect
My love should kindle to inflam’d respect.
Thy dowerless daughter, King, thrown to my chance,
Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France:
Not all the dukes of waterish Burgundy
Can buy this unpriz’d precious maid of me.
Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind:
Thou losest here, a better where to find.
nouns: choice virtue god god neglect love respect dowerless daughter chance queen our duke maid farewell unkind losest
adjectives: rich poor Most lawful strange fair waterish unpriz’d precious thou well
verbs: art forsake seize take ’ cast tis kindle throw buy bid find

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Thou hast her, France: let her be thine; for we
Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see
That face of hers again. Therefore be gone
Without our grace, our love, our benison.
Come, noble Burgundy.
nouns: thine daughter face grace love benison

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
The jewels of our father, with wash’d eyes
Cordelia leaves you: I know you what you are;
And like a sister am most loath to call
Your faults as they are nam’d. Love well our father:
To your professed bosoms I commit him:
But yet, alas, stood I within his grace,
I would prefer him to a better place.
So farewell to you both.
nouns: CORDELIA jewel father eye sister fault father bosom grace place
verbs: leave know call love profess commit stand prefer

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Let your study
Be to content your lord, who hath receiv’d you
At fortune’s alms. You have obedience scanted,
And well are worth the want that you have wanted.
verbs: GONERIL let content hath scant want

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides:
Who covers faults, at last shame derides.
Well may you prosper.

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Sister, it is not little I have to say of what most nearly
appertains to us both. I think our father will hence tonight.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
That’s most certain, and with you; next month with us.

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
You see how full of changes his age is; the observation we
have made of it hath not been little: he always loved our
sister most; and with what poor judgement he hath now cast her
off appears too grossly.
verbs: GONERIL see make hath love hath cast appear

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash; then must
we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of
long-engrafted condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness
that infirm and choleric years bring with them.
nouns: time hath age imperfection condition waywardness year
adjectives: good soundest rash unruly infirm choleric
verbs: GONERIL look receive engraft therewithal bring

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent’s
banishment.

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and
him. Pray you let us hit together: if our father carry authority
with such disposition as he bears, this last surrender of his
will but offend us.
nouns: compliment leave taking father authority disposition surrender
verbs: GONERIL pray let hit carry bear offend

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Thou, Nature, art my goddess; to thy law
My services are bound. Wherefore should I
Stand in the plague of custom, and permit
The curiosity of nations to deprive me?
For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines
Lag of a brother? Why bastard? Wherefore base?
When my dimensions are as well compact,
My mind as generous, and my shape as true
As honest madam’s issue? Why brand they us
With base? With baseness? bastardy? Base, base?
Who, in the lusty stealth of nature, take
More composition and fierce quality
Than doth within a dull stale tired bed
Go to the creating a whole tribe of fops
Got ’tween asleep and wake? Well then,
Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land:
Our father’s love is to the bastard Edmund
As to the legitimate: fine word: legitimate!
Well, my legitimate, if this letter speed,
And my invention thrive, Edmund the base
Shall top the legitimate. I grow, I prosper.
Now, gods, stand up for bastards!
nouns: goddess law service plague custom curiosity nation moonshine brother base dimension mind shape madam issue brand base baseness base stealth nature composition quality doth bed tribe fop land father love bastard word letter speed invention thrive base god bastard
adjectives: bastard wherefore compact generous true honest bastardy lusty More fierce dull stale tired whole asleep wake legitimate fine legitimate legitimate legitimate
verbs: art bind stand permit deprive take go create got tween top grow prosper stand

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
No? What needed then that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket? The
quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself. Let’s see. Come,
if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles.
nouns: no dispatch pocket quality need spectacle
verbs: need hath hide let see come be need

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
I beseech you, sir, pardon me. It is a letter from my brother that I
have not all o’er-read; and for so much as I have perus’d, I find it
not fit for your o’er-looking.
nouns: letter brother o’er read o’er looking

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
[_Reads._] ‘This policy and reverence of age makes the world
bitter to the best of our times; keeps our fortunes from us
till our oldness cannot relish them. I begin to find an idle
and fond bondage in the oppression of aged tyranny; who sways
not as it hath power, but as it is suffered. Come to me, that
of this I may speak more. If our father would sleep till I
waked him, you should enjoy half his revenue for ever, and live
the beloved of your brother EDGAR.’
Hum! Conspiracy? ‘Sleep till I wake him, you should enjoy half
his revenue.’—My son Edgar! Had he a hand to write this? A heart
and brain to breed it in? When came this to you? Who brought it?
nouns: read policy reverence age world time fortune oldness idle bondage oppression tyranny power father revenue beloved brother revenue ’—my son hand heart brain
verbs: make keep relish begin find sway hath suffer come speak sleep wake enjoy live sleep wake enjoy write breed come bring

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his; but
in respect of that, I would fain think it were not.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Never, my lord. But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit
that, sons at perfect age, and fathers declined, the father
should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue.
nouns: lord son age father father son son revenue

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
O villain, villain! His very opinion in the letter! Abhorred
villain! Unnatural, detested, brutish villain! worse than
brutish! Go, sirrah, seek him; I’ll apprehend him. Abominable
villain, Where is he?
adjectives: villain very unnatural brutish bad brutish abominable
verbs: abhor villain detest go seek apprehend

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
I do not well know, my lord. If it shall please you to suspend
your indignation against my brother till you can derive from him
better testimony of his intent, you should run a certain course;
where, if you violently proceed against him, mistaking his
purpose, it would make a great gap in your own honour, and shake
in pieces the heart of his obedience. I dare pawn down my life
for him, that he hath writ this to feel my affection to your
honour, and to no other pretence of danger.
nouns: lord indignation brother testimony intent course purpose gap honour piece heart obedience life affection honour pretence danger
verbs: know please suspend derive run proceed mistake make shake dare pawn hath writ feel

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
If your honour judge it meet, I will place you where you shall hear us
confer of this, and by an auricular assurance have your satisfaction,
and that without any further delay than this very evening.
nouns: honour judge confer assurance satisfaction delay evening

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him. Heaven
and earth! Edmund, seek him out; wind me into him, I pray you:
frame the business after your own wisdom. I would unstate myself
to be in a due resolution.
verbs: love seek wind pray frame unstate

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
I will seek him, sir, presently; convey the business as I shall
find means, and acquaint you withal.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us:
though the wisdom of Nature can reason it thus and thus, yet
nature finds itself scourged by the sequent effects. Love cools,
friendship falls off, brothers divide: in cities, mutinies; in
countries, discord; in palaces, treason; and the bond cracked
’twixt son and father. This villain of mine comes under the
prediction; there’s son against father: the King falls from
bias of nature; there’s father against child. We have seen the
best of our time. Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all
ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves. Find out
this villain, Edmund; it shall lose thee nothing; do it
carefully.—And the noble and true-hearted Kent banished! his
offence, honesty! ’Tis strange.
nouns: eclipse sun moon good wisdom nature effect love cool friendship brother city mutiny country discord palace treason bond son father villain mine prediction son bias nature father child time machination hollowness treachery disorder grave villain offence honesty
adjectives: late sequent good ruinous noble true strange
verbs: portend reason find scourge fall divide crack twixt come ’ fall ’ see follow find lose hearte banish tis

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
This is the excellent foppery of the world, that, when we are
sick in fortune, often the surfeits of our own behaviour, we
make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars; as
if we were villains on necessity; fools by heavenly compulsion;
knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance;
drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of
planetary influence; and all that we are evil in, by a divine
thrusting on. An admirable evasion of whoremaster man, to lay his
goatish disposition to the charge of a star. My father compounded
with my mother under the dragon’s tail, and my nativity was under
Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous. Fut! I
should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the
firmament twinkled on my bastardizing.
nouns: foppery world fortune surfeit behaviour disaster sun moon star villain necessity fool compulsion knave thief treacher predominance drunkard liar adulterer obedience influence thrusting evasion man disposition charge star father mother dragon tail nativity star firmament bastardizing
adjectives: excellent sick own guilty heavenly spherical planetary evil divine admirable whoremaster goatish rough lecherous maidenli
verbs: make enforce lay compound follow twinkle

title: lear
text:
Pat! he comes, like the catastrophe of the old comedy: my cue
is villainous melancholy, with a sigh like Tom o’Bedlam.—O,
these eclipses do portend these divisions! Fa, sol, la, mi.
nouns: catastrophe comedy cue sigh o’bedlam.—o eclipse division sol

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
I am thinking, brother, of a prediction I read this other day,
what should follow these eclipses.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
I promise you, the effects he writes of succeed unhappily: as of
unnaturalness between the child and the parent; death, dearth,
dissolutions of ancient amities; divisions in state, menaces and
maledictions against King and nobles; needless diffidences,
banishment of friends, dissipation of cohorts, nuptial breaches,
and I know not what.
nouns: effect unnaturalness child parent death dearth dissolution amity division state menace malediction noble diffidence banishment friend dissipation cohort breach

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Come, come! when saw you my father last?

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Parted you in good terms? Found you no displeasure in him, by word
nor countenance?

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended him: and at my
entreaty forbear his presence until some little time hath
qualified the heat of his displeasure; which at this instant so
rageth in him that with the mischief of your person it would
scarcely allay.
nouns: presence time hath heat displeasure instant mischief person

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Some villain hath done me wrong.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
That’s my fear. I pray you have a continent forbearance till the
speed of his rage goes slower; and, as I say, retire with me to
my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord
speak: pray ye, go; there’s my key. If you do stir abroad, go
armed.
nouns: fear continent forbearance speed rage lodging whence speak key
verbs: ’ pray go say retire bring hear pray go ’ stir go

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Brother, I advise you to the best; I am no honest man
if there be any good meaning toward you: I have told you what I
have seen and heard. But faintly; nothing like the image and
horror of it: pray you, away!

title: lear
text:
A credulous father! and a brother noble,
Whose nature is so far from doing harms
That he suspects none; on whose foolish honesty
My practices ride easy! I see the business.
Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit;
All with me’s meet that I can fashion fit.
nouns: father brother nature harm none honesty practice business birth land wit meet
verbs: do suspect ride see let fashion

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
By day and night, he wrongs me; every hour
He flashes into one gross crime or other,
That sets us all at odds; I’ll not endure it:
His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us
On every trifle. When he returns from hunting,
I will not speak with him; say I am sick.
If you come slack of former services,
You shall do well; the fault of it I’ll answer.
nouns: day night hour crime odd knight trifle hunting slack service fault
verbs: GONERIL wrong flash set endure grow upbraid return speak say come answer

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Put on what weary negligence you please,
You and your fellows; I’d have it come to question:
If he distaste it, let him to our sister,
Whose mind and mine, I know, in that are one,
Not to be overruled. Idle old man,
That still would manage those authorities
That he hath given away! Now, by my life,
Old fools are babes again; and must be us’d
With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abus’d.
Remember what I have said.
nouns: negligence fellow sister mind mine man authority life fool babe check flattery abus’d
verbs: GONERIL put please come question distaste let know overrule manage hath give see remember say

title: lear
nouns: knight fellow occasion sister course dinner
verbs: GONERIL let look grow advise breed speak write hold prepare

title: lear
text:
KENT.
If but as well I other accents borrow,
That can my speech defuse, my good intent
May carry through itself to that full issue
For which I rais’d my likeness. Now, banish’d Kent,
If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemn’d,
So may it come, thy master, whom thou lov’st,
Shall find thee full of labours.
nouns: accent speech defuse intent issue likeness condemn’d master labour
adjectives: other good full banish’d canst full
verbs: borrow carry rais’d serve stand come find

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Let me not stay a jot for dinner; go get it ready.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
What dost thou profess? What wouldst thou with us?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
I do profess to be no less than I seem; to serve him truly that
will put me in trust; to love him that is honest; to converse
with him that is wise and says little; to fear judgement; to fight
when I cannot choose; and to eat no fish.
verbs: seem serve put love converse say fear fight choose eat

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
If thou be’st as poor for a subject as he’s for a king, thou art
poor enough. What wouldst thou?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Who wouldst thou serve?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Dost thou know me, fellow?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in
telling it and deliver a plain message bluntly. That which
ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in, and the best of
me is diligence.
nouns: counsel run tale message man diligence
adjectives: honest curious plain ordinary fit qualified good

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing; nor so old to
dote on her for anything: I have years on my back forty-eight.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Follow me; thou shalt serve me. If I like thee no worse after dinner, I
will not part from thee yet. Dinner, ho, dinner! Where’s my knave? my
fool? Go you and call my fool hither.
nouns: shalt dinner dinner knave fool fool hither
verbs: follow serve like part ’ go call

title: lear
text: Where’s my fool? Ho, I think the world’s asleep.

title: lear
text:
KNIGHT.
He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.

title: lear
text:
KNIGHT.
My lord, I know not what the matter is; but to my judgement your
highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as
you were wont; there’s a great abatement of kindness appears as
well in the general dependants as in the Duke himself also, and
your daughter.
nouns: lord matter judgement highness affection abatement kindness dependant daughter

title: lear
text:
KNIGHT.
I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken; for my duty
cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception: I have perceived
a most faint neglect of late; which I have rather blamed as mine
own jealous curiosity than as a very pretence and purpose of
unkindness: I will look further into’t. But where’s my fool? I
have not seen him this two days.
nouns: conception neglect mine curiosity pretence purpose into’t fool day
adjectives: remember mine own faint late jealous very unkindness

title: lear
text:
KNIGHT.
Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool hath much
pined away.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
No more of that; I have noted it well. Go you and tell my
daughter I would speak with her.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I thank thee, fellow. Thou serv’st me, and I’ll love thee.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee: there’s earnest of thy service.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Sirrah, you were best take my coxcomb.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Why, for taking one’s part that’s out of favour. Nay, an thou
canst not smile as the wind sits, thou’lt catch cold shortly:
there, take my coxcomb: why, this fellow has banish’d two on’s
daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will; if
thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb. How now,
nuncle! Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters!
nouns: part favour thou wind catch coxcomb fellow daughter blessing will coxcomb nuncle coxcomb daughter
verbs: take ’ smile sit take banish’d follow need wear

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
If I gave them all my living, I’d keep my coxcombs myself. There’s
mine; beg another of thy daughters.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Mark it, nuncle:
    Have more than thou showest,
    Speak less than thou knowest,
    Lend less than thou owest,
    Ride more than thou goest,
    Learn more than thou trowest,
    Set less than thou throwest;
    Leave thy drink and thy whore,
    And keep in-a-door,
    And thou shalt have more
    Than two tens to a score.
nouns: nuncle thou thou knowest thou thou thou thou throwest drink whore door shalt ten score
adjectives: more show less less more go more trow less more
verbs: speak lend ride learn set leave keep

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Then ’tis like the breath of an unfee’d lawyer, you gave me
nothing for’t. Can you make no use of nothing, nuncle?

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and
a sweet one?

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
   That lord that counsell’d thee
     To give away thy land,
   Come place him here by me,
     Do thou for him stand.
   The sweet and bitter fool
     Will presently appear;
   The one in motley here,
     The other found out there.
verbs: counsell’d give Come place stand appear find

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Dost thou call me fool, boy?

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
All thy other titles thou hast given away; that thou wast born
with.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
No, faith; lords and great men will not let me; if I had a
monopoly out, they would have part on’t and ladies too, they
will not let me have all the fool to myself; they’ll be
snatching. Nuncle, give me an egg, and I’ll give thee two
crowns.
nouns: no faith lord man monopoly part on’t lady fool nuncle egg crown

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Why, after I have cut the egg i’ the middle and eat up the
meat, the two crowns of the egg. When thou clovest thy crown i’
the middle and gav’st away both parts, thou bor’st thine ass on
thy back o’er the dirt: thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown
when thou gav’st thy golden one away. If I speak like myself in
this, let him be whipped that first finds it so.
[_Singing._]
   Fools had ne’er less grace in a year;
     For wise men are grown foppish,
   And know not how their wits to wear,
     Their manners are so apish.
nouns: egg middle meat crown egg thou crown i middle part ass o’er dirt wit crown one singing ne’er grace year man wit manner
adjectives: back hadst little bald golden less wise foppish apish
verbs: cut eat clovest speak let whip find grow know wear

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
I have used it, nuncle, e’er since thou mad’st thy daughters thy
mothers; for when thou gav’st them the rod, and put’st down thine
own breeches,
[_Singing._]
   Then they for sudden joy did weep,
     And I for sorrow sung,
   That such a king should play bo-peep,
     And go the fools among.
Prythee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to
lie; I would fain learn to lie.
nouns: nuncle daughter mother rod thine breech singing joy sorrow king bo - peep fool nuncle schoolmaster fool
verbs: use gav’st weep play go keep teach lie fain learn lie

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are: they’ll have me
whipped for speaking true; thou’lt have me whipped for lying;
and sometimes I am whipped for holding my peace. I had rather be
any kind o’thing than a fool: and yet I would not be thee,
nuncle: thou hast pared thy wit o’both sides, and left nothing
i’ the middle: here comes one o’ the parings.
nouns: daughter peace kind fool nuncle wit o’both side middle o paring
verbs: marvel whip speak whip lie whip hold o’the pare leave come

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
How now, daughter? What makes that frontlet on? Methinks you
are too much of late i’ the frown.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for
her frowning. Now thou art an O without a figure: I am better
than thou art now. I am a fool, thou art nothing. [_To Goneril._]
Yes, forsooth, I will hold my tongue. So your face bids me, though
you say nothing. Mum, mum,
     He that keeps nor crust nor crum,
     Weary of all, shall want some.
[_Pointing to Lear_.] That’s a shealed peascod.
nouns: fellow need frowning art o figure art fool art tongue face mum mum crust crum _ peascod
verbs: wast care hold bid say keep want point ’

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Not only, sir, this your all-licens’d fool,
But other of your insolent retinue
Do hourly carp and quarrel; breaking forth
In rank and not-to-be-endured riots. Sir,
I had thought, by making this well known unto you,
To have found a safe redress; but now grow fearful,
By what yourself too late have spoke and done,
That you protect this course, and put it on
By your allowance; which if you should, the fault
Would not scape censure, nor the redresses sleep,
Which, in the tender of a wholesome weal,
Might in their working do you that offence
Which else were shame, that then necessity
Will call discreet proceeding.
nouns: sir licens’d fool insolent retinue carp quarrel rank riot redress course allowance fault censure redress tender weal working offence shame necessity proceeding
adjectives: other hourly safe fearful wholesome discreet
verbs: GONERIL break endure think make know find grow speak do protect put scape sleep call

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
For you know, nuncle,
   The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long
   That it’s had it head bit off by it young.
So out went the candle, and we were left darkling.
nouns: nuncle hedge cuckoo head bit candle

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Come, sir,
I would you would make use of that good wisdom,
Whereof I know you are fraught; and put away
These dispositions, which of late transform you
From what you rightly are.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Doth any here know me? This is not Lear;
Doth Lear walk thus? speak thus? Where are his eyes?
Either his notion weakens, his discernings
Are lethargied. Ha! waking? ’Tis not so!
Who is it that can tell me who I am?
verbs: know walk speak weaken lethargie wake tis tell

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I would learn that; for by the marks of sovereignty, knowledge and
reason, I should be false persuaded I had daughters.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Which they will make an obedient father.

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
This admiration, sir, is much o’ the favour
Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you
To understand my purposes aright:
As you are old and reverend, you should be wise.
Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires;
Men so disorder’d, so debosh’d and bold
That this our court, infected with their manners,
Shows like a riotous inn. Epicurism and lust
Makes it more like a tavern or a brothel
Than a grac’d palace. The shame itself doth speak
For instant remedy. Be, then, desir’d
By her that else will take the thing she begs
A little to disquantity your train;
And the remainder that shall still depend,
To be such men as may besort your age,
Which know themselves, and you.
nouns: admiration o favour prank purpose aright knight squire men disorder’d debosh’d court manner inn epicurism lust tavern brothel palace shame speak remedy thing train remainder man age
adjectives: much other new old reverend wise bold riotous grac’d instant little such
verbs: GONERIL beseech understand keep infect show make take beg disquantity depend besort know

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Woe that too late repents!—
[_To Albany._] O, sir, are you come?
Is it your will? Speak, sir.—Prepare my horses.
Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend,
More hideous when thou show’st thee in a child
Than the sea-monster!
nouns: repent will horse marble fiend thee child sea monster

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
[_to Goneril._] Detested kite, thou liest.
My train are men of choice and rarest parts,
That all particulars of duty know;
And in the most exact regard support
The worships of their name. O most small fault,
How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show!
Which, like an engine, wrench’d my frame of nature
From the fix’d place; drew from my heart all love,
And added to the gall. O Lear, Lear, Lear!
[_Striking his head._] Beat at this gate that let thy folly in
And thy dear judgement out! Go, go, my people.
nouns: kite liest train man choice part particular duty know regard support worship name fault thou show engine wrench’d frame nature place heart love gall head gate folly judgement people
adjectives: thou rare exact small ugly didst dear
verbs: detest draw add strike Beat let go go

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
My lord, I am guiltless, as I am ignorant
Of what hath moved you.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
It may be so, my lord.
Hear, nature, hear; dear goddess, hear!
Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend
To make this creature fruitful!
Into her womb convey sterility!
Dry up in her the organs of increase;
And from her derogate body never spring
A babe to honour her! If she must teem,
Create her child of spleen, that it may live
And be a thwart disnatur’d torment to her!
Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth;
With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks;
Turn all her mother’s pains and benefits
To laughter and contempt; that she may feel
How sharper than a serpent’s tooth it is
To have a thankless child! Away, away!
nouns: nature goddess purpose creature womb convey sterility organ increase body babe child spleen thwart disnatur’d torment wrinkle brow youth cadent tear channel cheek mother pain benefit laughter serpent tooth child
adjectives: dear thy fruitful derogate fret sharp thankless
verbs: hear hear suspend intend make dry spring honour teem create live let stamp turn contempt feel

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Never afflict yourself to know more of it;
But let his disposition have that scope
That dotage gives it.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I’ll tell thee. [_To Goneril._] Life and death! I am
asham’d
That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus;
That these hot tears, which break from me perforce,
Should make thee worth them. Blasts and fogs upon thee!
Th’untented woundings of a father’s curse
Pierce every sense about thee! Old fond eyes,
Beweep this cause again, I’ll pluck ye out,
And cast you with the waters that you lose
To temper clay. Ha! Let it be so.
I have another daughter,
Who, I am sure, is kind and comfortable:
When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails
She’ll flay thy wolvish visage. Thou shalt find
That I’ll resume the shape which thou dost think
I have cast off for ever.
nouns: life death thou hast power manhood tear perforce blast fog wounding father curse sense thee eye cause ye water temper clay daughter nail visage shalt shape thou dost
adjectives: hot old fond sure kind comfortable wolvish thou
verbs: tell shake break make worth th’untente pluck cast lose let hear flay find resume think cast

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
I cannot be so partial, Goneril,
To the great love I bear you,—

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Pray you, content. What, Oswald, ho!
[_To the Fool._] You, sir, more knave than fool, after your master.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Nuncle Lear, nuncle Lear, tarry and take the fool with thee.
   A fox when one has caught her,
   And such a daughter,
   Should sure to the slaughter,
   If my cap would buy a halter;
   So the fool follows after.
nouns: nuncle tarry fool fox daughter slaughter cap halter fool

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
This man hath had good counsel.—A hundred knights!
’Tis politic and safe to let him keep
At point a hundred knights: yes, that on every dream,
Each buzz, each fancy, each complaint, dislike,
He may enguard his dotage with their powers,
And hold our lives in mercy. Oswald, I say!
nouns: man counsel.—a knight point knight dream buzz fancy complaint dislike dotage power life mercy
verbs: GONERIL hath ti let keep enguard hold say

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Safer than trust too far:
Let me still take away the harms I fear,
Not fear still to be taken: I know his heart.
What he hath utter’d I have writ my sister:
If she sustain him and his hundred knights,
When I have show’d th’unfitness,—
nouns: harm heart utter’d sister knight th’unfitness
verbs: GONERIL trust let take fear fear take know hath writ sustain show’d

title: lear
verbs: GONERIL take inform thereto add compact get go hasten

title: lear
text:
No, no, my lord!
This milky gentleness and course of yours,
Though I condemn not, yet, under pardon,
You are much more attask’d for want of wisdom
Than prais’d for harmful mildness.
nouns: gentleness course your attask’d want wisdom prais’d mildness

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell:
Striving to better, oft we mar what’s well.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Go you before to Gloucester with these letters: acquaint my
daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her
demand out of the letter. If your diligence be not speedy, I
shall be there afore you.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Then I prythee be merry; thy wit shall not go slipshod.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly, for though
she’s as like this as a crab’s like an apple, yet I can tell
what I can tell.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
What canst tell, boy?

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
She’ll taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. Thou
canst tell why one’s nose stands i’the middle on’s face?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I will forget my nature. So kind a father! Be my horses ready?

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Thy asses are gone about ’em. The reason why the seven stars are
no more than seven is a pretty reason.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Yes indeed: thou wouldst make a good fool.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I’d have thee beaten for being
old before thy time.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!
Keep me in temper; I would not be mad!

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
She that’s a maid now, and laughs at my departure,
Shall not be a maid long, unless things be cut shorter.

title: lear
text:
CURAN.
Nay, I know not. You have heard of the news abroad; I mean the
whispered ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments?

title: lear
text:
CURAN.
Have you heard of no likely wars toward, ’twixt the two dukes
of Cornwall and Albany?

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
The Duke be here tonight? The better! best!
This weaves itself perforce into my business.
My father hath set guard to take my brother;
And I have one thing, of a queasy question,
Which I must act. Briefness and fortune work!
Brother, a word, descend, brother, I say!
nouns: tonight business father guard brother thing question briefness fortune work word brother
verbs: weave perforce hath set take act say

title: lear
text:
My father watches: O sir, fly this place;
Intelligence is given where you are hid;
You have now the good advantage of the night.
Have you not spoken ’gainst the Duke of Cornwall?
He’s coming hither; now, i’ the night, i’ the haste,
And Regan with him: have you nothing said
Upon his party ’gainst the Duke of Albany?
Advise yourself.
nouns: father sir place advantage night hither night haste party
verbs: watch fly give speak ’ come say advise

title: lear
text:
Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion
Of my more fierce endeavour: [_Wounds his arm._]
I have seen drunkards
Do more than this in sport. Father, father!
Stop, stop! No help?
nouns: blood opinion endeavour arm drunkard sport father help
verbs: draw beget wound see stop stop

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out,
Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the moon
To stand auspicious mistress.
nouns: dark sword mumbling charm moon mistress

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Persuade me to the murder of your lordship;
But that I told him the revenging gods
’Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend;
Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond
The child was bound to the father; sir, in fine,
Seeing how loathly opposite I stood
To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion
With his prepared sword, he charges home
My unprovided body, latch’d mine arm;
But when he saw my best alarum’d spirits,
Bold in the quarrel’s right, rous’d to th’encounter,
Or whether gasted by the noise I made,
Full suddenly he fled.
nouns: murder lordship god parricide thunder bond child father purpose motion sword body mine arm alarum’d spirit quarrel right noise
adjectives: manifold strong fine opposite unnatural fell prepared unprovided latch’d good full
verbs: persuade tell revenge bend speak bind see stand charge see rous’d th’encounter gaste make flee

title: lear
nouns: land dispatch’d master arch patron tonight authority thank coward stake death
verbs: let fly remain find come proclaim find deserve bring conceal

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
When I dissuaded him from his intent,
And found him pight to do it, with curst speech
I threaten’d to discover him: he replied,
‘Thou unpossessing bastard! dost thou think,
If I would stand against thee, would the reposal
Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee
Make thy words faith’d? No: what I should deny
As this I would; ay, though thou didst produce
My very character, I’d turn it all
To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice:
And thou must make a dullard of the world,
If they not thought the profits of my death
Were very pregnant and potential spurs
To make thee seek it.
nouns: intent speech bastard think reposal trust virtue word faith’d thou character suggestion plot practice thou dullard world profit death spur
adjectives: pight curst worth very pregnant potential
verbs: dissuade find discover reply unpossesse stand make deny produce turn damn make think make seek

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
O strange and fast’ned villain!
Would he deny his letter, said he? I never got him.

title: lear
text:
Hark, the Duke’s trumpets! I know not why he comes.
All ports I’ll bar; the villain shall not scape;
The Duke must grant me that: besides, his picture
I will send far and near, that all the kingdom
May have due note of him; and of my land,
Loyal and natural boy, I’ll work the means
To make thee capable.
nouns: trumpet port bar villain picture kingdom note land boy mean
verbs: know come scape grant send work make

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
How now, my noble friend! since I came hither,
Which I can call but now, I have heard strange news.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
If it be true, all vengeance comes too short
Which can pursue th’offender. How dost, my lord?

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
O madam, my old heart is crack’d, it’s crack’d!

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Was he not companion with the riotous knights
That tend upon my father?

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
No marvel then though he were ill affected:
’Tis they have put him on the old man’s death,
To have the expense and waste of his revenues.
I have this present evening from my sister
Been well inform’d of them; and with such cautions
That if they come to sojourn at my house,
I’ll not be there.
nouns: marvel man death expense waste revenue evening sister caution house
verbs: affect tis put be come sojourn

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Nor I, assure thee, Regan.
Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father
A childlike office.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
If he be taken, he shall never more
Be fear’d of doing harm: make your own purpose,
How in my strength you please. For you, Edmund,
Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant
So much commend itself, you shall be ours:
Natures of such deep trust we shall much need;
You we first seize on.
nouns: fear’d harm purpose strength virtue obedience instant our nature trust need
verbs: take do make please commend seize

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Thus out of season, threading dark-ey’d night:
Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise,
Wherein we must have use of your advice.
Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister,
Of differences, which I best thought it fit
To answer from our home; the several messengers
From hence attend dispatch. Our good old friend,
Lay comforts to your bosom; and bestow
Your needful counsel to our business,
Which craves the instant use.
nouns: season night poise Wherein use advice father writ sister difference home messenger dispatch friend comfort bosom counsel business use
adjectives: dark noble several good old needful instant
verbs: thread hath hath think fit answer attend bestow crave

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
I serve you, madam:
Your graces are right welcome.

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
Good dawning to thee, friend: art of this house?

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a base, proud,
shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy,
worsted-stocking knave; a lily-livered, action-taking, whoreson,
glass-gazing, super-serviceable, finical rogue;
one trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of
good service, and art nothing but the composition of a
knave, beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel
bitch: one whom I will beat into clamorous whining, if thou
deniest the least syllable of thy addition.
nouns: knave rascal eater meat base pound stocking knave action taking whoreson glass rogue trunk slave one bawd way service art composition coward pander son heir mongrel bitch whining syllable addition
adjectives: broken proud shallow filthy super - serviceable finical good beggar clamorous deni least
verbs: suit worst livere gaze inherit knave beat

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that’s
neither known of thee nor knows thee?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Strike, you slave; stand, rogue, stand; you neat slave, strike!

title: lear
text:
KENT.
With you, goodman boy, if you please: come, I’ll flesh ye; come
on, young master.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
No marvel, you have so bestirr’d your valour. You cowardly
rascal, nature disclaims in thee; a tailor made thee.
nouns: marvel bestirr’d valour nature disclaim tailor

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Thou art a strange fellow: a tailor make a man?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Ay, a tailor, sir: a stonecutter or a painter could not have
made him so ill, though he had been but two years at the trade.

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spared at suit of his grey
beard,—

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Thou whoreson zed! thou unnecessary letter! My lord, if you’ll
give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar and
daub the walls of a jakes with him. Spare my grey beard, you wagtail?
nouns: whoreson letter lord villain mortar wall jake grey
verbs: ze give leave tread daub spare wagtail

title: lear
text:
KENT.
That such a slave as this should wear a sword,
Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these,
Like rats, oft bite the holy cords a-twain
Which are too intrince t’unloose; smooth every passion
That in the natures of their lords rebel;
Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder moods;
Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks
With every gale and vary of their masters,
Knowing naught, like dogs, but following.
A plague upon your epileptic visage!
Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool?
Goose, if I had you upon Sarum plain,
I’d drive ye cackling home to Camelot.
nouns: slave sword honesty rogue rat cord twain intrince passion nature lord rebel oil fire snow mood halcyon beak gale vary master naught dog plague visage speech fool Goose plain ye home
adjectives: such holy smooth colder affirm epileptic
verbs: wear wear smile bite bring turn know follow smile drive cackle

title: lear
text:
KENT.
No contraries hold more antipathy
Than I and such a knave.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Why dost thou call him knave? What is his fault?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Sir, ’tis my occupation to be plain:
I have seen better faces in my time
Than stands on any shoulder that I see
Before me at this instant.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
This is some fellow
Who, having been prais’d for bluntness, doth affect
A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb
Quite from his nature: he cannot flatter, he,
An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth!
An they will take it, so; if not, he’s plain.
These kind of knaves I know which in this plainness
Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends
Than twenty silly-ducking observants
That stretch their duties nicely.
nouns: fellow prais’d bluntness doth saucy roughness garb nature mind truth kind knave plainness craft corrupter observant duty
verbs: have affect constrain flatter speak take ’ know harbour end duck stretch

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Sir, in good faith, in sincere verity,
Under th’allowance of your great aspect,
Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire
On flickering Phoebus’ front,—
nouns: faith verity th’allowance aspect influence wreath fire front

title: lear
text:
KENT.
To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. I know,
sir, I am no flatterer: he that beguiled you in a plain accent
was a plain knave; which, for my part, I will not be, though I
should win your displeasure to entreat me to’t.
nouns: dialect flatterer accent knave part displeasure
verbs: go discommend know beguile win entreat

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
I never gave him any:
It pleas’d the King his master very late
To strike at me, upon his misconstruction;
When he, compact, and flattering his displeasure,
Tripp’d me behind; being down, insulted, rail’d
And put upon him such a deal of man,
That worthied him, got praises of the King
For him attempting who was self-subdu’d;
And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit,
Drew on me here again.
nouns: master misconstruction displeasure rail’d deal man praise self subdu’d fleshment dread exploit
verbs: give pleas’d strike flatter Tripp’d insult put worthie get attempt

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Fetch forth the stocks!
You stubborn ancient knave, you reverent braggart,
We’ll teach you.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Sir, I am too old to learn:
Call not your stocks for me: I serve the King;
On whose employment I was sent to you:
You shall do small respect, show too bold malice
Against the grace and person of my master,
Stocking his messenger.
nouns: stock employment respect malice grace person master messenger
verbs: learn call serve send show stock

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
This is a fellow of the selfsame colour
Our sister speaks of. Come, bring away the stocks!

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Let me beseech your grace not to do so:
His fault is much, and the good King his master
Will check him for’t: your purpos’d low correction
Is such as basest and contemned’st wretches
For pilferings and most common trespasses,
Are punish’d with. The King must take it ill
That he, so slightly valued in his messenger,
Should have him thus restrained.
nouns: grace fault master for’t purpos’d correction basest wretch pilfering trespass messenger
adjectives: much good low such common punish’d ill
verbs: let beseech check take value restrain

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
My sister may receive it much more worse,
To have her gentleman abus’d, assaulted,
For following her affairs. Put in his legs.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
I am sorry for thee, friend; ’tis the Duke’s pleasure,
Whose disposition, all the world well knows,
Will not be rubb’d nor stopp’d; I’ll entreat for thee.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Pray do not, sir: I have watch’d, and travell’d hard;
Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I’ll whistle.
A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels:
Give you good morrow!
nouns: watch’d travell’d time rest whistle man fortune heel morrow

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Good King, that must approve the common saw,
Thou out of heaven’s benediction com’st
To the warm sun.
Approach, thou beacon to this under globe,
That by thy comfortable beams I may
Peruse this letter. Nothing almost sees miracles
But misery. I know ’tis from Cordelia,
Who hath most fortunately been inform’d
Of my obscured course. And shall find time
From this enormous state, seeking to give
Losses their remedies. All weary and o’erwatch’d,
Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold
This shameful lodging.
Fortune, good night: smile once more, turn thy wheel!
nouns: saw benediction sun beacon globe beam letter miracle misery tis course time state loss remedy o’erwatch’d vantage eye lodging night wheel
adjectives: common warm comfortable obscured enormous weary heavy shameful good
verbs: approve see know hath find seek give take behold smile turn

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
I heard myself proclaim’d,
And by the happy hollow of a tree
Escap’d the hunt. No port is free, no place
That guard and most unusual vigilance
Does not attend my taking. While I may scape
I will preserve myself: and am bethought
To take the basest and most poorest shape
That ever penury in contempt of man,
Brought near to beast: my face I’ll grime with filth,
Blanket my loins; elf all my hair in knots,
And with presented nakedness outface
The winds and persecutions of the sky.
The country gives me proof and precedent
Of Bedlam beggars, who, with roaring voices,
Strike in their numb’d and mortified bare arms
Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary;
And with this horrible object, from low farms,
Poor pelting villages, sheep-cotes, and mills,
Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers,
Enforce their charity. Poor Turlygod! poor Tom,
That’s something yet: Edgar I nothing am.
nouns: hollow tree escap’d hunt port place guard vigilance taking basest shape penury contempt man beast face filth loin hair knot nakedness outface wind persecution sky country proof precedent beggar voice numb’d arm prick nail sprig object farm pelting village sheep cote mill ban prayer charity
adjectives: happy free unusual poor bare wooden rosemary horrible low poor lunatic poor
verbs: hear attend scape preserve bethink take bring grime blanket present give roar mortify enforce ’

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
’Tis strange that they should so depart from home,
And not send back my messenger.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Ha, ha! he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the
heads; dogs and bears by the neck, monkeys by the loins, and
men by the legs: when a man is overlusty at legs, then he
wears wooden nether-stocks.
nouns: garter horse head dog bear neck monkey loin man leg man leg nether stock

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
They durst not do’t.
They could not, would not do’t; ’tis worse than murder,
To do upon respect such violent outrage:
Resolve me, with all modest haste, which way
Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage,
Coming from us.
nouns: murder outrage haste way mightst usage
verbs: durst tis respect resolve deserve impose come

title: lear
text:
KENT.
My lord, when at their home
I did commend your highness’ letters to them,
Ere I was risen from the place that show’d
My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post,
Stew’d in his haste, half breathless, panting forth
From Goneril his mistress salutations;
Deliver’d letters, spite of intermission,
Which presently they read; on those contents,
They summon’d up their meiny, straight took horse;
Commanded me to follow and attend
The leisure of their answer; gave me cold looks:
And meeting here the other messenger,
Whose welcome I perceiv’d had poison’d mine,
Being the very fellow which of late
Display’d so saucily against your highness,
Having more man than wit about me, drew;
He rais’d the house with loud and coward cries.
Your son and daughter found this trespass worth
The shame which here it suffers.
nouns: home highness letter place duty kneeling post haste breathless mistress salutation letter spite intermission content meiny horse leisure answer look messenger welcome perceiv’d poison’d mine fellow display’d highness man wit house cry son daughter trespass shame
