adjectives: half cold other late more loud coward worth
verbs: commend rise show’d come reek pant read summon’d take command follow attend give meet have draw rais’d find suffer

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Winter’s not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way.
  Fathers that wear rags
    Do make their children blind,
  But fathers that bear bags
    Shall see their children kind.
  Fortune, that arrant whore,
  Ne’er turns the key to th’ poor.
But for all this, thou shalt have as many dolours for thy
daughters as thou canst tell in a year.
nouns: geese way father rag child father bag child arrant whore ne’er key shalt dolour daughter tell year
adjectives: wild blind poor many thy canst
verbs: go fly wear make bear see kind turn th

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Made you no more offence but what you speak of?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
None.
How chance the King comes with so small a number?

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
We’ll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee there’s no
labouring i’the winter. All that follow their noses are led by
their eyes but blind men; and there’s not a nose among twenty
but can smell him that’s stinking. Let go thy hold when a great
wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with following
it; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw thee after.
When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again: I
would have none but knaves follow it, since a fool gives it.
          That sir which serves and seeks for gain,
             And follows but for form,
          Will pack when it begins to rain,
             And leave thee in the storm.
          But I will tarry; the fool will stay,
             And let the wise man fly:
          The knave turns fool that runs away;
             The fool no knave perdy.
nouns: ant winter nose eye man nose hold wheel hill neck one man thee counsel none knave fool sir gain form storm fool man knave fool fool knave perdy
adjectives: blind great great wise well wise
verbs: set school teach ’ labour follow lead ’ smell ’ stink let go run break follow go let draw give give follow give serve seek follow pack begin rain leave tarry stay let fly turn run

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Deny to speak with me? They are sick? they are weary?
They have travell’d all the night? Mere fetches;
The images of revolt and flying off.
Fetch me a better answer.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
My dear lord,
You know the fiery quality of the Duke;
How unremovable and fix’d he is
In his own course.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Inform’d them! Dost thou understand me, man?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
The King would speak with Cornwall; the dear father
Would with his daughter speak, commands, tends, service,
Are they inform’d of this? My breath and blood!
Fiery? The fiery Duke, tell the hot Duke that—
No, but not yet: maybe he is not well:
Infirmity doth still neglect all office
Whereto our health is bound: we are not ourselves
When nature, being oppress’d, commands the mind
To suffer with the body: I’ll forbear;
And am fallen out with my more headier will,
To take the indispos’d and sickly fit
For the sound man. [_Looking on Kent._]
Death on my state! Wherefore
Should he sit here? This act persuades me
That this remotion of the Duke and her
Is practice only. Give me my servant forth.
Go tell the Duke and’s wife I’d speak with them,
Now, presently: bid them come forth and hear me,
Or at their chamber door I’ll beat the drum
Till it cry sleep to death.
nouns: father daughter speak command tend service breath blood no doth office health nature oppress’d mind body will indispos’d man death state act remotion practice servant wife chamber door drum sleep death
adjectives: dear fiery hot well heady fit sound
verbs: speak tell neglect Whereto bind command suffer forbear fall take look sit persuade give go tell speak bid come hear beat cry

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put ’em
i’ the paste alive; she knapped ’em o’ the coxcombs
with a stick and cried ‘Down, wantons, down!’ ’Twas
her brother that, in pure kindness to his horse buttered his hay.
nouns: nuncle cockney eel paste coxcomb stick wanton brother kindness horse hay
verbs: cry put knap cry twa butter

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I am glad to see your highness.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Regan, I think you are; I know what reason
I have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad,
I would divorce me from thy mother’s tomb,
Sepulchring an adultress. [_To Kent_] O, are you free?
Some other time for that.—Beloved Regan,
Thy sister’s naught: O Regan, she hath tied
Sharp-tooth’d unkindness, like a vulture, here.
nouns: reason shouldst mother tomb adultress time sister naught tooth’d vulture
verbs: think know think divorce sepulchre hath tie

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I cannot think my sister in the least
Would fail her obligation. If, sir, perchance
She have restrain’d the riots of your followers,
’Tis on such ground, and to such wholesome end,
As clears her from all blame.
nouns: sister obligation sir restrain’d riot follower ground end blame

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
O, sir, you are old;
Nature in you stands on the very verge
Of her confine: you should be rul’d and led
By some discretion, that discerns your state
Better than you yourself. Therefore I pray you,
That to our sister you do make return;
Say you have wrong’d her, sir.
nouns: verge confine rul’d discretion state sister return
verbs: stand lead discern pray make say wrong’d

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Ask her forgiveness?
Do you but mark how this becomes the house?
‘Dear daughter, I confess that I am old;
[_Kneeling._]
Age is unnecessary: on my knees I beg
That you’ll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.’
nouns: forgiveness house daughter knee bed food
verbs: ask mark become confess beg vouchsafe

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Good sir, no more! These are unsightly tricks:
Return you to my sister.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
[_Rising._] Never, Regan:
She hath abated me of half my train;
Look’d black upon me; struck me with her tongue,
Most serpent-like, upon the very heart.
All the stor’d vengeances of heaven fall
On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones,
You taking airs, with lameness!
nouns: train look’d tongue serpent heart stor’d vengeance heaven top bone air
verbs: rise hath abate strike fall strike take

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames
Into her scornful eyes! Infect her beauty,
You fen-suck’d fogs, drawn by the powerful sun,
To fall and blast her pride!
nouns: lightning flame eye beauty fen suck’d fog sun pride

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
O the blest gods!
So will you wish on me when the rash mood is on.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse.
Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give
Thee o’er to harshness. Her eyes are fierce; but thine
Do comfort, and not burn. ’Tis not in thee
To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train,
To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes,
And, in conclusion, to oppose the bolt
Against my coming in. Thou better know’st
The offices of nature, bond of childhood,
Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude;
Thy half o’ the kingdom hast thou not forgot,
Wherein I thee endow’d.
nouns: thou shalt curse tender nature o’er eye thine comfort thee pleasure train bandy word size conclusion bolt office nature bond childhood effect courtesy due gratitude half o kingdom
verbs: heft give harshness burn tis grudge cut scant oppose come Thy thee endow’d

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
This is a slave, whose easy borrowed pride
Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.
Out, varlet, from my sight!

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Who stock’d my servant? Regan, I have good hope
Thou didst not know on’t. Who comes here? O heavens!

title: lear
text:
If you do love old men, if your sweet sway
Allow obedience, if yourselves are old,
Make it your cause; send down, and take my part!
[_To Goneril._] Art not asham’d to look upon this beard?
O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand?
nouns: man sway obedience yourself cause part art asham’d beard thou hand
verbs: love make send take look take

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Why not by the hand, sir? How have I offended?
All’s not offence that indiscretion finds
And dotage terms so.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
O sides, you are too tough!
Will you yet hold? How came my man i’ the stocks?

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
I set him there, sir: but his own disorders
Deserv’d much less advancement.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I pray you, father, being weak, seem so.
If, till the expiration of your month,
You will return and sojourn with my sister,
Dismissing half your train, come then to me:
I am now from home, and out of that provision
Which shall be needful for your entertainment.
nouns: father expiration month sister train home provision entertainment
verbs: pray seem return sojourn dismiss come

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Return to her, and fifty men dismiss’d?
No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose
To wage against the enmity o’ the air;
To be a comrade with the wolf and owl,
Necessity’s sharp pinch! Return with her?
Why, the hot-blooded France, that dowerless took
Our youngest born, I could as well be brought
To knee his throne, and, squire-like, pension beg
To keep base life afoot. Return with her?
Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter
To this detested groom.
nouns: man roof enmity o air comrade wolf owl pinch dowerless throne squire pension beg base life slave groom
verbs: return abjure choose wage return take bear bring knee keep return persuade detest

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I prythee, daughter, do not make me mad:
I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell:
We’ll no more meet, no more see one another.
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter;
Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh,
Which I must needs call mine. Thou art a boil,
A plague sore, or embossed carbuncle
In my corrupted blood. But I’ll not chide thee;
Let shame come when it will, I do not call it:
I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot,
Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove:
Mend when thou canst; be better at thy leisure:
I can be patient; I can stay with Regan,
I and my hundred knights.
nouns: daughter child farewell art flesh blood daughter disease flesh art boil plague carbuncle blood shame thunder bearer shoot tale leisure knight
adjectives: mad thou thou corrupted canst well patient
verbs: make trouble meet see ’ need call emboss chide let come call bid tell judge stay

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Not altogether so,
I look’d not for you yet, nor am provided
For your fit welcome. Give ear, sir, to my sister;
For those that mingle reason with your passion
Must be content to think you old, and so—
But she knows what she does.
verbs: look’d provide give mingle think know

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I dare avouch it, sir: what, fifty followers?
Is it not well? What should you need of more?
Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger
Speak ’gainst so great a number? How in one house
Should many people, under two commands,
Hold amity? ’Tis hard; almost impossible.
nouns: follower yea charge danger gainst number house people command amity
adjectives: avouch well more many great many impossible
verbs: dare need sith speak hold ti

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Why not, my lord? If then they chanc’d to slack ye,
We could control them. If you will come to me,—
For now I spy a danger,—I entreat you
To bring but five-and-twenty: to no more
Will I give place or notice.
verbs: chanc’d slack control come spy bring give notice

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
And in good time you gave it.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favour’d
When others are more wicked; not being the worst
Stands in some rank of praise.
[_To Goneril._] I’ll go with thee:
Thy fifty yet doth double five-and-twenty,
And thou art twice her love.
nouns: creature favour’d other rank praise doth art love

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Hear me, my lord:
What need you five-and-twenty? Ten? Or five?
To follow in a house where twice so many
Have a command to tend you?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
O, reason not the need: our basest beggars
Are in the poorest thing superfluous:
Allow not nature more than nature needs,
Man’s life is cheap as beast’s. Thou art a lady;
If only to go warm were gorgeous,
Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st
Which scarcely keeps thee warm. But, for true need,—
You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need!
You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,
As full of grief as age; wretched in both!
If it be you that stirs these daughters’ hearts
Against their father, fool me not so much
To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger,
And let not women’s weapons, water-drops,
Stain my man’s cheeks! No, you unnatural hags,
I will have such revenges on you both
That all the world shall,—I will do such things,—
What they are yet, I know not; but they shall be
The terrors of the earth. You think I’ll weep;
No, I’ll not weep:— [_Storm and tempest._]
I have full cause of weeping; but this heart
Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws
Or ere I’ll weep.—O fool, I shall go mad!
nouns: o reason need basest beggar thing nature nature need life beast art lady nature thou need heaven patience patience man grief age daughter heart father anger woman weapon water drop man cheek hag revenge world thing terror earth storm tempest cause weeping heart flaw fool
adjectives: poor superfluous more cheap thou warm gorgeous gorgeous warm true poor old full much noble unnatural such such full mad
verbs: allow go need keep give need see god wretche be stir fool bear touch let know think weep weep break go

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
’Tis his own blame; hath put himself from rest
And must needs taste his folly.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Followed the old man forth, he is return’d.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
’Tis best to give him way; he leads himself.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Alack, the night comes on, and the high winds
Do sorely ruffle; for many miles about
There’s scarce a bush.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
O, sir, to wilful men
The injuries that they themselves procure
Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors.
He is attended with a desperate train,
And what they may incense him to, being apt
To have his ear abus’d, wisdom bids fear.
nouns: man injury procure schoolmaster door train ear abus’d wisdom bid

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Shut up your doors, my lord; ’tis a wild night.
My Regan counsels well: come out o’ the storm.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Who’s there, besides foul weather?

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Contending with the fretful elements;
Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea,
Or swell the curled waters ’bove the main,
That things might change or cease; tears his white hair,
Which the impetuous blasts with eyeless rage,
Catch in their fury and make nothing of;
Strives in his little world of man to outscorn
The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain.
This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,
The lion and the belly-pinched wolf
Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs,
And bids what will take all.
nouns: element wind earth sea water thing hair blast rage fury strive world man fro wind rain night cub bear lion belly wolf fur
adjectives: fretful main white impetuous eyeless little dry unbonneted
verbs: contend bid blow swell curl change cease tear catch make outscorn conflict draw couch pinch keep run bid take

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Sir, I do know you;
And dare, upon the warrant of my note
Commend a dear thing to you. There is division,
Although as yet the face of it be cover’d
With mutual cunning, ’twixt Albany and Cornwall;
Who have, as who have not, that their great stars
Throne’d and set high; servants, who seem no less,
Which are to France the spies and speculations
Intelligent of our state. What hath been seen,
Either in snuffs and packings of the Dukes;
Or the hard rein which both of them have borne
Against the old kind King; or something deeper,
Whereof, perchance, these are but furnishings;—
But, true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this scatter’d kingdom; who already,
Wise in our negligence, have secret feet
In some of our best ports, and are at point
To show their open banner.—Now to you:
If on my credit you dare build so far
To make your speed to Dover, you shall find
Some that will thank you making just report
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The King hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding;
And from some knowledge and assurance
Offer this office to you.
nouns: warrant note thing division face cunning star throne’d servant spy speculation state hath snuff packing rein kind furnishing power scatter’d kingdom negligence foot port point banner.—now credit speed report bemadding sorrow cause gentleman blood breeding knowledge assurance office
adjectives: dear mutual great high less hard old deep true secret good open unnatural
verbs: know dare commend twixt set seem see bear come show dare build make find thank make hath plain offer

title: lear
text:
KENT.
No, do not.
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse, and take
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia,
As fear not but you shall, show her this ring;
And she will tell you who your fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the King.
nouns: no confirmation out wall purse fear ring fellow fie storm
verbs: open take contain see show tell know go seek

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Give me your hand: have you no more to say?

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Few words, but, to effect, more than all yet:
That, when we have found the King, in which your pain
That way, I’ll this; he that first lights on him
Holla the other.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage! blow!
You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout
Till you have drench’d our steeples, drown’d the cocks!
You sulphurous and thought-executing fires,
Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts,
Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,
Strike flat the thick rotundity o’ the world!
Crack nature’s moulds, all germens spill at once,
That make ingrateful man!
nouns: wind cheek rage blow cataract hurricanoe spout drench’d steeple cock thought fire vaunt courier thunderbolt head thunder rotundity o world nature mould germen man
verbs: crack drown’d execute oak cleave shake strike crack spill make

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
O nuncle, court holy-water in a dry house is better than this
rain-water out o’ door. Good nuncle, in; and ask thy daughters
blessing: here’s a night pities neither wise men nor fools.
nouns: nuncle court holy water house rain water o door nuncle daughter blessing night pity man fool

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! spout, rain!
Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters;
I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness.
I never gave you kingdom, call’d you children;
You owe me no subscription: then let fall
Your horrible pleasure. Here I stand your slave,
A poor, infirm, weak, and despis’d old man:
But yet I call you servile ministers,
That will with two pernicious daughters join
Your high-engender’d battles ’gainst a head
So old and white as this! O! O! ’tis foul!
nouns: fire spout rain rain wind thunder fire daughter element kingdom call’d child subscription pleasure slave man minister daughter engender’d battle head tis
adjectives: rumble bellyful unkindness horrible poor infirm weak old servile pernicious high old white
verbs: tax give owe let fall stand call join

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
He that has a house to put’s head in has a good head-piece.
   The codpiece that will house
     Before the head has any,
   The head and he shall louse:
     So beggars marry many.
   The man that makes his toe
     What he his heart should make
   Shall of a corn cry woe,
     And turn his sleep to wake.
For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a glass.
nouns: house head head piece codpiece head head beggar man toe heart corn cry woe sleep woman mouth glass
verbs: put house louse marry make make turn wake make

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece; that’s a wise man and a
fool.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night
Love not such nights as these; the wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark,
And make them keep their caves. Since I was man,
Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,
Such groans of roaring wind and rain I never
Remember to have heard. Man’s nature cannot carry
Th’affliction, nor the fear.
nouns: thing night night sky wanderer dark cave man sheet fire burst horrid thunder groan wind rain nature th’affliction fear
adjectives: such wrathful very such such such
verbs: love gallow make keep roar remember hear carry

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Let the great gods,
That keep this dreadful pudder o’er our heads,
Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch,
That hast within thee undivulged crimes
Unwhipp’d of justice. Hide thee, thou bloody hand;
Thou perjur’d, and thou simular of virtue
That art incestuous. Caitiff, to pieces shake
That under covert and convenient seeming
Hast practis’d on man’s life: close pent-up guilts,
Rive your concealing continents, and cry
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinn’d against than sinning.
nouns: god pudder o’er head enemy hast crime unwhipp’d justice thee hand perjur’d thou virtue art piece man life guilt continent summoner grace man
adjectives: great dreadful tremble thou undivulged thou bloody simular incestuous covert convenient close dreadful sinn’d
verbs: let keep find hide shake seem pen rive conceal cry sin

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Alack, bareheaded!
Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel;
Some friendship will it lend you ’gainst the tempest:
Repose you there, whilst I to this hard house,—
More harder than the stones whereof ’tis rais’d;
Which even but now, demanding after you,
Denied me to come in,—return, and force
Their scanted courtesy.
nouns: hovel friendship tempest house stone tis rais’d courtesy
verbs: bareheade lend repose whereof demand deny come force scant

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
My wits begin to turn.
Come on, my boy. How dost, my boy? Art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow?
The art of our necessities is strange,
That can make vile things precious. Come, your hovel.
Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
That’s sorry yet for thee.
nouns: wit boy boy art straw fellow art necessity thing hovel fool part heart
adjectives: dost cold cold strange vile precious poor sorry
verbs: begin turn come make come knave ’

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
[_Singing._]
   He that has and a little tiny wit,
     With heigh-ho, the wind and the rain,
   Must make content with his fortunes fit,
     Though the rain it raineth every day.
nouns: singing wit heigh wind rain content fortune rain day

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
True, boy. Come, bring us to this hovel.

title: lear
nouns: night courtezan prophecy ere priest word matter brewer malt water noble tailor tutor heretic burn’d wench suitor case law squire debt knight slander tongue cut purse throng usurer gold field bawd whore church realm confusion time us’d foot prophecy time
verbs: cool speak go mar live come tell build come come live go make live

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing. When I
desired their leave that I might pity him, they took from me the
use of mine own house; charged me on pain of perpetual displeasure,
neither to speak of him, entreat for him, or any way sustain him.
nouns: dealing leave use house pain displeasure way
verbs: like desire pity take charge speak entreat sustain

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Go to; say you nothing. There is division between the Dukes,
and a worse matter than that: I have received a letter this
night;—’tis dangerous to be spoken;—I have locked the letter
in my closet: these injuries the King now bears will be revenged
home; there’s part of a power already footed: we must incline to
the King. I will look him, and privily relieve him: go you and
maintain talk with the Duke, that my charity be not of him
perceived: if he ask for me, I am ill, and gone to bed. If I
die for it, as no less is threatened me, the King my old master
must be relieved. There is some strange thing toward, Edmund;
pray you be careful.
nouns: division matter letter night;—’tis letter closet injury home part power talk charity bed master thing
adjectives: bad dangerous ill old strange careful
verbs: go say receive spoken;—I lock bear revenge ’ foot incline look relieve go maintain perceive ask go die threaten relieve pray

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the Duke
Instantly know; and of that letter too.
This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me
That which my father loses, no less than all:
The younger rises when the old doth fall.
verbs: forbid know seem deserve draw lose rise

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Here is the place, my lord; good my lord, enter:
The tyranny of the open night’s too rough
For nature to endure.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Thou think’st ’tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin: so ’tis to thee,
But where the greater malady is fix’d,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou’dst shun a bear;
But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea,
Thou’dst meet the bear i’ the mouth. When the mind’s
free,
The body’s delicate: the tempest in my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to’t? But I will punish home;
No, I will weep no more. In such a night
To shut me out! Pour on; I will endure:
In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril!
Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all,
O, that way madness lies; let me shun that;
No more of that.
nouns: storm skin malady bear flight sea bear mouth mind body tempest mind sense feeling ingratitude mouth hand food to’t night night kind father heart o way madness
adjectives: contentious great less scarce free delicate filial more old frank more
verbs: tis invade tis feel shun lie rage meet take save beat tear lift punish weep shut pour endure give lie let shun

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Prythee go in thyself; seek thine own ease:
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I’ll go in.
[_To the Fool._] In, boy; go first. You houseless poverty,
Nay, get thee in. I’ll pray, and then I’ll sleep.
nouns: thine ease tempest thing boy poverty
verbs: go seek give leave ponder hurt go go houseless get pray sleep

title: lear
text:
Poor naked wretches, wheresoe’er you are,
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,
Your loop’d and window’d raggedness, defend you
From seasons such as these? O, I have ta’en
Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp;
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them
And show the heavens more just.
nouns: wretch wheresoe’er pelting pitiless storm houseless head side loop’d raggedness season care physic pomp wretch mayst superflux heaven
adjectives: poor naked unfed window’d such little thou
verbs: bide defend take expose feel feel shake show

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
A spirit, a spirit: he says his name’s poor Tom.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Away! the foul fiend follows me! Through the sharp hawthorn blows the
cold wind. Humh! go to thy cold bed, and warm thee.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Who gives anything to poor Tom? Whom the foul fiend hath led
through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlpool, o’er
bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pillow and
halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge; made him proud
of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horse over four-inched
bridges, to course his own shadow for a traitor. Bless thy five
wits! 	Tom’s a-cold. O, do, de, do, de, do, de. Bless thee from
whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do poor Tom some charity,
whom the foul fiend vexes. There could I have him now, and
there,—and there again, and there.
nouns: fiend hath fire flame o’er bog quagmire hath knife pillow halter pew porridge heart bay horse bridge shadow traitor wit de de whirlwind star blasting charity fiend vexe
adjectives: poor foul ratsbane proud own cold poor foul
verbs: give lead lay set make ride trot inch course bless ’ take

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air
Hang fated o’er men’s faults light on thy daughters!
nouns: plague air o’er man fault daughter

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Death, traitor! nothing could have subdu’d nature
To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Is it the fashion that discarded fathers
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Judicious punishment! ’twas this flesh begot
Those pelican daughters.
nouns: traitor nature lowness daughter fashion father mercy flesh punishment flesh daughter

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Take heed o’ th’ foul fiend: obey thy parents; keep thy word
justly; swear not; commit not with man’s sworn spouse; set not
thy sweet-heart on proud array. Tom’s a-cold.
nouns: th fiend parent word man spouse heart array
verbs: take obey keep swear commit swear set ’

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
A serving-man, proud in heart and mind; that curled my hair;
wore gloves in my cap; served the lust of my mistress’ heart, and
did the act of darkness with her; swore as many oaths as I spake
words, and broke them in the sweet face of heaven. One that
slept in the contriving of lust, and waked to do it. Wine loved
I deeply, dice dearly; and in woman out-paramour’d the Turk.
False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox
in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey.
Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray
thy poor heart to woman. Keep thy foot out of brothels, thy hand
out of plackets, thy pen from lender’s book, and defy the foul
fiend. Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind: says
suum, mun, nonny. Dolphin my boy, boy, sessa! let him trot by.
nouns: man heart mind hair glove cap lust mistress heart act darkness oath word face contriving lust dice woman paramour’d heart light ear hand greediness dog madness lion creaking shoe rustling silk heart woman foot brothel hand placket pen lender book fiend hawthorn wind nonny dolphin boy
adjectives: proud many sweet bloody poor thy foul cold
verbs: serve curl wear serve swear spake break sleep wake love let betray keep defy blow say let trot

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy uncovered
body this extremity of the skies. Is man no more than this? Consider
him well. Thou owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep no
wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! here’s three on’s are
sophisticated! Thou art the thing itself: unaccommodated man is no more
but such a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art. Off, off, you
lendings! Come, unbutton here.
nouns: thou wert grave body extremity sky man owest worm silk beast hide sheep wool cat perfume art thing man animal art lending
adjectives: uncovered more thou sophisticated thou unaccommodated poor bare thou

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Prythee, nuncle, be contented; ’tis a naughty night to swim
in. Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher’s
heart, a small spark, all the rest on’s body cold. Look, here
comes a walking fire.
nouns: nuncle night fire field lecher heart spark rest body fire
adjectives: naughty little wild old small cold
verbs: content tis swim look come walk

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet: he begins at curfew, and walks
till the first cock; he gives the web and the pin, squints the eye, and
makes the harelip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts the poor creature
of earth.
   Swithold footed thrice the old;
   He met the nightmare, and her nine-fold;
     Bid her alight and her troth plight,
   And aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!
nouns: fiend curfew walk cock web pin eye harelip wheat creature earth thrice nightmare fold alight plight thee witch
adjectives: foul first white poor old - troth
verbs: begin give squint make hurt foot meet bid aroint aroint

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Poor Tom; that eats the swimming frog, the toad, the todpole, the
wall-newt and the water; that in the fury of his heart, when the
foul fiend rages, eats cow-dung for sallets; swallows the old rat
and the ditch-dog; drinks the green mantle of the standing pool;
who is whipped from tithing to tithing, and stocked, punished,
and imprisoned; who hath had three suits to his back, six shirts
to his body,
     Horse to ride, and weapon to wear.
     But mice and rats and such small deer,
     Have been Tom’s food for seven long year.
Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin; peace, thou fiend!
nouns: swimming frog toad todpole wall newt water fury heart fiend rage cow sallet rat ditch dog pool tithing suit back shirt body weapon mouse rat deer food year follower peace peace fiend
adjectives: foul old green such small long thou
verbs: eat eat swallow drink stand whip tithe stock punish imprison hath ride wear beware

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
What, hath your grace no better company?

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Our flesh and blood, my lord, is grown so vile
That it doth hate what gets it.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Go in with me: my duty cannot suffer
T’obey in all your daughters’ hard commands;
Though their injunction be to bar my doors,
And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,
Yet have I ventur’d to come seek you out,
And bring you where both fire and food is ready.
nouns: duty daughter command injunction door night hold fire food
verbs: go suffer be bar let take come seek bring

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I’ll talk a word with this same learned Theban.
What is your study?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Let me ask you one word in private.

title: lear
lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Canst thou blame him?
His daughters seek his death. Ah, that good Kent!
He said it would be thus, poor banish’d man!
Thou sayest the King grows mad; I’ll tell thee, friend,
I am almost mad myself. I had a son,
Now outlaw’d from my blood; he sought my life
But lately, very late: I lov’d him, friend,
No father his son dearer: true to tell thee,
nouns: thou daughter death banish’d man friend son outlaw’d blood life friend father son dearer
adjectives: canst good poor say mad mad true
verbs: blame seek say grow tell seek tell

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
O, cry you mercy, sir.
Noble philosopher, your company.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
In, fellow, there, into the hovel; keep thee warm.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
   Child Rowland to the dark tower came,
   His word was still—Fie, foh, and fum,
   I smell the blood of a British man.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
I now perceive it was not altogether your brother’s evil
disposition made him seek his death; but a provoking merit, set
a-work by a reproveable badness in himself.
nouns: brother disposition death merit work badness

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to be just! This
is the letter he spoke of, which approves him an intelligent
party to the advantages of France. O heavens! that this treason
were not; or not I the detector!
nouns: fortune letter party advantage heaven treason detector

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester. Seek out
where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehension.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
[_Aside._] If I find him comforting the King, it will stuff his
suspicion more fully. I will persever in my course of loyalty,
though the conflict be sore between that and my blood.
nouns: king suspicion course loyalty conflict blood

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Here is better than the open air; take it thankfully. I will
piece out the comfort with what addition I can: I will not be
long from you.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Frateretto calls me; and tells me Nero is an angler in the lake
of darkness. Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
No, he’s a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son; for he’s a mad
yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.
nouns: yeoman gentleman son yeoman son gentleman

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
To have a thousand with red burning spits
Come hissing in upon ’em.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
The foul fiend bites my back.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
He’s mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse’s health,
a boy’s love, or a whore’s oath.
nouns: tameness wolf horse health boy love whore oath

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
It shall be done; I will arraign them straight.
[_To Edgar._] Come, sit thou here, most learned justicer;
[_To the Fool._] Thou, sapient sir, sit here. Now, you she-foxes!—
verbs: do arraign come sit learn sit

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Look, where he stands and glares! Want’st thou eyes at trial, madam?
  Come o’er the bourn, Bessy, to me.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale.
Hoppedance cries in Tom’s belly for two white herring. Croak not, black
angel; I have no food for thee.
nouns: fiend voice nightingale belly herring angel food

title: lear
lear
text:
LEAR.
I’ll see their trial first. Bring in their evidence.
[_To Edgar._] Thou, robed man of justice, take thy place.
[_To the Fool._] And thou, his yokefellow of equity,
Bench by his side. [_To Kent._] You are o’ the commission,
Sit you too.
nouns: trial evidence man justice place yokefellow equity side o commission

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
   Let us deal justly.
   Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?
     Thy sheep be in the corn;
   And for one blast of thy minikin mouth
     Thy sheep shall take no harm.
Purr! the cat is grey.
nouns: shepherd sheep corn blast mouth sheep harm Purr cat

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Arraign her first; ’tis Goneril. I here take my oath before
this honourable assembly, she kicked the poor King her father.

title: lear
text:
FOOL.
Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
And here’s another, whose warp’d looks proclaim
What store her heart is made on. Stop her there!
Arms, arms! sword! fire! Corruption in the place!
False justicer, why hast thou let her ’scape?
nouns: warp’d store heart arm arm sword fire corruption place justicer thou scape

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
[_Aside._] My tears begin to take his part so much
They mar my counterfeiting.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
The little dogs and all,
Trey, Blanch, and Sweetheart, see, they bark at me.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs!
   Be thy mouth or black or white,
   Tooth that poisons if it bite;
   Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim,
   Hound or spaniel, brach or him,
   Or bobtail tike or trundle-tail,
   Tom will make them weep and wail;
   For, with throwing thus my head,
   Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.
Do, de, de, de. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and fairs and market towns.
Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.
nouns: head mouth poison greyhound mongrel grim spaniel bobtail tike trundle tail wail head hatch wake fair market town horn
verbs: throw cur bite make weep throw leap flee come

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Then let them anatomize Regan; see what breeds about her
heart. Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard
hearts? [_To Edgar._] You, sir, I entertain you for one of my
hundred; only I do not like the fashion of your garments. You’ll
say they are Persian; but let them be changed.
nouns: heart cause nature heart sir fashion garment
verbs: let anatomize see breed make entertain like say let change

title: lear
nouns: friend prythee arm plot death litter friend shalt welcome protection master hour life thine loss provision conduct
verbs: take o’erheard lay drive meet take shouldst offer defend stand take take follow give

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Oppressed nature sleeps.
This rest might yet have balm’d thy broken sinews,
Which, if convenience will not allow,
Stand in hard cure. Come, help to bear thy master;
[_To the Fool._] Thou must not stay behind.
nouns: nature sleep rest sinew convenience cure master
verbs: oppress balm’d allow stand come help bear stay

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
When we our betters see bearing our woes,
We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Who alone suffers, suffers most i’ the mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind:
But then the mind much sufferance doth o’erskip
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship.
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that which makes me bend makes the King bow;
He childed as I fathered! Tom, away!
Mark the high noises; and thyself bewray,
When false opinion, whose wrong thoughts defile thee,
In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee.
What will hap more tonight, safe ’scape the King!
Lurk, lurk.
nouns: better woe misery foe mind thing show mind sufferance grief hath mate fellowship light pain noise opinion thought thee repeal reconcile tonight lurk
adjectives: free happy much high false wrong proof more safe
verbs: see bear think suffer suffer leave bear portable seem make bend make bow childe father mark bewray defile scape

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our sister
company: the revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous
father are not fit for your beholding. Advise the Duke where you
are going, to a most festinate preparation: we are bound to the
like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.
Farewell, dear sister, farewell, my lord of Gloucester.
nouns: displeasure sister company revenge father beholding preparation post betwixt sister lord
adjectives: edmund traitorous fit festinate swift intelligent dear
verbs: leave keep bind take advise go bind

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
My lord of Gloucester hath convey’d him hence:
Some five or six and thirty of his knights,
Hot questrists after him, met him at gate;
Who, with some other of the lord’s dependants,
Are gone with him toward Dover: where they boast
To have well-armed friends.
nouns: lord hath knight questrist gate dependant friend

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Bind fast his corky arms.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
What mean your graces?
Good my friends, consider you are my guests.
Do me no foul play, friends.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Unmerciful lady as you are, I’m none.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find—

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Naughty lady,
These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin
Will quicken, and accuse thee. I am your host:
With robber’s hands my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?
nouns: lady hair thou ravish chin host hand favour

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Be simple answer’d, for we know the truth.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
To whose hands have you sent the lunatic King?
Speak.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
I have a letter guessingly set down,
Which came from one that’s of a neutral heart,
And not from one oppos’d.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charg’d at peril,—

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
In hell-black night endur’d, would have buoy’d up,
And quench’d the stelled fires;
Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
If wolves had at thy gate howl’d that stern time,
Thou shouldst have said, ‘Good porter, turn the key.’
All cruels else subscrib’d: but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.
nouns: nail eye sister flesh boarish fang sea storm head hell night buoy’d fire heart heaven rain wolf time shouldst porter key subscrib’d vengeance child
adjectives: cruel poor old fierce anointed bare black poor old stern good such
verbs: see pluck quench’d stelle holp say turn cruel see wing overtake

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
He that will think to live till he be old,
Give me some help!—O cruel! O you gods!

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
One side will mock another; the other too!

title: lear
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
Hold your hand, my lord:
I have serv’d you ever since I was a child;
But better service have I never done you
Than now to bid you hold.

title: lear
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
If you did wear a beard upon your chin,
I’d shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?

title: lear
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
Nay, then, come on, and take the chance of anger.

title: lear
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
O, I am slain! My lord, you have one eye left
To see some mischief on him. O!

title: lear
text: [_Tears out Gloucester’s other eye and throws it on the ground._]

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
All dark and comfortless. Where’s my son Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature
To quit this horrid act.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Out, treacherous villain!
Thou call’st on him that hates thee: it was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us;
Who is too good to pity thee.

title: lear
text:
CORNWALL.
I have receiv’d a hurt: follow me, lady.
Turn out that eyeless villain. Throw this slave
Upon the dunghill. Regan, I bleed apace:
Untimely comes this hurt: give me your arm.
nouns: receiv’d hurt lady villain slave dunghill apace hurt arm
verbs: follow turn throw bleed come give

title: lear
text:
SECOND SERVANT.
I’ll never care what wickedness I do,
If this man come to good.

title: lear
text:
THIRD SERVANT.
If she live long,
And in the end meet the old course of death,
Women will all turn monsters.

title: lear
text:
SECOND SERVANT.
Let’s follow the old Earl, and get the bedlam
To lead him where he would: his roguish madness
Allows itself to anything.

title: lear
text:
THIRD SERVANT.
Go thou: I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
To apply to his bleeding face. Now heaven help him!

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Yet better thus, and known to be contemn’d,
Than still contemn’d and flatter’d. To be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:
The lamentable change is from the best;
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace;
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts.
nouns: contemn’d contemn’d flatter’d thing fortune esperance fear change return laughter air wretch blast
adjectives: bad low dejected lamentable good bad unsubstantial bad thy
verbs: know stand live embrace blow owe

title: lear
text:
But who comes here? My father, poorly led?
World, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Life would not yield to age.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Away, get thee away; good friend, be gone.
Thy comforts can do me no good at all;
Thee they may hurt.

title: lear
text:
OLD MAN.
You cannot see your way.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;
I stumbled when I saw. Full oft ’tis seen
Our means secure us, and our mere defects
Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar,
The food of thy abused father’s wrath!
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I’d say I had eyes again!
nouns: way eye tis mean defect commodity son food father wrath touch eye
verbs: want stumble see see secure prove abuse live see say

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
[_Aside._] O gods! Who is’t can say ‘I am at the
worst’?
I am worse than e’er I was.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
He has some reason, else he could not beg.
I’ the last night’s storm I such a fellow saw;
Which made me think a man a worm. My son
Came then into my mind, and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him.
I have heard more since.
As flies to wanton boys are we to the gods,
They kill us for their sport.
nouns: reason night storm saw man worm son mind mind friend fly boy god sport
verbs: beg make think come hear wanton kill

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Then prythee get thee away. If for my sake
Thou wilt o’ertake us hence a mile or twain,
I’ the way toward Dover, do it for ancient love,
And bring some covering for this naked soul,
Which I’ll entreat to lead me.
nouns: prythee sake wilt mile twain way love covering soul

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
’Tis the time’s plague when madmen lead the blind.
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure;
Above the rest, be gone.
nouns: time plague madman thee pleasure rest

title: lear
text:
OLD MAN.
I’ll bring him the best ’parel that I have,
Come on’t what will.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
[_Aside._] And yet I must. Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Both stile and gate, horseway and footpath. Poor Tom hath been
scared out of his good wits. Bless thee, good man’s son, from
the foul fiend! Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of
lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of darkness; Mahu, of
stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and
mowing, who since possesses chambermaids and waiting women. So,
bless thee, master!
nouns: gate horseway footpath hath wit man son fiend fiend lust prince darkness murder chambermaid woman master
verbs: stile be bless steal mop mow possess wait bless

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Here, take this purse, thou whom the heaven’s plagues
Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier. Heavens deal so still!
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he does not feel, feel your power quickly;
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?
nouns: purse plague stroke man ordinance power distribution excess man thou
verbs: take humble make deal let diet slave see feel feel undo know

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
There is a cliff, whose high and bending head
Looks fearfully in the confined deep:
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And I’ll repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me: from that place
I shall no leading need.
nouns: cliff head brim misery thou dost place need

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Welcome, my lord. I marvel our mild husband
Not met us on the way. Now, where’s your master?

title: lear
nouns: man army answer treachery service son turn’d side
adjectives: chang’d bad loyal sot wrong most pleasant offensive
verbs: tell land smil’d tell come inform’d call’d tell dislike seem like

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
[_To Edmund._] Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit,
That dares not undertake. He’ll not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother;
Hasten his musters and conduct his powers.
I must change names at home, and give the distaff
Into my husband’s hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us. Ere long you are like to hear,
If you dare venture in your own behalf,
A mistress’s command. [_Giving a favour._]
Wear this; spare speech;
Decline your head. This kiss, if it durst speak,
Would stretch thy spirits up into the air.
Conceive, and fare thee well.
nouns: terror spirit wrong answer wish way effect brother muster power name home distaff husband hand servant venture behalf mistress command favour speech head kiss spirit air
verbs: GONERIL go dare undertake feel tie prove conduct change give pass hear dare give wear decline durst speak stretch fare

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
My most dear Gloucester.
O, the difference of man and man!
To thee a woman’s services are due;
My fool usurps my body.
nouns: difference man man woman service fool body

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
I have been worth the whistle.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
O Goneril!
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face! I fear your disposition;
That nature which contemns its origin
Cannot be bordered certain in itself.
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap, perforce must wither
And come to deadly use.
nouns: dust wind face disposition nature origin material perforce use
verbs: blow fear contemn border sliver disbranch wither come

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
No more; the text is foolish.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile;
Filths savour but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform’d?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whose reverence even the head-lugg’d bear would lick,
Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you madded.
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man, a prince, by him so benefitted!
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vile offences,
It will come,
Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
Like monsters of the deep.
nouns: wisdom goodness vile savour tiger daughter father man reverence head lugg’d bear brother man prince heaven spirit offence prey monster
adjectives: vile gracious aged barbarous most degenerate good visible vile deep
verbs: seem filth do lick mad suffer benefit send tame come perforce

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Milk-liver’d man!
That bear’st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs;
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know’st
Fools do those villains pity who are punish’d
Ere they have done their mischief. Where’s thy drum?
France spreads his banners in our noiseless land;
With plumed helm thy state begins to threat,
Whilst thou, a moral fool, sitt’st still, and criest
‘Alack, why does he so?’
nouns: milk liver’d man cheek blow head wrong brow eye honour suffering villain pity mischief drum banner land state thou fool criest
verbs: GONERIL hast discern do ’ spread plume begin threat

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
See thyself, devil!
Proper deformity seems not in the fiend
So horrid as in woman.

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
O vain fool!

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Thou changed and self-cover’d thing, for shame!
Be-monster not thy feature! Were’t my fitness
To let these hands obey my blood,
They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
Thy flesh and bones. Howe’er thou art a fiend,
A woman’s shape doth shield thee.
nouns: self cover’d thing shame monster feature fitness hand blood tear flesh bone art fiend woman shape

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Marry, your manhood, mew!

title: lear
text:
MESSENGER.
O, my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall’s dead;
Slain by his servant, going to put out
The other eye of Gloucester.

title: lear
text:
MESSENGER.
A servant that he bred, thrill’d with remorse,
Oppos’d against the act, bending his sword
To his great master; who, thereat enrag’d,
Flew on him, and amongst them fell’d him dead;
But not without that harmful stroke which since
Hath pluck’d him after.
nouns: messenger servant remorse act sword master enrag’d fell’d stroke pluck’d

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
This shows you are above,
You justicers, that these our nether crimes
So speedily can venge! But, O poor Gloucester!
Lost he his other eye?

title: lear
text:
MESSENGER.
Both, both, my lord.
This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer;
’Tis from your sister.

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
[_Aside._] One way I like this well;
But being widow, and my Gloucester with her,
May all the building in my fancy pluck
Upon my hateful life. Another way
The news is not so tart. I’ll read, and answer.
nouns: way widow building pluck life way news

title: lear
text:
MESSENGER.
No, my good lord; I met him back again.

title: lear
text:
MESSENGER.
Ay, my good lord. ’Twas he inform’d against him;
And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment
Might have the freer course.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Gloucester, I live
To thank thee for the love thou show’dst the King,
And to revenge thine eyes. Come hither, friend,
Tell me what more thou know’st.
nouns: love thou thine eye hither friend
verbs: live thank show’dst revenge come tell

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Something he left imperfect in the state, which since his coming
forth is thought of, which imports to the kingdom so much fear
and danger that his personal return was most required and
necessary.
verbs: leave think import fear danger require

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Ay, sir; she took them, read them in my presence;
And now and then an ample tear trill’d down
Her delicate cheek. It seem’d she was a queen
Over her passion; who, most rebel-like,
Sought to be king o’er her.
nouns: presence tear trill’d cheek queen passion rebel king

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Not to a rage: patience and sorrow strove
Who should express her goodliest. You have seen
Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears
Were like a better day. Those happy smilets
That play’d on her ripe lip seem’d not to know
What guests were in her eyes; which parted thence
As pearls from diamonds dropp’d. In brief,
Sorrow would be a rarity most belov’d,
If all could so become it.
nouns: rage patience sorrow goodliest rain smile tear day smilet play’d lip guest eye thence pearl diamond brief rarity belov’d
verbs: express see seem’d know part become

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Made she no verbal question?

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Faith, once or twice she heav’d the name of ‘father’
Pantingly forth, as if it press’d her heart;
Cried ‘Sisters, sisters! Shame of ladies! sisters!
Kent! father! sisters! What, i’ the storm? i’ the night?
Let pity not be believ’d!’ There she shook
The holy water from her heavenly eyes,
And clamour master’d her: then away she started
To deal with grief alone.
nouns: name father heart sister sister shame lady sister sister storm night pity water eye master’d grief
verbs: heav’d press’d cry let shake clamour start deal

title: lear
text:
KENT.
It is the stars,
The stars above us govern our conditions;
Else one self mate and make could not beget
Such different issues. You spoke not with her since?
nouns: star star condition self mate issue

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear’s i’ the town;
Who sometime, in his better tune, remembers
What we are come about, and by no means
Will yield to see his daughter.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
A sovereign shame so elbows him. His own unkindness,
That stripp’d her from his benediction, turn’d her
To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights
To his dog-hearted daughters, these things sting
His mind so venomously that burning shame
Detains him from Cordelia.
nouns: shame benediction turn’d casualty right dog daughter thing mind shame
adjectives: sovereign own unkindness foreign dear hearted
verbs: elbow stripp’d give ste burn detain

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Well, sir, I’ll bring you to our master Lear
And leave you to attend him. Some dear cause
Will in concealment wrap me up awhile;
When I am known aright, you shall not grieve
Lending me this acquaintance.
I pray you, go along with me.
verbs: bring leave attend wrap know grieve lend pray go

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Alack, ’tis he: why, he was met even now
As mad as the vex’d sea; singing aloud;
Crown’d with rank fumiter and furrow weeds,
With harlocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,
Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
In our sustaining corn. A century send forth;
Search every acre in the high-grown field,
And bring him to our eye.
nouns: CORDELIA he sea rank fumiter weed harlock hemlock nettle cuckoo flower weed corn century acre field eye
verbs: tis meet singe grow sustain send search grow bring

title: lear
text:
What can man’s wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved sense,
He that helps him take all my outward worth.

title: lear
text:
PHYSICIAN.
There is means, madam:
Our foster nurse of nature is repose,
The which he lacks; that to provoke in him
Are many simples operative, whose power
Will close the eye of anguish.
nouns: mean nurse nature simple power eye anguish

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
All bless’d secrets,
All you unpublish’d virtues of the earth,
Spring with my tears! Be aidant and remediate
In the good man’s distress! Seek, seek for him;
Lest his ungovern’d rage dissolve the life
That wants the means to lead it.
nouns: CORDELIA bless’d secret virtue earth tear man distress rage life mean
verbs: unpublish’d remediate seek seek dissolve want lead

title: lear
lear
text:
CORDELIA.
’Tis known before. Our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear father,
It is thy business that I go about;
Therefore great France
My mourning and important tears hath pitied.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite,
But love, dear love, and our ag’d father’s right:
Soon may I hear and see him!
nouns: CORDELIA preparation expectation father business mourning tear ambition arm incite love love ag’d father right
verbs: ti know stand go hath pity doth hear see

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.
It was great ignorance, Gloucester’s eyes being out,
To let him live. Where he arrives he moves
All hearts against us. Edmund, I think, is gone
In pity of his misery, to dispatch
His nighted life; moreover to descry
The strength o’ th’enemy.
nouns: matter ignorance eye heart pity misery life strength o th’enemy
verbs: post let live arrive move think go dispatch descry

title: lear
lear
text:
REGAN.
Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you
Transport her purposes by word? Belike,
Somethings, I know not what, I’ll love thee much.
Let me unseal the letter.
verbs: write transport know love let unseal

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I know your lady does not love her husband;
I am sure of that; and at her late being here
She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks
To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.
adjectives: sure late strange most speaking noble

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I speak in understanding; y’are, I know’t:
Therefore I do advise you take this note:
My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk’d,
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your lady’s. You may gather more.
If you do find him, pray you give him this;
And when your mistress hears thus much from you,
I pray desire her call her wisdom to her.
So, fare you well.
If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,
Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.
nouns: understanding note lord talk’d hand lady mistress wisdom chance traitor
verbs: speak know’t advise take gather find pray give hear pray desire call fare hear fall cut

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
When shall I come to the top of that same hill?

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Horrible steep.
Hark, do you hear the sea?

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect
By your eyes’ anguish.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Y’are much deceiv’d: in nothing am I chang’d
But in my garments.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Come on, sir; here’s the place. Stand still. How fearful
And dizzy ’tis to cast one’s eyes so low!
The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as beetles. Half way down
Hangs one that gathers samphire—dreadful trade!
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head.
The fishermen that walk upon the beach
Appear like mice; and yond tall anchoring bark,
Diminish’d to her cock; her cock a buoy
Almost too small for sight: the murmuring surge
That on th’unnumber’d idle pebble chafes
Cannot be heard so high. I’ll look no more;
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.
nouns: place tis eye crow air beetle way one trade methink head fisherman beach mouse yond anchoring bark diminish’d cock cock buoy sight surge th’unnumber’d chafe brain turn sight
adjectives: fearful dizzy low scarce gross half dreadful big tall small idle pebble high more deficient
verbs: come ’ stand cast chough we gather seem walk appear murmur hear look

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Let go my hand.
Here, friend, ’s another purse; in it a jewel
Well worth a poor man’s taking. Fairies and gods
Prosper it with thee! Go thou further off;
Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.
nouns: hand friend purse jewel man taking fairy god farewell
verbs: let go ’ prosper go bid let hear go

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
O you mighty gods!
This world I do renounce, and in your sights,
Shake patiently my great affliction off:
If I could bear it longer, and not fall
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,
My snuff and loathed part of nature should
Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!
Now, fellow, fare thee well.
nouns: god world renounce sight affliction opposeless will snuff part nature fellow
verbs: shake bear fall quarrel loathe burn live bless fare

title: lear
text:
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The treasury of life when life itself
Yields to the theft. Had he been where he thought,
By this had thought been past. Alive or dead?
Ho you, sir! friend! Hear you, sir? speak!
Thus might he pass indeed: yet he revives.
What are you, sir?
nouns: conceit treasury life life yield theft friend
verbs: know rob think think hear pass revive

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,
So many fathom down precipitating,
Thou’dst shiver’d like an egg: but thou dost breathe;
Hast heavy substance; bleed’st not; speak’st; art sound.
Ten masts at each make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell.
Thy life is a miracle. Speak yet again.
nouns: thou aught gossamer feather air precipitating egg thou substance art sound mast altitude thou life miracle
verbs: be fathom dost hast make fall speak

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.
Look up a-height, the shrill-gorg’d lark so far
Cannot be seen or heard. Do but look up.
nouns: dread summit bourn height shrill gorg’d lark

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Alack, I have no eyes.
Is wretchedness depriv’d that benefit
To end itself by death? ’Twas yet some comfort
When misery could beguile the tyrant’s rage
And frustrate his proud will.
nouns: eye wretchedness depriv’d death comfort misery tyrant rage will

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
As I stood here below, methought his eyes
Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses,
Horns whelk’d and waved like the enraged sea.
It was some fiend. Therefore, thou happy father,
Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours
Of men’s impossibilities, have preserv’d thee.
nouns: eye moon nose horn whelk’d sea fiend father god man impossibility preserv’d
verbs: stand methought wave think make honour

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
I do remember now: henceforth I’ll bear
Affliction till it do cry out itself
‘Enough, enough,’ and die. That thing you speak of,
I took it for a man; often ’twould say,
‘The fiend, the fiend’; he led me to that place.
verbs: remember bear cry die speak take say lead

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Bear free and patient thoughts. But who comes here?

title: lear
text:
The safer sense will ne’er accommodate
His master thus.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Nature’s above art in that respect. There’s your press money.
That fellow handles his bow like a crow-keeper: draw me a clothier’s
yard. Look, look, a mouse! Peace, peace, this piece of toasted cheese
will do’t. There’s my gauntlet; I’ll prove it on a giant.
Bring up the brown bills. O, well flown, bird! i’ the clout, i’
the clout. Hewgh! Give the word.
nouns: art respect press money fellow bow crow keeper clothier yard mouse peace peace piece cheese gauntlet giant bill bird clout clout word
verbs: ’ handle draw look look toast ’ prove bring give

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Ha! Goneril with a white beard! They flattered me like a dog; and told
me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones were there. To say
‘ay’ and ‘no’ to everything I said ‘ay’
and ‘no’ to was no good divinity. When the rain came to wet
me once, and the wind to make me chatter; when the thunder would not
peace at my bidding; there I found ’em, there I smelt ’em out.
Go to, they are not men o’ their words: they told me I was everything;
’tis a lie, I am not ague-proof.
nouns: beard dog hair beard ere one ay ay divinity rain wind thunder peace bidding man word lie ague proof
verbs: flatter tell say say come wet make chatter find smell go tell tis

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Ay, every inch a king.
When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
I pardon that man’s life. What was thy cause?
Adultery? Thou shalt not die: die for adultery! No:
The wren goes to’t, and the small gilded fly
Does lecher in my sight. Let copulation thrive;
For Gloucester’s bastard son was kinder to his father
Than my daughters got ’tween the lawful sheets.
To’t, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers.
Behold yond simp’ring dame,
Whose face between her forks presages snow;
That minces virtue, and does shake the head
To hear of pleasure’s name.
The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to’t with a more riotous
appetite. Down from the waist they are centaurs, though women all
above. But to the girdle do the gods inherit, beneath is all the
fiend’s; there’s hell, there’s darkness, there is the sulphurous pit;
burning, scalding, stench,
consumption. Fie, fie, fie! pah, pah! Give me an ounce of civet, good
apothecary, to sweeten my imagination. There’s money for thee.
nouns: inch king stare quake man life cause adultery shalt adultery no wren to’t fly sight copulation bastard son father daughter sheet luxury pell mell soldier yond dame face fork presage snow head pleasure name fitchew horse to’t appetite waist centaur woman girdle god inherit fiend hell darkness pit burning scalding stench consumption fie ounce civet apothecary imagination money
adjectives: subject thou small gilded kind lawful behold soiled riotous sulphurous good
verbs: see pardon die die go lecher let thrive get tween lack simp’re mince virtue shake hear go ’ ’ give sweeten ’

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
O ruin’d piece of nature, this great world
Shall so wear out to naught. Dost thou know me?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou squiny at me?
No, do thy worst, blind Cupid; I’ll not love.
Read thou this challenge; mark but the penning of it.
nouns: thine eye thou squiny no thou challenge mark penning

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your head, nor no money
in your purse? Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse in a
light, yet you see how this world goes.
nouns: eye head money purse eye case purse light world

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
What, art mad? A man may see how the world goes with no eyes.
Look with thine ears. See how yon justice rails upon yon simple
thief. Hark, in thine ear: change places; and, handy-dandy, which
is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen a farmer’s
dog bark at a beggar?
nouns: art man world eye thine ear justice rail yon thief thine ear place dandy justice thief hast farmer dog bark beggar
verbs: see go look see change see

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightst behold
the great image of authority: a dog’s obeyed in office.
Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand!
Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back;
Thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind
For which thou whipp’st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.
Through tatter’d clothes great vices do appear;
Robes and furr’d gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold,
And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks;
Arm it in rags, a pygmy’s straw does pierce it.
None does offend, none, I say none; I’ll able ’em;
Take that of me, my friend, who have the power
To seal the accuser’s lips. Get thee glass eyes,
And like a scurvy politician, seem
To see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now:
Pull off my boots: harder, harder, so.
nouns: creature cur thou image authority dog office beadle hand lash whore thine kind thou usurer cozener clothe vice robe furr’d gown sin gold lance justice hurtless break rag pygmy straw none none none friend power accuser lip glass eye politician thing thou boot
adjectives: great rascal bloody dost thou great plate strong able thee scurvy hard hard
verbs: run behold obey hold own lust use hang appear hide arm pierce offend say ’ll take seal get seem see dost pull

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough, thy name is Gloucester.
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know’st the first time that we smell the air
We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee: mark.
nouns: wilt fortune eye name hither time air cry mark
verbs: weep take know come cry smell wawl preach

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
When we are born, we cry that we are come
To this great stage of fools. This a good block:
It were a delicate stratagem to shoe
A troop of horse with felt. I’ll put’t in proof
And when I have stol’n upon these son-in-laws,
Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
nouns: stage fool block stratagem shoe troop horse felt proof stol’n son law
verbs: bear cry come kill kill kill kill kill kill

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
O, here he is: lay hand upon him. Sir,
Your most dear daughter—

title: lear
nouns: rescue prisoner fool fortune ransom surgeon brain

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom.
What! I will be jovial. Come, come,
I am a king, my masters, know you that.

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
You are a royal one, and we obey you.

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,
Past speaking of in a king! Thou hast one daughter
Who redeems nature from the general curse
Which twain have brought her to.
nouns: sight wretch past king hast daughter nature curse twain

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Most sure and vulgar.
Everyone hears that, which can distinguish sound.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
But, by your favour,
How near’s the other army?

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Near and on speedy foot; the main descry
Stands on the hourly thought.

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
You ever-gentle gods, take my breath from me;
Let not my worser spirit tempt me again
To die before you please.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
A most poor man, made tame to fortune’s blows;
Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows,
Am pregnant to good pity. Give me your hand,
I’ll lead you to some biding.
nouns: man tame blow art sorrow pity hand biding

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
A proclaim’d prize! Most happy!
That eyeless head of thine was first fram’d flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old unhappy traitor,
Briefly thyself remember. The sword is out
That must destroy thee.
nouns: proclaim’d prize head thine flesh fortune traitor sword
adjectives: happy eyeless first fram’d thou old unhappy

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
Now let thy friendly hand
Put strength enough to’t.

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
Wherefore, bold peasant,
Dar’st thou support a publish’d traitor? Hence;
Lest that th’infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.
nouns: peasant traitor th’infection fortune take hold arm

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Chill not let go, zir, without vurther ’casion.

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
Let go, slave, or thou diest!

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor volke pass. An chud ha’
bin zwaggered out of my life, ’twould not ha’ bin zo long
as ’tis by a vortnight. Nay, come not near th’old man; keep
out, che vor ye, or ise try whether your costard or my ballow be the
harder: chill be plain with you.
nouns: gentleman gait pass chud life tis vortnight th’old man vor ise costard ballow chill
verbs: go let zwaggere come keep try

title: lear
text:
OSWALD.
Slave, thou hast slain me. Villain, take my purse.
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body;
And give the letters which thou find’st about me
To Edmund, Earl of Gloucester. Seek him out
Upon the British party. O, untimely death!
nouns: purse wilt thrive body letter party death

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
I know thee well. A serviceable villain,
As duteous to the vices of thy mistress
As badness would desire.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Sit you down, father; rest you.
Let’s see these pockets; the letters that he speaks of
May be my friends. He’s dead; I am only sorry
He had no other deathsman. Let us see:
Leave, gentle wax; and, manners, blame us not.
To know our enemies’ minds, we rip their hearts,
Their papers is more lawful.
[_Reads._] ‘Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have many
opportunities to cut him off: if your will want not, time and place
will be fruitfully offered. There is nothing done if he return the
conqueror: then am I the prisoner, and his bed my gaol; from the
loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply the place for your
labour. ‘Your (wife, so I would say) affectionate servant, ‘Goneril.’
O indistinguish’d space of woman’s will!
A plot upon her virtuous husband’s life,
And the exchange my brother! Here in the sands
Thee I’ll rake up, the post unsanctified
Of murderous lechers: and in the mature time,
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death-practis’d Duke: for him ’tis well
That of thy death and business I can tell.
nouns: father pocket letter friend deathsman wax manner enemy mind heart paper read vow opportunity time place conqueror prisoner bed gaol warmth place labour wife servant o indistinguish’d space woman will plot husband life exchange brother sand post lecher time paper strike sight death practis’d death business
adjectives: dead sorry other gentle lawful reciprocal many virtuous murderous mature ungracious
verbs: sit rest let see speak ’ let see leave blame know rip let remember cut want offer do return loathe whereof deliver supply say affectionate rake unsanctifie tis tell

title: lear
text:
GLOUCESTER.
The King is mad: how stiff is my vile sense,
That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling
Of my huge sorrows! Better I were distract:
So should my thoughts be sever’d from my griefs,
And woes by wrong imaginations lose
The knowledge of themselves.
nouns: sense feeling sorrow distract thought grief woe imagination knowledge
adjectives: mad stiff vile ingenious huge sever’d wrong

title: lear
text:
Lear on a bed, asleep, soft
music playing; Physician, Gentleman and others
attending.

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work
To match thy goodness? My life will be too short,
And every measure fail me.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
To be acknowledg’d, madam, is o’erpaid.
All my reports go with the modest truth;
Nor more, nor clipp’d, but so.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Pardon, dear madam;
Yet to be known shortens my made intent.
My boon I make it that you know me not
Till time and I think meet.
verbs: know make make know think meet

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
O you kind gods,
Cure this great breach in his abused nature!
The untun’d and jarring senses, O, wind up
Of this child-changed father.
nouns: CORDELIA god breach nature sense wind child father

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Be govern’d by your knowledge, and proceed
I’ the sway of your own will. Is he array’d?

title: lear
text:
PHYSICIAN.
Ay, madam. In the heaviness of sleep
We put fresh garments on him.
Be by, good madam, when we do awake him;
I doubt not of his temperance.
nouns: madam heaviness sleep garment madam temperance

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
