O my dear father! Restoration hang
Thy medicine on my lips; and let this kiss
Repair those violent harms that my two sisters
Have in thy reverence made!
nouns: CORDELIA father restoration hang medicine lip harm sister reverence

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
Had you not been their father, these white flakes
Did challenge pity of them. Was this a face
To be oppos’d against the warring winds?
To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick cross lightning? to watch, poor perdu!
With this thin helm? Mine enemy’s dog,
Though he had bit me, should have stood that night
Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father,
To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn
In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!
’Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes; speak to him.
nouns: CORDELIA father flake challenge pity face oppos’d wind dread thunder stroke cross lightning perdu helm enemy dog night fire fain father swine rogue straw life wit
adjectives: white deep terrible nimble quick poor thin mine thou poor forlorn short musty alack
verbs: war stand bolt watch bite stand wast hovel wonder conclude wake speak

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
You do me wrong to take me out o’ the grave.
Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound
Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears
Do scald like molten lead.
nouns: o grave art soul bliss wheel fire tear scald lead

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight?
I am mightily abus’d. I should e’en die with pity,
To see another thus. I know not what to say.
I will not swear these are my hands: let’s see;
I feel this pin prick. Would I were assur’d
Of my condition!
nouns: daylight abus’d pity hand pin prick assur’d condition
verbs: e’en die see know say swear let see feel

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Pray, do not mock me:
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less;
And to deal plainly,
I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtful: for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is; and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments; nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me;
For, as I am a man, I think this lady
To be my child Cordelia.
nouns: man hour mind methink man place skill garment lodge night man lady child
adjectives: foolish fond old perfect doubtful ignorant last
verbs: mock deal fear know know remember know laugh think

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Be your tears wet? Yes, faith. I pray weep not:
If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
I know you do not love me; for your sisters
Have, as I do remember, done me wrong.
You have some cause, they have not.
verbs: pray weep drink know love remember do

title: lear
text:
PHYSICIAN.
Be comforted, good madam, the great rage,
You see, is kill’d in him: and yet it is danger
To make him even o’er the time he has lost.
Desire him to go in; trouble him no more
Till further settling.
verbs: comfort see make o’er lose desire go trouble settle

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so slain?

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent
in Germany.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Report is changeable. ’Tis time to look about; the powers of
the kingdom approach apace.

title: lear
text:
GENTLEMAN.
The arbitrement is like to be bloody.
Fare you well, sir.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
My point and period will be throughly wrought,
Or well or ill, as this day’s battle’s fought.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is advis’d by aught
To change the course, he’s full of alteration
And self-reproving, bring his constant pleasure.
nouns: purpose hold advis’d aught course alteration self reproving pleasure

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Now, sweet lord,
You know the goodness I intend upon you:
Tell me but truly, but then speak the truth,
Do you not love my sister?

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
I am doubtful that you have been conjunct
And bosom’d with her, as far as we call hers.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Our very loving sister, well be-met.
Sir, this I heard: the King is come to his daughter,
With others whom the rigour of our state
Forc’d to cry out. Where I could not be honest,
I never yet was valiant. For this business,
It toucheth us as France invades our land,
Not bolds the King, with others whom I fear
Most just and heavy causes make oppose.
nouns: sister daughter other rigour state business land other cause
verbs: meet hear come cry toucheth invade bold fear make oppose

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Combine together ’gainst the enemy;
For these domestic and particular broils
Are not the question here.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
If e’er your grace had speech with man so poor,
Hear me one word.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Before you fight the battle, ope this letter.
If you have victory, let the trumpet sound
For him that brought it: wretched though I seem,
I can produce a champion that will prove
What is avouched there. If you miscarry,
Your business of the world hath so an end,
And machination ceases. Fortune love you!
nouns: battle letter victory trumpet champion business world end machination fortune
verbs: fight ope let sound bring seem produce prove avouch miscarry hath cease love

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
The enemy’s in view; draw up your powers.
Here is the guess of their true strength and forces
By diligent discovery; but your haste
Is now urg’d on you.
nouns: enemy view power guess strength force discovery haste

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
To both these sisters have I sworn my love;
Each jealous of the other, as the stung
Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?
Both? One? Or neither? Neither can be enjoy’d,
If both remain alive. To take the widow
Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril;
And hardly shall I carry out my side,
Her husband being alive. Now, then, we’ll use
His countenance for the battle; which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him devise
His speedy taking off. As for the mercy
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The battle done, and they within our power,
Shall never see his pardon: for my state
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.
nouns: sister love stung adder widow sister side husband countenance battle speedy mercy battle power pardon state
adjectives: jealous other enjoy’d alive mad alive
verbs: swear take remain take make carry use do let rid devise take intend do see stand defend debate

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Here, father, take the shadow of this tree
For your good host; pray that the right may thrive:
If ever I return to you again,
I’ll bring you comfort.
nouns: father shadow tree host right comfort

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Away, old man, give me thy hand, away!
King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta’en:
Give me thy hand; come on!

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
What, in ill thoughts again? Men must endure
Their going hence, even as their coming hither;
Ripeness is all. Come on.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Some officers take them away: good guard
Until their greater pleasures first be known
That are to censure them.

title: lear
text:
CORDELIA.
We are not the first
Who with best meaning have incurr’d the worst.
For thee, oppressed King, I am cast down;
Myself could else out-frown false fortune’s frown.
Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters?
nouns: CORDELIA meaning incurr’d thee fortune frown daughter sister

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
No, no, no, no. Come, let’s away to prison:
We two alone will sing like birds i’ the cage:
When thou dost ask me blessing I’ll kneel down
And ask of thee forgiveness. So we’ll live,
And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues
Talk of court news; and we’ll talk with them too,
Who loses and who wins; who’s in, who’s out;
And take upon’s the mystery of things,
As if we were God’s spies. And we’ll wear out,
In a wall’d prison, packs and sects of great ones
That ebb and flow by the moon.
nouns: no prison bird cage thou blessing forgiveness tale butterfly rogue talk court news ’ mystery thing spy wall’d prison pack sect one ebb flow moon
verbs: come let sing ask kneel ask live pray sing tell laugh hear talk lose win ’ ’ take wear

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia,
The gods themselves throw incense. Have I caught thee?
He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven,
And fire us hence like foxes. Wipe thine eyes;
The good years shall devour them, flesh and fell,
Ere they shall make us weep!
We’ll see ’em starve first: come.
nouns: sacrifice god incense brand fox wipe thine eye year flesh
verbs: throw catch part bring fire devour fall make weep see starve come

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Come hither, captain, hark.
Take thou this note [_giving a paper_]; go follow them to prison.
One step I have advanc’d thee; if thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To noble fortunes: know thou this, that men
Are as the time is; to be tender-minded
Does not become a sword. Thy great employment
Will not bear question; either say thou’lt do’t,
Or thrive by other means.
nouns: hither captain thou note paper prison step advanc’d thee instruct thee dost way fortune man time tender sword employment question mean
verbs: Come take give go follow dost make know become bear say thou’lt thrive

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Sir, you have show’d today your valiant strain,
And fortune led you well: you have the captives
Who were the opposites of this day’s strife:
I do require them of you, so to use them
As we shall find their merits and our safety
May equally determine.
nouns: today strain fortune captive opposite day strife merit safety
verbs: show’d lead require use find determine

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Sir, I thought it fit
To send the old and miserable King
To some retention and appointed guard;
Whose age has charms in it, whose title more,
To pluck the common bosom on his side,
And turn our impress’d lances in our eyes
Which do command them. With him I sent the queen;
My reason all the same; and they are ready
Tomorrow, or at further space, to appear
Where you shall hold your session. At this time
We sweat and bleed: the friend hath lost his friend;
And the best quarrels in the heat are curs’d
By those that feel their sharpness.
The question of Cordelia and her father
Requires a fitter place.
nouns: retention guard age charm title bosom side impress’d lance eye queen reason space session time friend hath friend quarrel heat sharpness question father fitter place
adjectives: old miserable common same ready further good
verbs: think fit send appoint pluck turn command send appear hold sweat bleed lose feel require

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
Not so hot:
In his own grace he doth exalt himself,
More than in your addition.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
In my rights,
By me invested, he compeers the best.

title: lear
text:
REGAN.
Lady, I am not well; else I should answer
From a full-flowing stomach. General,
Take thou my soldiers, prisoners, patrimony;
Dispose of them, of me; the walls are thine:
Witness the world that I create thee here
My lord and master.
nouns: stomach thou soldier prisoner patrimony wall world lord master

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
The let-alone lies not in your good will.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Stay yet; hear reason: Edmund, I arrest thee
On capital treason; and, in thine arrest,
This gilded serpent. [_pointing to Goneril._]
For your claim, fair sister,
I bar it in the interest of my wife;
’Tis she is sub-contracted to this lord,
And I her husband contradict your bans.
If you will marry, make your loves to me,
My lady is bespoke.
nouns: reason capital treason thine arrest serpent claim sister interest wife husband ban love lady
verbs: stay hear arrest gild point bar tis - contract contradict marry make

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Thou art arm’d, Gloucester. Let the trumpet sound:
If none appear to prove upon thy person
Thy heinous, manifest, and many treasons,
There is my pledge. [_Throwing down a glove._]
I’ll make it on thy heart,
Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less
Than I have here proclaim’d thee.
nouns: art trumpet none person treason pledge glove heart bread art
verbs: let sound appear prove Thy throw make taste proclaim’d

title: lear
text:
Trust to thy single virtue; for thy soldiers,
All levied in my name, have in my name
Took their discharge.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
She is not well. Convey her to my tent.

title: lear
text:
HERALD.
[_Reads._] ‘If any man of quality or degree within the lists of
the army will maintain upon Edmund, supposed Earl of Gloucester,
that he is a manifold traitor, let him appear by the third sound
of the trumpet. He is bold in his defence.’
nouns: read man quality degree list army traitor sound trumpet defence

title: lear
text:
Third trumpet. Trumpet answers within. Enter Edgar, armed, preceded by
 a trumpet.

title: lear
text:
HERALD.
What are you?
Your name, your quality? and why you answer
This present summons?

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Know my name is lost;
By treason’s tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit.
Yet am I noble as the adversary
I come to cope.
nouns: name treason tooth canker bit adversary

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Draw thy sword,
That if my speech offend a noble heart,
Thy arm may do thee justice: here is mine.
Behold, it is the privilege of mine honours,
My oath, and my profession: I protest,
Maugre thy strength, youth, place, and eminence,
Despite thy victor sword and fire-new fortune,
Thy valour and thy heart, thou art a traitor;
False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father;
Conspirant ’gainst this high illustrious prince;
And, from the extremest upward of thy head
To the descent and dust beneath thy foot,
A most toad-spotted traitor. Say thou ‘No,’
This sword, this arm, and my best spirits are bent
To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak,
Thou liest.
nouns: sword speech heart arm thee justice privilege mine oath profession strength youth place eminence victor sword fire fortune valour heart traitor god brother father prince head descent dust foot toad traitor thou no sword arm spirit heart liest
adjectives: noble new high illustrious extreme good bent
verbs: draw offend honour protest art spot say prove speak

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
In wisdom I should ask thy name;
But since thy outside looks so fair and warlike,
And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes,
What safe and nicely I might well delay
By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn.
Back do I toss those treasons to thy head,
With the hell-hated lie o’erwhelm thy heart;
Which for they yet glance by and scarcely bruise,
This sword of mine shall give them instant way,
Where they shall rest for ever. Trumpets, speak!
nouns: wisdom name look tongue breeding breathe rule knighthood spurn treason head hell lie heart sword way trumpet
adjectives: outside fair warlike safe o’erwhelm instant
verbs: ask say delay disdain toss hate glance bruise give rest speak

title: lear
text:
GONERIL.
This is mere practice, Gloucester:
By the law of arms thou wast not bound to answer
An unknown opposite; thou art not vanquish’d,
But cozen’d and beguil’d.
nouns: practice law arm thou opposite art cozen’d

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Shut your mouth, dame,
Or with this paper shall I stop it. Hold, sir;
Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil.
No tearing, lady; I perceive you know it.
nouns: mouth dame paper hold name thine evil lady

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
What you have charg’d me with, that have I done;
And more, much more; the time will bring it out.
’Tis past, and so am I. But what art thou
That hast this fortune on me? If thou’rt noble,
I do forgive thee.
verbs: charg’d do bring ti hast forgive

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Let’s exchange charity.
I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund;
If more, the more thou hast wrong’d me.
My name is Edgar and thy father’s son.
The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices
Make instruments to plague us:
The dark and vicious place where thee he got
Cost him his eyes.
nouns: charity blood art hast name son god vice instrument place eye
adjectives: less thou more thou pleasant dark vicious
verbs: let exchange wrong’d make plague get cost

title: lear
lear
text:
ALBANY.
Methought thy very gait did prophesy
A royal nobleness. I must embrace thee.
Let sorrow split my heart if ever I
Did hate thee or thy father.
verbs: Methought prophesy embrace let split hate

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
By nursing them, my lord. List a brief tale;
And when ’tis told, O that my heart would burst!
The bloody proclamation to escape
That follow’d me so near,—O, our lives’ sweetness!
That with the pain of death we’d hourly die
Rather than die at once!—taught me to shift
Into a madman’s rags; t’assume a semblance
That very dogs disdain’d; and in this habit
Met I my father with his bleeding rings,
Their precious stones new lost; became his guide,
Led him, begg’d for him, sav’d him from despair;
Never,—O fault!—reveal’d myself unto him
Until some half hour past, when I was arm’d;
Not sure, though hoping of this good success,
I ask’d his blessing, and from first to last
Told him my pilgrimage. But his flaw’d heart,
Alack, too weak the conflict to support!
’Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief,
Burst smilingly.
nouns: lord tale heart proclamation near,—o life sweetness pain death once!—taught madman rag semblance dog habit father bleeding ring stone guide despair never,—o hour past success blessing pilgrimage heart conflict extreme passion joy grief
adjectives: brief bloody precious new half sure good last flaw’d weak
verbs: nurse list tell burst escape follow’d ’d die die shift t’assume disdain’d lose become lead begg’d fault!—reveal’d hope ask’d tell support twixt burst

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
This speech of yours hath mov’d me,
And shall perchance do good, but speak you on;
You look as you had something more to say.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
If there be more, more woeful, hold it in;
For I am almost ready to dissolve,
Hearing of this.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
This would have seem’d a period
To such as love not sorrow; but another,
To amplify too much, would make much more,
And top extremity.
Whilst I was big in clamour, came there a man
Who, having seen me in my worst estate,
Shunn’d my abhorr’d society; but then finding
Who ’twas that so endur’d, with his strong arms
He fastened on my neck, and bellow’d out
As he’d burst heaven; threw him on my father;
Told the most piteous tale of Lear and him
That ever ear receiv’d, which in recounting
His grief grew puissant, and the strings of life
Began to crack. Twice then the trumpets sounded,
And there I left him tranc’d.
nouns: period love extremity clamour man estate abhorr’d society arm neck father tale grief puissant string life trumpet
adjectives: such sorrow more top big bad strong piteous
verbs: seem’d amplify make come have see shunn’d find twa fasten bellow’d burst throw tell ear recount grow begin crack sound leave

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
Kent, sir, the banish’d Kent; who in disguise
Follow’d his enemy king and did him service
Improper for a slave.

title: lear
text:
Enter a Gentleman hastily,
with a bloody knife.

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
What means this bloody knife?

title: lear
lear
text:
ALBANY.
Produce their bodies, be they alive or dead.
This judgement of the heavens that makes us tremble
Touches us not with pity. O, is this he?
The time will not allow the compliment
Which very manners urges.
nouns: body judgement heaven pity time compliment manner

title: lear
text:
KENT.
I am come
To bid my King and master aye good night:
Is he not here?

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Great thing of us forgot!
Speak, Edmund, where’s the King? and where’s Cordelia?

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
Yet Edmund was belov’d.
The one the other poisoned for my sake,
And after slew herself.

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
I pant for life. Some good I mean to do,
Despite of mine own nature. Quickly send,
Be brief in it, to the castle; for my writ
Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia;
Nay, send in time.
nouns: life nature castle writ life time

title: lear
text:
EDMUND.
He hath commission from thy wife and me
To hang Cordelia in the prison, and
To lay the blame upon her own despair,
That she fordid herself.

title: lear
text:
Enter Lear with Cordelia dead in his arms; Edgar,
Officer and others following.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Howl, howl, howl, howl! O, you are men of stone.
Had I your tongues and eyes, I’ld use them so
That heaven’s vault should crack. She’s gone for ever!
I know when one is dead, and when one lives;
She’s dead as earth. Lend me a looking glass;
If that her breath will mist or stain the stone,
Why, then she lives.
nouns: howl howl howl man stone tongue eye I’ld vault earth glass breath stone
verbs: use crack ’ go know live ’ lend look mist stain live

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
’Tis noble Kent, your friend.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
A plague upon you, murderers, traitors all!
I might have sav’d her; now she’s gone for ever!
Cordelia, Cordelia! stay a little. Ha!
What is’t thou say’st? Her voice was ever soft,
Gentle, and low, an excellent thing in woman.
I kill’d the slave that was a-hanging thee.
nouns: plague murderer traitor voice thing woman slave thee

title: lear
text:
OFFICER.
’Tis true, my lords, he did.

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
Did I not, fellow?
I have seen the day, with my good biting falchion
I would have made them skip. I am old now,
And these same crosses spoil me. Who are you?
Mine eyes are not o’ the best, I’ll tell you straight.
adjectives: fellow good old same mine good
verbs: see bite make skip spoil tell

title: lear
lear
text:
KENT.
That from your first of difference and decay
Have follow’d your sad steps.

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Nor no man else. All’s cheerless, dark and deadly.
Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves,
And desperately are dead.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
That’s but a trifle here.
You lords and noble friends, know our intent.
What comfort to this great decay may come
Shall be applied. For us, we will resign,
During the life of this old majesty,
To him our absolute power;
[_to Edgar and Kent_] you to your rights;
With boot and such addition as your honours
Have more than merited. All friends shall taste
The wages of their virtue and all foes
The cup of their deservings. O, see, see!
nouns: trifle lord friend intent comfort decay life majesty power _ right boot addition honour friend wage virtue foe cup deserving
adjectives: noble great old absolute such more
verbs: ’ know come apply resign _ merit taste see see

title: lear
text:
LEAR.
And my poor fool is hang’d! No, no, no life!
Why should a dog, a horse, a rat have life,
And thou no breath at all? Thou’lt come no more,
Never, never, never, never, never!
Pray you undo this button. Thank you, sir.
Do you see this? Look on her: look, her lips,
Look there, look there!
nouns: fool life dog horse rat life breath button lip
verbs: come pray undo thank see look look look look

title: lear
text:
KENT.
Vex not his ghost: O, let him pass! He hates him
That would upon the rack of this rough world
Stretch him out longer.

title: lear
text:
ALBANY.
Bear them from hence. Our present business
Is general woe. [_To Edgar and Kent._] Friends of my soul, you twain,
Rule in this realm and the gor’d state sustain.
nouns: business woe friend soul realm state sustain

title: lear
text:
EDGAR.
The weight of this sad time we must obey;
Speak what we feel, not what we ought to say.
The oldest hath borne most; we that are young
Shall never see so much, nor live so long.
verbs: obey speak feel say bear see live

title: romeo_juliet
text: *** START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK ROMEO AND JULIET ***

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ACT II
CHORUS.
Scene I. An open place adjoining Capulet’s Garden.
Scene II. Capulet’s Garden.
Scene III. Friar Lawrence’s Cell.
Scene IV. A Street.
Scene V. Capulet’s Garden.
Scene VI. Friar Lawrence’s Cell.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ACT III
Scene I. A public Place.
Scene II. A Room in Capulet’s House.
Scene III. Friar Lawrence’s cell.
Scene IV. A Room in Capulet’s House.
Scene V. An open Gallery to Juliet’s Chamber, overlooking the Garden.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CHORUS.
Two households, both alike in dignity,
In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
From ancient grudge break to new mutiny,
Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean.
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes
A pair of star-cross’d lovers take their life;
Whose misadventur’d piteous overthrows
Doth with their death bury their parents’ strife.
The fearful passage of their death-mark’d love,
And the continuance of their parents’ rage,
Which, but their children’s end, nought could remove,
Is now the two hours’ traffic of our stage;
The which, if you with patient ears attend,
What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.
nouns: household dignity scene grudge break mutiny blood hand loin foe pair star cross’d lover life misadventur’d piteous death parent strife passage death mark’d love continuance parent rage child end nought hour traffic stage ear toil
adjectives: fair ancient new civil civil unclean fatal fearful patient
verbs: lay make take overthrow bury remove attend miss strive mend

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SAMPSON.
I mean, if we be in choler, we’ll draw.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
GREGORY.
But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
GREGORY.
To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand: therefore, if thou
art moved, thou runn’st away.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
GREGORY.
That shows thee a weak slave, for the weakest goes to the wall.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SAMPSON.
True, and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to
the wall: therefore I will push Montague’s men from the wall, and
thrust his maids to the wall.
nouns: sampson woman vessel wall man wall maid wall

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SAMPSON.
’Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I have fought with the
men I will be civil with the maids, I will cut off their heads.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SAMPSON.
Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and ’tis known I am a
pretty piece of flesh.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
GREGORY.
’Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou hadst been poor John.
Draw thy tool; here comes of the house of Montagues.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SAMPSON.
My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SAMPSON.
But if you do, sir, I am for you. I serve as good a man as you.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
TYBALT.
What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
Turn thee Benvolio, look upon thy death.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!

title: romeo_juliet
text:
PRINCE.
Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,—
Will they not hear? What, ho! You men, you beasts,
That quench the fire of your pernicious rage
With purple fountains issuing from your veins,
On pain of torture, from those bloody hands
Throw your mistemper’d weapons to the ground
And hear the sentence of your moved prince.
Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,
By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,
Have thrice disturb’d the quiet of our streets,
And made Verona’s ancient citizens
Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,
To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
Canker’d with peace, to part your canker’d hate.
If ever you disturb our streets again,
Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time all the rest depart away:
You, Capulet, shall go along with me,
And Montague, come you this afternoon,
To know our farther pleasure in this case,
To old Free-town, our common judgement-place.
Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.
nouns: subject enemy peace neighbour steel man beast fire rage fountain vein pain torture hand mistemper’d weapon ground sentence prince brawl airy word thrice disturb’d street citizen beseeming ornament partisan hand canker’d peace canker’d street life forfeit peace time rest depart afternoon pleasure case town judgement place pain death man
adjectives: rebellious pernicious purple bloody moved civil thee old quiet ancient grave old old farther old free common more
verbs: stain hear quench issue throw hear breed make Cast wield part hate disturb pay go come know depart

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MONTAGUE.
Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?
Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Here were the servants of your adversary
And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.
I drew to part them, in the instant came
The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepar’d,
Which, as he breath’d defiance to my ears,
He swung about his head, and cut the winds,
Who nothing hurt withal, hiss’d him in scorn.
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows
Came more and more, and fought on part and part,
Till the Prince came, who parted either part.
nouns: servant adversary your approach instant fiery sword prepar’d defiance ear head wind withal scorn thrust blow part part part
verbs: fight draw part come breath’d swing cut hurt hiss’d interchange come fight come part

title: romeo_juliet
text:
LADY MONTAGUE.
O where is Romeo, saw you him today?
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Madam, an hour before the worshipp’d sun
Peer’d forth the golden window of the east,
A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad,
Where underneath the grove of sycamore
That westward rooteth from this city side,
So early walking did I see your son.
Towards him I made, but he was ware of me,
And stole into the covert of the wood.
I, measuring his affections by my own,
Which then most sought where most might not be found,
Being one too many by my weary self,
Pursu’d my humour, not pursuing his,
And gladly shunn’d who gladly fled from me.
nouns: hour worshipp’d sun window east mind grove sycamore rooteth city side walking son covert wood affection self humour
adjectives: golden troubled westward early ware own most many weary
verbs: drave walk see make steal measure seek find Pursu’d pursue shunn’d flee

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MONTAGUE.
Many a morning hath he there been seen,
With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew,
Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;
But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
Should in the farthest east begin to draw
The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed,
Away from light steals home my heavy son,
And private in his chamber pens himself,
Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out
And makes himself an artificial night.
Black and portentous must this humour prove,
Unless good counsel may the cause remove.
nouns: montague morning hath tear morning dew cloud cloud sigh sun east curtain bed steal son chamber pen window daylight night humour counsel cause remove
adjectives: many fresh more deep farth shady light heavy private fair artificial black portentous good
verbs: be see augment add cheer begin draw shut lock make prove

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MONTAGUE.
Both by myself and many other friends;
But he, his own affections’ counsellor,
Is to himself—I will not say how true—
But to himself so secret and so close,
So far from sounding and discovery,
As is the bud bit with an envious worm
Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,
Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.
Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow,
We would as willingly give cure as know.
nouns: montague friend affection counsellor discovery bud bit worm leave air beauty sun whence sorrow cure
adjectives: many other own true secret close envious sweet
verbs: say sound spread dedicate learn grow give

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MONTAGUE.
I would thou wert so happy by thy stay
To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let’s away,

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Ay me, sad hours seem long.
Was that my father that went hence so fast?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Not having that which, having, makes them short.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Alas that love so gentle in his view,
Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Alas that love, whose view is muffled still,
Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!
Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?
Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.
Here’s much to do with hate, but more with love:
Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!
O anything, of nothing first create!
O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
Misshapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health!
Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!
This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
Dost thou not laugh?
nouns: ROMEO love view eye pathway will fray hate love brawling love hate lightness vanity chaos form lead smoke fire health sleep love love thou
adjectives: much heavy serious bright cold sick laugh
verbs: muffle see dine tell hear ’ love create seem wake feel feel

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Why such is love’s transgression.
Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,
Which thou wilt propagate to have it prest
With more of thine. This love that thou hast shown
Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
Love is a smoke made with the fume of sighs;
Being purg’d, a fire sparkling in lovers’ eyes;
Being vex’d, a sea nourish’d with lovers’ tears:
What is it else? A madness most discreet,
A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.
Farewell, my coz.
nouns: ROMEO love transgression lie breast thou wilt thine love grief smoke fume sigh fire lover eye sea nourish’d lover tear madness gall coz
adjectives: such own heavy pr more more much own purg’d discreet sweet
verbs: propagate show add make sparkle choke preserve

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Tut! I have lost myself; I am not here.
This is not Romeo, he’s some other where.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Bid a sick man in sadness make his will,
A word ill urg’d to one that is so ill.
In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
nouns: ROMEO man sadness will word sadness cousin woman

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
A right good markman, and she’s fair I love.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Well, in that hit you miss: she’ll not be hit
With Cupid’s arrow, she hath Dian’s wit;
And in strong proof of chastity well arm’d,
From love’s weak childish bow she lives uncharm’d.
She will not stay the siege of loving terms
Nor bide th’encounter of assailing eyes,
Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:
O she’s rich in beauty, only poor
That when she dies, with beauty dies her store.
nouns: ROMEO arrow wit proof chastity love bow siege term th’encounter eye lap saint gold beauty beauty store
adjectives: strong weak childish uncharm’d rich poor
verbs: hit miss hit hath live stay love bide assail ope seduce ’ die die

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste;
For beauty starv’d with her severity,
Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
She is too fair, too wise; wisely too fair,
To merit bliss by making me despair.
She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow
Do I live dead, that live to tell it now.
nouns: ROMEO sparing waste beauty starv’d severity beauty posterity merit despair vow
adjectives: huge fair wise fair forsworn dead
verbs: hath make cut bliss make hath love live live tell

title: romeo_juliet
romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
’Tis the way
To call hers, exquisite, in question more.
These happy masks that kiss fair ladies’ brows,
Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair;
He that is strucken blind cannot forget
The precious treasure of his eyesight lost.
Show me a mistress that is passing fair,
What doth her beauty serve but as a note
Where I may read who pass’d that passing fair?
Farewell, thou canst not teach me to forget.
nouns: ROMEO way question mask lady brow mind treasure mistress beauty note
adjectives: exquisite more happy fair black fair blind precious eyesight fair fair canst
verbs: tis call kiss put hide strucken forget lose show pass serve read pass teach forget

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
But Montague is bound as well as I,
In penalty alike; and ’tis not hard, I think,
For men so old as we to keep the peace.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
PARIS.
Of honourable reckoning are you both,
And pity ’tis you liv’d at odds so long.
But now my lord, what say you to my suit?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
But saying o’er what I have said before.
My child is yet a stranger in the world,
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years;
Let two more summers wither in their pride
Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.
nouns: o’er child stranger world change year summer pride bride
verbs: say say hath see let wither think

title: romeo_juliet
text:
PARIS.
Younger than she are happy mothers made.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
And too soon marr’d are those so early made.
The earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she,
She is the hopeful lady of my earth:
But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart,
My will to her consent is but a part;
And she agree, within her scope of choice
Lies my consent and fair according voice.
This night I hold an old accustom’d feast,
Whereto I have invited many a guest,
Such as I love, and you among the store,
One more, most welcome, makes my number more.
At my poor house look to behold this night
Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:
Such comfort as do lusty young men feel
When well apparell’d April on the heel
Of limping winter treads, even such delight
Among fresh female buds shall you this night
Inherit at my house. Hear all, all see,
And like her most whose merit most shall be:
Which, on more view of many, mine, being one,
May stand in number, though in reckoning none.
Come, go with me. Go, sirrah, trudge about
Through fair Verona; find those persons out
Whose names are written there, [_gives a paper_] and to them say,
My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.
nouns: earth hath hope lady earth heart will consent part scope choice consent voice night accustom’d feast guest store number house night earth star light comfort man heel winter tread delight bud night house merit view mine number none trudge verona person name paper house pleasure stay
adjectives: hopeful gentle fair old such more welcome more poor dark such lusty young such fresh female more many fair
verbs: make swallow woo get agree lie accord hold invite love make look behold tread make feel limp hear see stand reckon come go go find write give say welcome

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SERVANT.
Find them out whose names are written here! It is written that the
shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the
fisher with his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am sent to
find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what
names the writing person hath here writ. I must to the learned. In good
time!
nouns: SERVANT name shoemaker yard tailor fisher pencil painter net person name writing person time
verbs: find write write meddle send find find name hath learn

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Tut, man, one fire burns out another’s burning,
One pain is lessen’d by another’s anguish;
Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning;
One desperate grief cures with another’s languish:
Take thou some new infection to thy eye,
And the rank poison of the old will die.
nouns: man fire burning pain anguish holp turning grief cure languish thou infection eye poison
adjectives: lessen’d giddy backward desperate new rank old

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Not mad, but bound more than a madman is:
Shut up in prison, kept without my food,
Whipp’d and tormented and—God-den, good fellow.
nouns: ROMEO madman prison food whipp’d fellow

title: romeo_juliet
text: A fair assembly. [_Gives back the paper_] Whither should they come?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SERVANT.
Now I’ll tell you without asking. My master is the great rich Capulet,
and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a
cup of wine. Rest you merry.
verbs: tell ask be pray come crush rest merry

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s
Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lov’st;
With all the admired beauties of Verona.
Go thither and with unattainted eye,
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
nouns: feast thou beauty thither eye face crow
verbs: sup go compare show make think

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
When the devout religion of mine eye
Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fire;
And these who, often drown’d, could never die,
Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars.
One fairer than my love? The all-seeing sun
Ne’er saw her match since first the world begun.
nouns: ROMEO religion mine eye falsehood tear fire drown’d heretic liar love sun ne’er match world
verbs: maintain turn die burn see see begin

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,
Herself pois’d with herself in either eye:
But in that crystal scales let there be weigh’d
Your lady’s love against some other maid
That I will show you shining at this feast,
And she shall scant show well that now shows best.
nouns: none eye crystal scale lady love maid feast scant
verbs: see pois’d let show shine show show

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown,
But to rejoice in splendour of my own.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old,
I bade her come. What, lamb! What ladybird!
God forbid! Where’s this girl? What, Juliet!

title: romeo_juliet
text:
LADY CAPULET.
This is the matter. Nurse, give leave awhile,
We must talk in secret. Nurse, come back again,
I have remember’d me, thou’s hear our counsel.
Thou knowest my daughter’s of a pretty age.
verbs: give leave talk come remember’d hear

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
Even or odd, of all days in the year,
Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Susan and she,—God rest all Christian souls!—
Were of an age. Well, Susan is with God;
She was too good for me. But as I said,
On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen;
That shall she, marry; I remember it well.
’Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;
And she was wean’d,—I never shall forget it—,
Of all the days of the year, upon that day:
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,
Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall;
My lord and you were then at Mantua:
Nay, I do bear a brain. But as I said,
When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple
Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool,
To see it tetchy, and fall out with the dug!
Shake, quoth the dovehouse: ’twas no need, I trow,
To bid me trudge.
And since that time it is eleven years;
For then she could stand alone; nay, by th’rood
She could have run and waddled all about;
For even the day before she broke her brow,
And then my husband,—God be with his soul!
A was a merry man,—took up the child:
‘Yea,’ quoth he, ‘dost thou fall upon thy face?
Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;
Wilt thou not, Jule?’ and, by my holidame,
The pretty wretch left crying, and said ‘Ay’.
To see now how a jest shall come about.
I warrant, and I should live a thousand years,
I never should forget it. ‘Wilt thou not, Jule?’ quoth he;
And, pretty fool, it stinted, and said ‘Ay.’
nouns: day year night soul age night earthquake year day year day wormwood dug sun dovehouse wall lord brain wormwood nipple dug fool dug quoth dovehouse need trudge time year day brow soul merry child quoth fall face wilt wit thou holidame wretch crying jest year thou fool
adjectives: odd christian good bitter pretty tetchy yea thou more pretty pretty ay
verbs: come rest say marry remember forget lay sit bear say taste feel see fall twa trow bid stand run waddle break be man,—took dost fall hast leave say see come warrant live forget stint say

title: romeo_juliet
text:
LADY CAPULET.
Enough of this; I pray thee hold thy peace.

title: romeo_juliet
nouns: madam crying bump stone knock quoth husband face wilt thou age thou
verbs: choose laugh think leave say warrant brow cry fall’st fall stint say

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace
Thou wast the prettiest babe that e’er I nurs’d:
And I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.
verbs: do mark wast nurs’d live see marry

title: romeo_juliet
text:
LADY CAPULET.
Marry, that marry is the very theme
I came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet,
How stands your disposition to be married?
verbs: marry come talk tell stand marry

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
An honour! Were not I thine only nurse,
I would say thou hadst suck’d wisdom from thy teat.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
LADY CAPULET.
Well, think of marriage now: younger than you,
Here in Verona, ladies of esteem,
Are made already mothers. By my count
I was your mother much upon these years
That you are now a maid. Thus, then, in brief;
The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.
nouns: marriage lady esteem mother count mother year maid brief valiant love

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
A man, young lady! Lady, such a man
As all the world—why he’s a man of wax.
nouns: man lady man world man wax

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
Nay, he’s a flower, in faith a very flower.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
LADY CAPULET.
What say you, can you love the gentleman?
This night you shall behold him at our feast;
Read o’er the volume of young Paris’ face,
And find delight writ there with beauty’s pen.
Examine every married lineament,
And see how one another lends content;
And what obscur’d in this fair volume lies,
Find written in the margent of his eyes.
This precious book of love, this unbound lover,
To beautify him, only lacks a cover:
The fish lives in the sea; and ’tis much pride
For fair without the fair within to hide.
That book in many’s eyes doth share the glory,
That in gold clasps locks in the golden story;
So shall you share all that he doth possess,
By having him, making yourself no less.
nouns: gentleman night feast volume face delight writ beauty pen lineament lend content obscur’d volume margent eye book love unbound lover cover fish sea pride book eye glory clasp lock story possess
adjectives: young married fair precious much fair fair many gold golden
verbs: say love behold read o’er find examine see lie find write beautify lack live tis hide share share doth have make

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
No less, nay bigger. Women grow by men.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
I’ll look to like, if looking liking move:
But no more deep will I endart mine eye
Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.
verbs: look look like endart give make fly

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SERVANT.
Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you called, my young lady
asked for, the Nurse cursed in the pantry, and everything in extremity.
I must hence to wait, I beseech you follow straight.
nouns: SERVANT guest supper lady pantry extremity
verbs: come serve call ask curse wait beseech follow

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
The date is out of such prolixity:
We’ll have no Cupid hoodwink’d with a scarf,
Bearing a Tartar’s painted bow of lath,
Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;
Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke
After the prompter, for our entrance:
But let them measure us by what they will,
We’ll measure them a measure, and be gone.
nouns: date prolixity hoodwink’d scarf bow lath lady crow keeper book prologue prompter entrance measure
verbs: bear paint scare speak let measure measure go

title: romeo_juliet
romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Not I, believe me, you have dancing shoes,
With nimble soles, I have a soul of lead
So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
nouns: ROMEO dancing shoe sol soul lead ground

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
You are a lover, borrow Cupid’s wings,
And soar with them above a common bound.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
I am too sore enpierced with his shaft
To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,
I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.
nouns: ROMEO shaft feather pitch woe love burden

title: romeo_juliet
romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Is love a tender thing? It is too rough,
Too rude, too boisterous; and it pricks like thorn.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
If love be rough with you, be rough with love;
Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.
Give me a case to put my visage in: [_Putting on a mask._]
A visor for a visor. What care I
What curious eye doth quote deformities?
Here are the beetle-brows shall blush for me.
nouns: MERCUTIO love love love love case visage mask visor visor care eye doth deformity beetle brow blush
verbs: be prick beat give put put

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
A torch for me: let wantons, light of heart,
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels;
For I am proverb’d with a grandsire phrase,
I’ll be a candle-holder and look on,
The game was ne’er so fair, and I am done.
nouns: ROMEO torch wanton light heart senseless heel proverb’d grandsire phrase candle holder game ne’er

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
Tut, dun’s the mouse, the constable’s own word:
If thou art dun, we’ll draw thee from the mire
Or save your reverence love, wherein thou stickest
Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho.
nouns: MERCUTIO mouse constable word mire reverence love thou ear daylight

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
I mean sir, in delay
We waste our lights in vain, light lights by day.
Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits
Five times in that ere once in our five wits.
nouns: MERCUTIO delay light light day meaning judgment time wit

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
She is the fairies’ midwife, and she comes
In shape no bigger than an agate-stone
On the fore-finger of an alderman,
Drawn with a team of little atomies
Over men’s noses as they lie asleep:
Her waggon-spokes made of long spinners’ legs;
The cover, of the wings of grasshoppers;
Her traces, of the smallest spider’s web;
The collars, of the moonshine’s watery beams;
Her whip of cricket’s bone; the lash, of film;
Her waggoner, a small grey-coated gnat,
Not half so big as a round little worm
Prick’d from the lazy finger of a maid:
Her chariot is an empty hazelnut,
Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,
Time out o’ mind the fairies’ coachmakers.
And in this state she gallops night by night
Through lovers’ brains, and then they dream of love;
O’er courtiers’ knees, that dream on curtsies straight;
O’er lawyers’ fingers, who straight dream on fees;
O’er ladies’ lips, who straight on kisses dream,
Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,
Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are:
Sometime she gallops o’er a courtier’s nose,
And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;
And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail,
Tickling a parson’s nose as a lies asleep,
Then dreams he of another benefice:
Sometime she driveth o’er a soldier’s neck,
And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,
Of breaches, ambuscados, Spanish blades,
Of healths five fathom deep; and then anon
Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes;
And, being thus frighted, swears a prayer or two,
And sleeps again. This is that very Mab
That plats the manes of horses in the night;
And bakes the elf-locks in foul sluttish hairs,
Which, once untangled, much misfortune bodes:
This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,
That presses them, and learns them first to bear,
Making them women of good carriage:
This is she,—
nouns: MERCUTIO fairy midwife shape agate stone fore finger alderman team atomie man nose waggon spoke spinner leg cover wing grasshopper trace spider web collar moonshine beam whip cricket bone lash film waggoner grey gnat worm prick’d finger maid chariot hazelnut joiner grub o mind fairy coachmaker state night night lover brain love o’er courtier knee dream curtsy o’er lawyer finger dream fee o’er lady lip kiss dream blister plague breath sweetmeat courtier nose suit pig tail parson nose lie benefice soldier neck throat breach ambuscado blade health ear wake prayer mane horse night elf lock hair misfortune bode hag maid back woman carriage
adjectives: big little asleep long small watery small big round little lazy empty old angry asleep foreign spanish deep foul sluttish untangled much good
verbs: see hath come draw lie make coat make gallop dream oft taint gallop o’er dream smell come tickle dream o’er dream cut start fright swear sleep plat bake lie press learn bear make

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
True, I talk of dreams,
Which are the children of an idle brain,
Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,
Which is as thin of substance as the air,
And more inconstant than the wind, who woos
Even now the frozen bosom of the north,
And, being anger’d, puffs away from thence,
Turning his side to the dew-dropping south.
nouns: MERCUTIO dream child brain fantasy substance air wind bosom north anger’d thence side dew south
adjectives: true idle vain thin inconstant frozen

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
I fear too early: for my mind misgives
Some consequence yet hanging in the stars,
Shall bitterly begin his fearful date
With this night’s revels; and expire the term
Of a despised life, clos’d in my breast
By some vile forfeit of untimely death.
But he that hath the steerage of my course
Direct my suit. On, lusty gentlemen!
nouns: ROMEO mind consequence star date night revel term life breast forfeit death steerage course suit gentleman
verbs: fear misgive hang begin expire despise hath direct

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
Where’s Potpan, that he helps not to take away?
He shift a trencher! He scrape a trencher!

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SECOND SERVANT.
When good manners shall lie all in one or two men’s hands, and they
unwash’d too, ’tis a foul thing.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
Away with the join-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the
plate. Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane; and as thou loves me,
let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell. Antony and Potpan!
nouns: SERVANT join stool court cupboard plate thou piece marchpane thou porter
verbs: remove look save love let let

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FIRST SERVANT.
You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the
great chamber.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
SECOND SERVANT.
We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys. Be brisk awhile, and
the longer liver take all.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
Welcome, gentlemen, ladies that have their toes
Unplagu’d with corns will have a bout with you.
Ah my mistresses, which of you all
Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty,
She I’ll swear hath corns. Am I come near ye now?
Welcome, gentlemen! I have seen the day
That I have worn a visor, and could tell
A whispering tale in a fair lady’s ear,
Such as would please; ’tis gone, ’tis gone, ’tis gone,
You are welcome, gentlemen! Come, musicians, play.
A hall, a hall, give room! And foot it, girls.
nouns: gentleman lady toe corn bout mistress dainty hath corn gentleman day visor tale lady ear tis tis tis gentleman musician play hall hall room girl
verbs: deny dance make swear come see wear tell whisper please go go go come give foot

title: romeo_juliet
text:
More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up,
And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.
Ah sirrah, this unlook’d-for sport comes well.
Nay sit, nay sit, good cousin Capulet,
For you and I are past our dancing days;
How long is’t now since last yourself and I
Were in a mask?
nouns: table fire room unlook’d sport cousin dancing day mask
verbs: knave turn quench grow come sit sit

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
What, man, ’tis not so much, ’tis not so much:
’Tis since the nuptial of Lucentio,
Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,
Some five and twenty years; and then we mask’d.

title: romeo_juliet
romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!
It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night
As a rich jewel in an Ethiop’s ear;
Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!
So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows
As yonder lady o’er her fellows shows.
The measure done, I’ll watch her place of stand,
And touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.
Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight!
For I ne’er saw true beauty till this night.
nouns: ROMEO torch cheek night jewel ear use earth dove crow lady fellow measure place stand her hand heart sight beauty night
adjectives: bright rich rich dear snowy rude true
verbs: teach burn seem hang show troop o’er show do watch touch make bless love see

title: romeo_juliet
text:
TYBALT.
This by his voice, should be a Montague.
Fetch me my rapier, boy. What, dares the slave
Come hither, cover’d with an antic face,
To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
Now by the stock and honour of my kin,
To strike him dead I hold it not a sin.
nouns: voice rapier slave hither face solemnity stock honour sin
verbs: fetch dare Come fleer scorn strike hold

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone,
A bears him like a portly gentleman;
And, to say truth, Verona brags of him
To be a virtuous and well-govern’d youth.
I would not for the wealth of all the town
Here in my house do him disparagement.
Therefore be patient, take no note of him,
It is my will; the which if thou respect,
Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,
An ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.
nouns: thee coz gentleman truth govern’d youth wealth town house disparagement note will respect presence frown semblance feast
adjectives: gentle portly virtuous patient thou fair ill
verbs: let bear say brag take show put beseem

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
Go to, go to!
You are a saucy boy. Is’t so, indeed?
This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what.
You must contrary me! Marry, ’tis time.
Well said, my hearts!—You are a princox; go:
Be quiet, or—More light, more light!—For shame!
I’ll make you quiet. What, cheerly, my hearts.
verbs: go go chance scathe know contrary say go make

title: romeo_juliet
text:
TYBALT.
Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.
I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall,
Now seeming sweet, convert to bitter gall.
nouns: patience perforce choler meeting flesh tremble greeting intrusion gall

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
[_To Juliet._] If I profane with my unworthiest hand
This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this,
My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand
To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.
nouns: ROMEO hand shrine sin lip blushing pilgrim touch tender kiss

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,
Which mannerly devotion shows in this;
For saints have hands that pilgrims’ hands do touch,
And palm to palm is holy palmers’ kiss.
nouns: juliet pilgrim hand devotion saint hand hand touch palm palm palmer kiss

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do:
They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
nouns: ROMEO saint lip hand faith despair

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Then move not while my prayer’s effect I take.
Thus from my lips, by thine my sin is purg’d.
[_Kissing her._]
nouns: ROMEO prayer effect lip thine sin

title: romeo_juliet
text:
NURSE.
Marry, bachelor,
Her mother is the lady of the house,
And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous.
I nurs’d her daughter that you talk’d withal.
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her
Shall have the chinks.
nouns: bachelor mother lady house lady daughter talk’d hold chink

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Away, be gone; the sport is at the best.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CAPULET.
Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone,
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.
Is it e’en so? Why then, I thank you all;
I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night.
More torches here! Come on then, let’s to bed.
Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late,
I’ll to my rest.
nouns: gentleman banquet e’en gentleman night torch bed fay rest
verbs: prepare go trifle thank thank come let wax ’ll

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
My only love sprung from my only hate!
Too early seen unknown, and known too late!
Prodigious birth of love it is to me,
That I must love a loathed enemy.
nouns: juliet love hate birth love enemy

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
A rhyme I learn’d even now
Of one I danc’d withal.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
CHORUS.
Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie,
And young affection gapes to be his heir;
That fair for which love groan’d for and would die,
With tender Juliet match’d, is now not fair.
Now Romeo is belov’d, and loves again,
Alike bewitched by the charm of looks;
But to his foe suppos’d he must complain,
And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks:
Being held a foe, he may not have access
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear;
And she as much in love, her means much less
To meet her new beloved anywhere.
But passion lends them power, time means, to meet,
Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
nouns: desire doth lie affection gape heir groan’d match’d belov’d charm look foe suppos’d love bait hook foe access vow lover love passion power time extremity
adjectives: old deathbed young fair tender fair sweet fearful such much less new beloved extreme sweet
verbs: love die love bewitch complain steal hold breathe use swear mean meet lend mean meet temper

title: romeo_juliet
text: SCENE I. An open place adjoining Capulet’s Garden.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Can I go forward when my heart is here?
Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
He is wise,
And on my life hath stol’n him home to bed.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
He ran this way, and leap’d this orchard wall:
Call, good Mercutio.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
Nay, I’ll conjure too.
Romeo! Humours! Madman! Passion! Lover!
Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh,
Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied;
Cry but ‘Ah me!’ Pronounce but Love and dove;
Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,
One nickname for her purblind son and heir,
Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so trim
When King Cophetua lov’d the beggar-maid.
He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not;
The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.
I conjure thee by Rosaline’s bright eyes,
By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,
By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh,
And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,
That in thy likeness thou appear to us.
nouns: MERCUTIO passion thou likeness sigh rhyme gossip word nickname son heir beggar maid ape eye forehead lip foot leg quivering thigh demesne lie
adjectives: satisfied fair purblind dead bright high scarlet fine straight adjacent thy likeness
verbs: conjure appear speak cry dive speak shoot trim heareth stirreth moveth conjure conjure appear

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
This cannot anger him. ’Twould anger him
To raise a spirit in his mistress’ circle,
Of some strange nature, letting it there stand
Till she had laid it, and conjur’d it down;
That were some spite. My invocation
Is fair and honest, and, in his mistress’ name,
I conjure only but to raise up him.
nouns: MERCUTIO spirit mistress circle nature conjur’d spite invocation mistress name
verbs: anger anger raise let stand lay conjure raise

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Come, he hath hid himself among these trees
To be consorted with the humorous night.
Blind is his love, and best befits the dark.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
MERCUTIO.
If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
Now will he sit under a medlar tree,
And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit
As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.
O Romeo, that she were, O that she were
An open-arse and thou a poperin pear!
Romeo, good night. I’ll to my truckle-bed.
This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep.
Come, shall we go?
nouns: MERCUTIO love love mark tree mistress kind fruit maid medlar Romeo arse poperin pear night truckle bed field bed
verbs: be hit sit wish call laugh thou sleep come go

title: romeo_juliet
text:
BENVOLIO.
Go then; for ’tis in vain
To seek him here that means not to be found.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
But soft, what light through yonder window breaks?
It is the east, and Juliet is the sun!
Arise fair sun and kill the envious moon,
Who is already sick and pale with grief,
That thou her maid art far more fair than she.
Be not her maid since she is envious;
Her vestal livery is but sick and green,
And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.
It is my lady, O it is my love!
O, that she knew she were!
She speaks, yet she says nothing. What of that?
Her eye discourses, I will answer it.
I am too bold, ’tis not to me she speaks.
Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,
Having some business, do entreat her eyes
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head?
The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars,
As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven
Would through the airy region stream so bright
That birds would sing and think it were not night.
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
O that I were a glove upon that hand,
That I might touch that cheek.
nouns: light window break east sun sun moon grief thou art livery none fool lady love eye star business eye sphere eye head brightness cheek star daylight doth lamp eye airy region stream bird night cheek hand glove hand cheek
adjectives: soft fair envious sick pale fair envious vestal sick green bold fair bright
verbs: arise kill maid maid wear cast know speak say discourse answer tis speak have entreat twinkle return shame sing think see lean touch

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
She speaks.
O speak again bright angel, for thou art
As glorious to this night, being o’er my head,
As is a winged messenger of heaven
Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
When he bestrides the lazy-puffing clouds
And sails upon the bosom of the air.
nouns: ROMEO angel art night head messenger wondering eye mortal cloud sail bosom air
adjectives: bright thou glorious white upturned lazy
verbs: speak speak o’er wing fall gaze bestride puff

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Deny thy father and refuse thy name.
Or if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,
And I’ll no longer be a Capulet.
nouns: juliet art thou father name love capulet

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
[_Aside._] Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
’Tis but thy name that is my enemy;
Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.
What’s Montague? It is nor hand nor foot,
Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part
Belonging to a man. O be some other name.
What’s in a name? That which we call a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet;
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call’d,
Retain that dear perfection which he owes
Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,
And for thy name, which is no part of thee,
Take all myself.
nouns: name enemy art montague montague hand foot face part man name name rose name Romeo call’d perfection title Romeo doff name name part thee
verbs: ’ arm belong ’ call smell owe take

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
I take thee at thy word.
Call me but love, and I’ll be new baptis’d;
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
By a name
I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,
Because it is an enemy to thee.
Had I it written, I would tear the word.
nouns: ROMEO name name saint enemy word

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words
Of thy tongue’s utterance, yet I know the sound.
Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?
nouns: juliet ear word tongue utterance sound art thou montague

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
How cam’st thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
And the place death, considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
nouns: juliet wall place death art kinsman

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
With love’s light wings did I o’erperch these walls,
For stony limits cannot hold love out,
And what love can do, that dares love attempt:
Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.
nouns: ROMEO love wing wall stony limit love love attempt kinsman stop

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye
Than twenty of their swords. Look thou but sweet,
And I am proof against their enmity.
nouns: ROMEO peril thine eye sword thou proof enmity

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
By love, that first did prompt me to enquire;
He lent me counsel, and I lent him eyes.
I am no pilot; yet wert thou as far
As that vast shore wash’d with the farthest sea,
I should adventure for such merchandise.
nouns: ROMEO love counsel eye pilot thou shore sea merchandise

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face,
Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.
Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny
What I have spoke; but farewell compliment.
Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say Ay,
And I will take thy word. Yet, if thou swear’st,
Thou mayst prove false. At lovers’ perjuries,
They say Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,
If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.
Or if thou thinkest I am too quickly won,
I’ll frown and be perverse, and say thee nay,
So thou wilt woo. But else, not for the world.
In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond;
And therefore thou mayst think my ’haviour light:
But trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove more true
Than those that have more cunning to be strange.
I should have been more strange, I must confess,
But that thou overheard’st, ere I was ’ware,
My true-love passion; therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yielding to light love,
Which the dark night hath so discovered.
nouns: juliet mask night face blush cheek tonight form fain fain compliment thou word mayst lover perjury thou love thinkest world truth mayst haviour light gentleman love passion love night hath
adjectives: know maiden dost false gentle perverse wilt fair fond true cunning strange strange ware true light dark
verbs: bepaint hear speak dwell deny speak love know say take prove say laugh dost pronounce win frown say think trust prove confess pardon impute yield discover

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
O swear not by the moon, th’inconstant moon,
That monthly changes in her circled orb,
Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.
nouns: juliet swear moon moon change orb love

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Do not swear at all.
Or if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,
Which is the god of my idolatry,
And I’ll believe thee.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Well, do not swear. Although I joy in thee,
I have no joy of this contract tonight;
It is too rash, too unadvis’d, too sudden,
Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
Ere one can say “It lightens.” Sweet, good night.
This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath,
May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest
Come to thy heart as that within my breast.
nouns: juliet joy contract tonight lightning doth night bud love summer breath flower night night repose rest heart breast
adjectives: rash sudden sweet good beauteous good good sweet
verbs: swear joy cease say lighten ripen prove meet come

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?

title: romeo_juliet
romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
But to be frank and give it thee again.
And yet I wish but for the thing I have;
My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
My love as deep; the more I give to thee,
The more I have, for both are infinite.
I hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu.
[_Nurse calls within._]
Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague be true.
Stay but a little, I will come again.
nouns: juliet thee thing bounty sea love noise love
adjectives: frank boundless deep infinite dear adieu good true little
verbs: give wish give hear call stay come

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
O blessed, blessed night. I am afeard,
Being in night, all this is but a dream,
Too flattering sweet to be substantial.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
If that thy bent of love be honourable,
Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow,
By one that I’ll procure to come to thee,
Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite,
And all my fortunes at thy foot I’ll lay
And follow thee my lord throughout the world.
nouns: word night bent love purpose marriage word tomorrow procure time wilt fortune foot world

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
I come, anon.— But if thou meanest not well,
I do beseech thee,—

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
A thousand times the worse, to want thy light.
Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books,
But love from love, towards school with heavy looks.
nouns: ROMEO time light love schoolboy book love love school look

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Hist! Romeo, hist! O for a falconer’s voice
To lure this tassel-gentle back again.
Bondage is hoarse and may not speak aloud,
Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,
And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine
With repetition of my Romeo’s name.
nouns: Romeo hist falconer voice tassel cave airy tongue repetition name

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
It is my soul that calls upon my name.
How silver-sweet sound lovers’ tongues by night,
Like softest music to attending ears.
nouns: ROMEO soul name lover tongue night music ear

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
’Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone,
And yet no farther than a wanton’s bird,
That lets it hop a little from her hand,
Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,
And with a silk thread plucks it back again,
So loving-jealous of his liberty.
nouns: morning wanton bird hand prisoner gyve silk thread liberty

title: romeo_juliet
text:
JULIET.
Sweet, so would I:
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
Good night, good night. Parting is such sweet sorrow
That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
nouns: i cherishing night night parting sorrow night morrow
adjectives: much good good such sweet good

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.
Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.
Hence will I to my ghostly Sire’s cell,
His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.
nouns: ROMEO dwell thine eye peace breast sleep peace rest cell help hap

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FRIAR LAWRENCE.
The grey-ey’d morn smiles on the frowning night,
Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light;
And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels
From forth day’s pathway, made by Titan’s fiery wheels
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,
The day to cheer, and night’s dank dew to dry,
I must upfill this osier cage of ours
With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.
The earth that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb;
What is her burying grave, that is her womb:
And from her womb children of divers kind
We sucking on her natural bosom find.
Many for many virtues excellent,
None but for some, and yet all different.
O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies
In plants, herbs, stones, and their true qualities.
For naught so vile that on the earth doth live
But to the earth some special good doth give;
Nor aught so good but, strain’d from that fair use,
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.
Virtue itself turns vice being misapplied,
And vice sometime’s by action dignified.
nouns: morn smile night cloud streak light darkness drunkard reel day pathway wheel sun eye day night dew cage weed flower earth nature mother tomb burying grave womb womb child diver bosom find virtue none mickle grace plant herb stone quality naught earth doth earth doth give aught use birth abuse vice vice sometime ’s action
adjectives: grey frowning eastern fiery dank osi baleful precious natural many many excellent different powerful true vile special good good strain’d fair true dignified
verbs: chequer fleckle make advance burn cheer dry upfill juice ’ kind suck lie live stumble turn misapply

title: romeo_juliet
text:
Within the infant rind of this weak flower
Poison hath residence, and medicine power:
For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;
Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart.
Two such opposed kings encamp them still
In man as well as herbs,—grace and rude will;
And where the worser is predominant,
Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
nouns: infant rind flower residence medicine power part part sense heart king man worser canker death plant
adjectives: weak such opposed rude predominant full
verbs: hath smell cheer taste slay encamp eat

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FRIAR LAWRENCE.
Benedicite!
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Young son, it argues a distemper’d head
So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.
Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye,
And where care lodges sleep will never lie;
But where unbruised youth with unstuff’d brain
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure
Thou art uprous’d with some distemperature;
Or if not so, then here I hit it right,
Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
nouns: tongue saluteth son distemper’d head morrow bed watch man eye care lodge sleep youth limb sleep doth reign earliness art distemperature bed tonight
adjectives: early sweet good old unbruised golden
verbs: argue bid keep lie couch doth assure hit hath

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FRIAR LAWRENCE.
God pardon sin. Wast thou with Rosaline?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
With Rosaline, my ghostly father? No.
I have forgot that name, and that name’s woe.

title: romeo_juliet
text:
FRIAR LAWRENCE.
That’s my good son. But where hast thou been then?

title: romeo_juliet
text:
ROMEO.
I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.
I have been feasting with mine enemy,
Where on a sudden one hath wounded me
That’s by me wounded. Both our remedies
Within thy help and holy physic lies.
I bear no hatred, blessed man; for lo,
My intercession likewise steads my foe.
