What will you do with’t, that you have been so earnest
To have me filch it?

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give ’t me again. Poor lady, she’ll run mad
When she shall lack it.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Be not acknown on’t, I have use for it.
Go, leave me.

title: othello
text:
I will in Cassio’s lodging lose this napkin,
And let him find it. Trifles light as air
Are to the jealous confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ. This may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison:
Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons,
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste,
But with a little act upon the blood
Burn like the mines of sulphur. I did say so.
nouns: lodging napkin trifle light air confirmation proof poison conceit nature poison act blood mine sulphur
adjectives: jealous strong dangerous first scarce little
verbs: lose let find change find distaste burn say

title: othello
text:
Look, where he comes. Not poppy, nor mandragora,
Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world,
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep
Which thou ow’dst yesterday.
nouns: drowsy syrup world thee sleep thou yesterday

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Avaunt! be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack.
I swear ’tis better to be much abus’d
Than but to know’t a little.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
What sense had I of her stol’n hours of lust?
I saw’t not, thought it not, it harm’d not me.
I slept the next night well, was free and merry;
I found not Cassio’s kisses on her lips.
He that is robb’d, not wanting what is stol’n,
Let him not know’t, and he’s not robb’d at all.
nouns: sense stol’n hour lust night kiss lip robb’d stol’n robb’d

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I had been happy if the general camp,
Pioners and all, had tasted her sweet body,
So I had nothing known. O, now, for ever
Farewell the tranquil mind! Farewell content!
Farewell the plumed troops and the big wars
That make ambition virtue! O, farewell,
Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump,
The spirit-stirring drum, the ear-piercing fife,
The royal banner, and all quality,
Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war!
And, O you mortal engines, whose rude throats
The immortal Jove’s dread clamours counterfeit,
Farewell! Othello’s occupation’s gone!
nouns: camp pioner body tranquil mind farewell content troop war ambition virtue neighing trump spirit drum ear fife banner quality pomp circumstance war engine throat dread occupation
adjectives: happy general sweet big shrill royal glorious mortal rude immortal counterfeit
verbs: taste know plume make stee stir pierce clamour go

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore;
Be sure of it. Give me the ocular proof,
Or, by the worth of man’s eternal soul,
Thou hadst been better have been born a dog
Than answer my wak’d wrath.
nouns: thou love whore proof worth man soul dog wrath

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Make me to see’t, or at the least so prove it,
That the probation bear no hinge nor loop
To hang a doubt on, or woe upon thy life!
nouns: probation hinge loop doubt woe life

title: othello
nouns: thou remorse horror head horror deed earth amaz’d thou damnation
verbs: dost slander torture pray abandon accumulate make weep add

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
O grace! O heaven defend me!
Are you a man? Have you a soul or sense?
God be wi’ you. Take mine office.—O wretched fool,
That liv’st to make thine honesty a vice!
O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,
To be direct and honest is not safe.
I thank you for this profit, and from hence
I’ll love no friend, sith love breeds such offence.
nouns: grace man soul sense mine fool liv’st thine honesty vice world note note world profit friend sith love offence
adjectives: wi office.—o wretched monstrous direct honest safe such
verbs: defend take make take take thank love breed

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Nay, stay. Thou shouldst be honest.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
I should be wise; for honesty’s a fool,
And loses that it works for.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
By the world,
I think my wife be honest, and think she is not.
I think that thou art just, and think thou art not.
I’ll have some proof: her name, that was as fresh
As Dian’s visage, is now begrim’d and black
As mine own face. If there be cords or knives,
Poison or fire, or suffocating streams,
I’ll not endure ’t. Would I were satisfied!
nouns: world wife art art proof name visage begrim’d face cord knife fire stream
adjectives: honest thou thou fresh black own satisfied
verbs: think think think think be suffocate endure

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion.
I do repent me that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
And may; but how? How satisfied, my lord?
Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on,
Behold her topp’d?

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
It were a tedious difficulty, I think,
To bring them to that prospect. Damn them then,
If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster
More than their own! What then? How then?
What shall I say? Where’s satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this,
Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys,
As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross
As ignorance made drunk. But yet I say,
If imputation and strong circumstances,
Which lead directly to the door of truth,
Will give you satisfaction, you may have’t.
nouns: difficulty prospect eye satisfaction goat monkey salt wolf pride fool ignorance imputation circumstance door truth satisfaction
adjectives: tedious mortal More own impossible prime hot gross drunk strong
verbs: think bring damn see bolster say ’s see make say lead give

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Give me a living reason she’s disloyal.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
I do not like the office,
But sith I am enter’d in this cause so far,
Prick’d to ’t by foolish honesty and love,
I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately,
And being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not sleep.
There are a kind of men so loose of soul,
That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs.
One of this kind is Cassio:
In sleep I heard him say, “Sweet Desdemona,
Let us be wary, let us hide our loves;”
And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand,
Cry “O sweet creature!” and then kiss me hard,
As if he pluck’d up kisses by the roots,
That grew upon my lips, then laid his leg
Over my thigh, and sigh’d and kiss’d, and then
Cried “Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!”
nouns: office enter’d cause prick’d t honesty love tooth kind man soul sleep affair kind sleep love hand creature kiss root lip leg thigh sigh’d fate
verbs: like go lie trouble rage sleep mutter hear say let let hide gripe wre kiss pluck’d grow lay kiss’d cry give

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
But this denoted a foregone conclusion.
’Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
And this may help to thicken other proofs
That do demonstrate thinly.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Nay, but be wise. Yet we see nothing done,
She may be honest yet. Tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief
Spotted with strawberries in your wife’s hand?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I gave her such a one, ’twas my first gift.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
I know not that: but such a handkerchief
(I am sure it was your wife’s) did I today
See Cassio wipe his beard with.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
If it be that, or any that was hers,
It speaks against her with the other proofs.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
O, that the slave had forty thousand lives!
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge!
Now do I see ’tis true. Look here, Iago;
All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.
’Tis gone.
Arise, black vengeance, from thy hollow hell!
Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne
To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
For ’tis of aspics’ tongues!
nouns: slave life revenge tis love vengeance hell love crown throne hate bosom tis aspic tongue
adjectives: poor weak true fond black hollow thy hearted tyrannous fraught
verbs: see look blow ti go yield

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Never, Iago. Like to the Pontic Sea,
Whose icy current and compulsive course
Ne’er feels retiring ebb, but keeps due on
To the Propontic and the Hellespont;
Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace
Shall ne’er look back, ne’er ebb to humble love,
Till that a capable and wide revenge
Swallow them up. Now by yond marble heaven,
In the due reverence of a sacred vow [_Kneels._]
I here engage my words.
nouns: course ne’er ebb thought pace ne’er ne’er ebb love revenge marble reverence vow word
adjectives: icy current compulsive bloody violent humble capable wide due sacred
verbs: feel retire keep look swallow engage

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Do not rise yet. [_Kneels._]
Witness, you ever-burning lights above,
You elements that clip us round about,
Witness that here Iago doth give up
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wrong’d Othello’s service! Let him command,
And to obey shall be in me remorse,
What bloody business ever.
nouns: light element doth execution wit hand heart service remorse business
verbs: rise burn clip witness give wrong’d let command obey

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I greet thy love,
Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to ’t.
Within these three days let me hear thee say
That Cassio’s not alive.
nouns: love thank acceptance instant put day

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
My friend is dead. ’Tis done at your request.
But let her live.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her, damn her!
Come, go with me apart, I will withdraw
To furnish me with some swift means of death
For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.
nouns: minx mean death devil art thou lieutenant

title: othello
text:
CLOWN.
I know not where he lodges; and for me to devise a lodging, and say he
lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.
verbs: know lodge devise say lie lie lie

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Seek him, bid him come hither. Tell him I have moved my lord on his
behalf, and hope all will be well.
verbs: seek bid come tell move hope

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse
Full of crusadoes. And but my noble Moor
Is true of mind and made of no such baseness
As jealous creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill thinking.
nouns: purse crusado mind baseness creature thinking
adjectives: full noble true such jealous enough ill

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Who, he? I think the sun where he was born
Drew all such humours from him.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart.
Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires
A sequester from liberty, fasting and prayer,
Much castigation, exercise devout;
For here’s a young and sweating devil here
That commonly rebels. ’Tis a good hand,
A frank one.
nouns: heart moist hand your sequester liberty fasting prayer castigation exercise devil rebel hand
adjectives: fruitfulness liberal hot hot much young good frank

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
A liberal hand. The hearts of old gave hands,
But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.
nouns: hand heart hand heraldry hand heart

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me.
Lend me thy handkerchief.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
That is a fault. That handkerchief
Did an Egyptian to my mother give.
She was a charmer, and could almost read
The thoughts of people. She told her, while she kept it,
’Twould make her amiable and subdue my father
Entirely to her love. But if she lost it,
Or made a gift of it, my father’s eye
Should hold her loathed, and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies: she, dying, gave it me,
And bid me, when my fate would have me wive,
To give it her. I did so; and take heed on’t,
Make it a darling like your precious eye.
To lose’t or give’t away were such perdition
As nothing else could match.
nouns: fault handkerchief mother charmer thought people father love gift father eye spirit fancy dying fate darling eye perdition
verbs: give read tell keep make subdue lose make hold loathe hunt give bid give take make lose’t give’t match

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
’Tis true. There’s magic in the web of it.
A sibyl, that had number’d in the world
The sun to course two hundred compasses,
In her prophetic fury sew’d the work;
The worms were hallow’d that did breed the silk,
And it was dyed in mummy, which the skillful
Conserv’d of maiden’s hearts.
nouns: magic web sibyl number’d world sun compass fury work worm silk conserv’d maiden heart

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Most veritable, therefore look to ’t well.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Come, come.
You’ll never meet a more sufficient man.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
A man that all his time
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
Shar’d dangers with you,—

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
I ne’er saw this before.
Sure there’s some wonder in this handkerchief,
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
’Tis not a year or two shows us a man:
They are all but stomachs and we all but food;
They eat us hungerly, and when they are full,
They belch us.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
There is no other way; ’tis she must do ’t,
And, lo, the happiness! Go and importune her.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
How now, good Cassio, what’s the news with you?

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love,
Whom I, with all the office of my heart,
Entirely honour. I would not be delay’d.
If my offence be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purpos’d merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so must be my benefit;
So shall I clothe me in a forc’d content,
And shut myself up in some other course
To fortune’s alms.
nouns: suit mean member love office heart offence be kind service past sorrow merit futurity love benefit content course alm
adjectives: former virtuous honour delay’d such mortal present forc’d other
verbs: beseech exist purpos’d ransom know clothe shut

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio,
My advocation is not now in tune;
My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him
Were he in favour as in humour alter’d.
So help me every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you all my best,
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech! You must awhile be patient.
What I can do I will; and more I will
Than for myself I dare. Let that suffice you.
nouns: thrice advocation tune lord favour humour spirit blank displeasure speech
verbs: know help sanctify speak stand dare let suffice

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
He went hence but now,
And certainly in strange unquietness.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon,
When it hath blown his ranks into the air
And, like the devil, from his very arm
Puff’d his own brother, and can he be angry?
Something of moment then. I will go meet him.
There’s matter in’t indeed if he be angry.
nouns: cannon rank air devil arm brother moment matter
verbs: see hath blow go meet ’ be

title: othello
text:
Something sure of state,
Either from Venice, or some unhatch’d practice
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit, and in such cases
Men’s natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. ’Tis even so.
For let our finger ache, and it indues
Our other healthful members even to that sense
Of pain. Nay, we must think men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observancy
As fits the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia,
I was (unhandsome warrior as I am)
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
But now I find I had suborn’d the witness,
And he’s indicted falsely.
nouns: state practice spirit case man nature thing one object finger member sense pain man god observancy bridal warrior soul witness
adjectives: sure unhatch’d demonstrable clear such inferior great other healthful such much unhandsome unkindness
verbs: make puddle wrangle tis let indue think look fit arraign find ’s indict

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Pray heaven it be state matters, as you think,
And no conception nor no jealous toy
Concerning you.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
But jealous souls will not be answer’d so;
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous for they are jealous: ’tis a monster
Begot upon itself, born on itself.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
I will go seek him. Cassio, walk hereabout:
If I do find him fit, I’ll move your suit,
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.
verbs: go seek walk find move seek effect

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
What make you from home?
How is it with you, my most fair Bianca?
I’ faith, sweet love, I was coming to your house.

title: othello
text:
BIANCA.
And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
What, keep a week away? Seven days and nights?
Eight score eight hours, and lovers’ absent hours,
More tedious than the dial eight score times?
O weary reckoning!
nouns: lodging week day night score hour lover hour dial score time reckoning

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
Pardon me, Bianca.
I have this while with leaden thoughts been press’d,
But I shall in a more continuate time
Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca,

title: othello
text:
BIANCA.
O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend.
To the felt absence now I feel a cause.
Is’t come to this? Well, well.

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
Go to, woman!
Throw your vile guesses in the devil’s teeth,
From whence you have them. You are jealous now
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance.
No, in good troth, Bianca.
nouns: woman guess devil tooth whence mistress remembrance

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
I know not neither. I found it in my chamber.
I like the work well. Ere it be demanded,
As like enough it will, I’d have it copied.
Take it, and do ’t, and leave me for this time.
verbs: know find like demand copy take leave

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
I do attend here on the general,
And think it no addition, nor my wish,
To have him see me woman’d.

title: othello
text:
BIANCA.
But that you do not love me.
I pray you bring me on the way a little,
And say if I shall see you soon at night.

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
’Tis but a little way that I can bring you,
For I attend here. But I’ll see you soon.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Or to be naked with her friend in bed
An hour or more, not meaning any harm?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm?
It is hypocrisy against the devil:
They that mean virtuously and yet do so,
The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.
nouns: bed harm hypocrisy devil devil virtue tempt

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
So they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip.
But if I give my wife a handkerchief—

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Her honour is an essence that’s not seen;
They have it very oft that have it not:
But for the handkerchief—

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
Thou said’st (O, it comes o’er my memory,
As doth the raven o’er the infected house,
Boding to all) he had my handkerchief.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
What
If I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say (as knaves be such abroad,
Who having, by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab.)
verbs: say see hear say be have supply choose blab

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Lie with her! lie on her!—We say lie on her when they belie her.—Lie
with her! that’s fulsome. Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief! To
confess, and be hanged for his labour. First, to be hanged, and then to
confess. I tremble at it. Nature would not invest herself in such
shadowing passion without some instruction. It is not words that shake
me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips. Is’t
possible?—Confess?—handkerchief?—O devil!—
nouns: lie her.—Lie handkerchief confession handkerchief labour nature passion instruction word nose ear lip possible?—confess?—handkerchief?—o devil
verbs: lie say lie belie ’ confess hang hang confess tremble invest shadow shake

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Work on,
My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught,
And many worthy and chaste dames even thus,
All guiltless, meet reproach. What, ho! my lord!
My lord, I say! Othello!
nouns: medicine work fool dame guiltless reproach lord

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
My lord is fallen into an epilepsy.
This is his second fit. He had one yesterday.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
No, forbear;
The lethargy must have his quiet course.
If not, he foams at mouth, and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight. When he is gone,
I would on great occasion speak with you.
nouns: no forbear lethargy course mouth madness while occasion
verbs: foam savage look stir withdraw recover go speak

title: othello
text: How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Dost thou mock me?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
A horned man’s a monster and a beast.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
There’s many a beast, then, in a populous city,
And many a civil monster.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Good sir, be a man.
Think every bearded fellow that’s but yok’d
May draw with you. There’s millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar: your case is better.
O, ’tis the spite of hell, the fiend’s arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure couch,
And to suppose her chaste! No, let me know,
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
nouns: sir man fellow million lie unproper bed case spite hell fiend mock wanton couch chaste
adjectives: bearded alive peculiar well arch secure
verbs: think ’ draw ’ dare swear tis lip suppose let know know know

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
O, thou art wise, ’tis certain.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Stand you awhile apart,
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o’erwhelmed with your grief,
(A passion most unsuiting such a man)
Cassio came hither. I shifted him away,
And laid good ’scuse upon your ecstasy,
Bade him anon return, and here speak with me,
The which he promis’d. Do but encave yourself,
And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns,
That dwell in every region of his face;
For I will make him tell the tale anew,
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife:
I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience,
Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen,
And nothing of a man.
nouns: patient list grief passion man scuse ecstasy return fleer gibe scorn dwell region face tale wife gesture patience spleen man
verbs: stand confine o’erwhelme unsuite come shift lay speak promis’d encave mark make tell hath cope say mark say

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Dost thou hear, Iago?
I will be found most cunning in my patience;
But,—dost thou hear?—most bloody.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
That’s not amiss.
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?

title: othello
text:
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A housewife that by selling her desires
Buys herself bread and clothes: it is a creature
That dotes on Cassio, (as ’tis the strumpet’s plague
To beguile many and be beguil’d by one.)
He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes.
nouns: housewife desire bread clothe creature strumpet plague excess laughter
verbs: question sell buy dote tis beguile hear refrain come

title: othello
text:
As he shall smile Othello shall go mad,
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and light behaviour
Quite in the wrong. How do you now, lieutenant?

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on’t.
[_Speaking lower._] Now, if this suit lay in Bianca’s power,
How quickly should you speed!

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
Alas, poor rogue! I think, i’ faith, she loves me.

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
I marry her? What? A customer? I prithee, bear some charity to my wit,
do not think it so unwholesome. Ha, ha, ha!

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
This is the monkey’s own giving out. She is persuaded I will marry her,
out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
She was here even now. She haunts me in every place. I was the other
day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes
the bauble, and falls thus about my neck.

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
’Tis such another fitchew! Marry, a perfum’d one.
What do you mean by this haunting of me?

title: othello
text:
BIANCA.
Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you mean by that same
handkerchief you gave me even now? I was a fine fool to take it. I must
take out the work? A likely piece of work, that you should find it in
your chamber and not know who left it there! This is some minx’s token,
and I must take out the work? There, give it your hobby-horse.
Wheresoever you had it, I’ll take out no work on’t.
nouns: devil dam handkerchief fool work piece work chamber minx work hobby horse work on’t
verbs: let haunt mean give take take find know leave take give take

title: othello
text:
BIANCA.
If you’ll come to supper tonight, you may. If you will not, come when
you are next prepared for.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Yours, by this hand: and to see how he prizes the foolish woman your
wife! she gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Ay, let her rot, and perish, and be damned tonight, for she shall not
live. No, my heart is turned to stone; I strike it, and it hurts my
hand. O, the world hath not a sweeter creature. She might lie by an
emperor’s side, and command him tasks.
nouns: perish tonight heart stone hand world creature emperor side task
verbs: let rot damn live turn strike hurt hath lie command

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Hang her, I do but say what she is. So delicate with her needle, an
admirable musician! O, she will sing the savageness out of a bear! Of
so high and plenteous wit and invention!
nouns: needle musician savageness bear wit invention

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Nay, that’s certain. But yet the pity of it, Iago! O Iago, the pity of
it, Iago!

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if
it touch not you, it comes near nobody.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Good, good. The justice of it pleases. Very good.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker. You shall hear more by
midnight.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Something from Venice, sure. ’Tis Lodovico
Come from the duke. See, your wife is with him.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Save you, worthy general!

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
And what’s the news, good cousin Lodovico?

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
He did not call; he’s busy in the paper.
Is there division ’twixt my lord and Cassio?

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
A most unhappy one. I would do much
To atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Trust me, I am glad on’t.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Truly, an obedient lady.
I do beseech your lordship, call her back.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.
Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,
And turn again. And she can weep, sir, weep;
And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient,
Very obedient. Proceed you in your tears.
Concerning this, sir,—O well-painted passion!
I am commanded home.—Get you away;
I’ll send for you anon.—Sir, I obey the mandate,
And will return to Venice.—Hence, avaunt!
nouns: turn sir tear sir,—o passion home.—get mandate venice.—hence
verbs: wish make turn turn go turn weep weep ’ say proceed concern paint command send obey return

title: othello
text:
Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight,
I do entreat that we may sup together.
You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus. Goats and monkeys!

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Is this the noble Moor, whom our full senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature
Whom passion could not shake? whose solid virtue
The shot of accident nor dart of chance
Could neither graze nor pierce?
nouns: nature passion virtue shot accident dart chance

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Faith, that was not so well; yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst!

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood,
And new-create this fault?

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Alas, alas!
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so
That I may save my speech: do but go after,
And mark how he continues.
verbs: speak see know observe denote save go mark continue

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest,
Lay down my soul at stake: if you think other,
Remove your thought, it doth abuse your bosom.
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let heaven requite it with the serpent’s curse,
For if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There’s no man happy. The purest of their wives
Is foul as slander.
nouns: EMILIA soul stake thought bosom wretch head serpent curse man wife
adjectives: honest other honest chaste true happy pure foul slander
verbs: durst wager think remove abuse put let requite be ’

title: othello
text:
She says enough. Yet she’s a simple bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtle whore,
A closet lock and key of villainous secrets.
And yet she’ll kneel and pray. I have seen her do ’t.
nouns: bawd whore closet lock key secret

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
What horrible fancy’s this?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Come, swear it, damn thyself,
Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves
Should fear to seize thee. Therefore be double-damn’d.
Swear thou art honest.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Alas the heavy day, why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me. If you have lost him,
Why, I have lost him too.
nouns: day motive tear father instrument blame

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Had it pleas’d heaven
To try me with affliction, had they rain’d
All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head,
Steep’d me in poverty to the very lips,
Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my soul
A drop of patience. But, alas, to make me
A fixed figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow unmoving finger at.
Yet could I bear that too, well, very well:
But there, where I have garner’d up my heart,
Where either I must live or bear no life,
The fountain from the which my current runs,
Or else dries up, to be discarded thence,
Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads
To knot and gender in!—turn thy complexion there,
Patience, thou young and rose-lipp’d cherubin,
Ay, there, look grim as hell!
nouns: affliction kind sore shame head poverty lip hope place soul drop patience figure time scorn unmoving finger garner’d heart life fountain run thence cistern toad gender complexion thou rose cherubin hell
adjectives: bare very utmost slow current foul young grim
verbs: pleas’d try rain’d steep’d give captivity find make fix point bear live bear dry discard keep knot look

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
O, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed,
Who art so lovely fair, and smell’st so sweet,
That the sense aches at thee,
Would thou hadst ne’er been born!
nouns: summer fly shamble thou weed sense thou ne’er

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write “whore” upon? What committed?
Committed! O thou public commoner!
I should make very forges of my cheeks,
That would to cinders burn up modesty,
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed!
Heaven stops the nose at it, and the moon winks;
The bawdy wind, that kisses all it meets,
Is hush’d within the hollow mine of earth,
And will not hear it. What committed!
Impudent strumpet!
nouns: paper book whore thou commoner forge cheek cinder deed nose moon wink wind hush’d mine earth strumpet
adjectives: fair public very modesty bawdy hollow
verbs: make write commit commit make burn speak commit stop kiss meet hear commit

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
No, as I am a Christian:
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I cry you mercy then.
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice
That married with Othello.—You, mistress,

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
How do you, madam? How do you, my good lady?

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Good madam, what’s the matter with my lord?

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
’Tis meet I should be us’d so, very meet.
How have I been behav’d, that he might stick
The small’st opinion on my least misuse?

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
I cannot tell. Those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
He might have chid me so, for, in good faith,
I am a child to chiding.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhor’d her,
Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her,
As true hearts cannot bear.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
He call’d her whore: a beggar in his drink
Could not have laid such terms upon his callet.
nouns: EMILIA whore beggar drink term callet

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
I do not know. I am sure I am none such.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Hath she forsook so many noble matches,
Her father, and her country, and her friends,
To be call’d whore? would it not make one weep?
nouns: EMILIA match father country friend call’d whore weep

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
I will be hang’d, if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devis’d this slander. I’ll be hang’d else.
nouns: EMILIA villain rogue slave office devis’d slander

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
A halter pardon him, and hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company?
What place? what time? what form? what likelihood?
The Moor’s abused by some most villainous knave,
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
O heaven, that such companions thou’dst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to the west!
nouns: EMILIA halter hell bone whore company place time form likelihood knave base knave scurvy fellow companion unfold hand whip rascal world east west
verbs: pardon gnaw call keep abuse thou’dst put lash

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
O, fie upon them! Some such squire he was
That turn’d your wit the seamy side without,
And made you to suspect me with the Moor.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Alas, Iago,
What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him. For by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel.
If e’er my will did trespass ’gainst his love,
Either in discourse of thought or actual deed,
Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense,
Delighted them in any other form,
Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
And ever will, (though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement) love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much;
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my love. I cannot say “whore,”
It does abhor me now I speak the word;
To do the act that might the addition earn
Not the world’s mass of vanity could make me.
nouns: lord friend light love discourse thought deed eye mine ear sense form divorcement unkindness life love whore word act addition world mass vanity
verbs: win go know lose kneel e’er trespass delight shake love forswear defeat taint say abhor speak earn make

title: othello
text:
Hark, how these instruments summon to supper.
The messengers of Venice stay the meat.
Go in, and weep not. All things shall be well.

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
Every day thou daffest me with some device, Iago, and rather, as it
seems to me now, keepest from me all conveniency than suppliest me with
the least advantage of hope. I will indeed no longer endure it. Nor am
I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly
suffered.
nouns: day thou device conveniency advantage hope peace
verbs: daffest seem endure persuade put suffer

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
Faith, I have heard too much, for your words and performances are no
kin together.

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
With naught but truth. I have wasted myself out of my means. The jewels
you have had from me to deliver to Desdemona would half have corrupted
a votarist: you have told me she hath received them, and returned me
expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance, but I
find none.
nouns: naught truth mean jewel votarist expectation comfort respect acquaintance none
verbs: waste deliver corrupt tell hath receive return find

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
Very well, go to, I cannot go to, man, nor ’tis not very well. Nay, I
say ’tis very scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it.
verbs: go go tis say tis begin find foppe

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
I tell you ’tis not very well. I will make myself known to Desdemona.
If she will return me my jewels, I will give over my suit and repent my
unlawful solicitation. If not, assure yourself I will seek satisfaction
of you.
verbs: tell tis make return give repent assure seek

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Why, now I see there’s mettle in thee, and even from this instant do
build on thee a better opinion than ever before. Give me thy hand,
Roderigo. Thou hast taken against me a most just exception, but yet I
protest, I have dealt most directly in thy affair.
nouns: mettle thee instant opinion hand hast exception affair
verbs: see ’ build give take protest deal

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is not without
wit and judgement. But, Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed,
which I have greater reason to believe now than ever,—I mean purpose,
courage, and valour,—this night show it. If thou the next night
following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery
and devise engines for my life.
nouns: suspicion wit judgement reason purpose courage night night world treachery engine life
verbs: grant hath appear hast believe show follow enjoy take devise

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in
Othello’s place.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
O, no; he goes into Mauritania, and takes away with him the fair
Desdemona, unless his abode be lingered here by some accident: wherein
none can be so determinate as the removing of Cassio.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Why, by making him uncapable of Othello’s place: knocking out his
brains.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. He sups tonight with
a harlotry, and thither will I go to him. He knows not yet of his
honourable fortune. If you will watch his going thence, which I will
fashion to fall out between twelve and one, you may take him at your
pleasure: I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall
between us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with me. I will
show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself
bound to put it on him. It is now high supper-time, and the night grows
to waste. About it.
nouns: profit right tonight harlotry thither fortune thence fashion pleasure attempt necessity death supper time night
verbs: dare sup go know watch go fall take second fall come stand go show think bind put grow waste

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
I will hear further reason for this.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Madam, good night. I humbly thank your ladyship.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
How goes it now? He looks gentler than he did.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
It was his bidding. Therefore, good Emilia,
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
We must not now displease him.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
So would not I. My love doth so approve him,
That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns,—
Prithee, unpin me,—have grace and favour in them.
nouns: love doth stubbornness check frown grace favour

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
All’s one. Good faith, how foolish are our minds!
If I do die before thee, prithee, shroud me
In one of those same sheets.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
My mother had a maid call’d Barbary,
She was in love, and he she lov’d prov’d mad
And did forsake her. She had a song of “willow”,
An old thing ’twas, but it express’d her fortune,
And she died singing it. That song tonight
Will not go from my mind. I have much to do
But to go hang my head all at one side
And sing it like poor Barbary. Prithee dispatch.
nouns: mother maid call’d love song willow thing fortune song tonight mind head side dispatch
verbs: prov’d forsake twa express’d die singe go go hang sing

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
No, unpin me here.
This Lodovico is a proper man.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
[_Singing._]
    _The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
        Sing all a green willow.
    Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
        Sing willow, willow, willow.
    The fresh streams ran by her, and murmur’d her moans,
        Sing willow, willow, willow;
    Her salt tears fell from her, and soften’d the stones;—_
nouns: singing soul sycamore tree willow hand bosom head knee willow willow willow stream murmur’d moan willow willow willow salt tear stone
verbs: sit sigh sing sing run sing fall soften’d

title: othello
text:
[_Sings._]
    _Sing all a green willow must be my garland.
Let nobody blame him, his scorn I approve,—_

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
[_Sings._]
    _I call’d my love false love; but what said he then?
        Sing willow, willow, willow:
    If I court mo women, you’ll couch with mo men._
nouns: sing love love willow willow mo woman couch mo man

title: othello
text:
So get thee gone; good night. Mine eyes do itch;
Doth that bode weeping?

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think,—tell me, Emilia,—
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?
nouns: man man thou conscience woman husband kind

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
The world’s a huge thing. It is a great price
For a small vice.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
In troth, I think I should, and undo’t when I had done. Marry, I would
not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for
gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition; but, for the
whole world—why, who would not make her husband a cuckold to make him a
monarch? I should venture purgatory for ’t.
nouns: EMILIA troth undo’t thing ring measure lawn gown petticoat cap exhibition world husband cuckold monarch purgatory

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Why, the wrong is but a wrong i’ the world; and having the world for
your labour, ’tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make
it right.
nouns: EMILIA wrong world world labour wrong world

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
I do not think there is any such woman.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Yes, a dozen; and as many to the vantage as would store the world they
played for.
But I do think it is their husbands’ faults
If wives do fall: say that they slack their duties,
And pour our treasures into foreign laps;
Or else break out in peevish jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us. Or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite.
Why, we have galls; and though we have some grace,
Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know
Their wives have sense like them: they see, and smell
And have their palates both for sweet and sour,
As husbands have. What is it that they do
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is. And doth affection breed it?
I think it doth. Is’t frailty that thus errs?
It is so too. And have not we affections,
Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Then let them use us well: else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
nouns: EMILIA dozen vantage world husband fault wife duty treasure lap jealousy restraint gall grace revenge husband wife sense palate husband other doth affection affection desire sport man ill ill
adjectives: many foreign peevish former sweet sour sport
verbs: store play think fall say slack pour break throw say strike scant have let know see smell change think breed think doth err let use let know instruct

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Good night, good night. Heaven me such usage send,
Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend!
adjectives: good good such bad bad bad

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Here, stand behind this bulk. Straight will he come.
Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home.
Quick, quick, fear nothing; I’ll be at thy elbow.
It makes us, or it mars us, think on that,
And fix most firm thy resolution.
verbs: stand come wear put fear make mar think fix

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Here, at thy hand. Be bold, and take thy stand.

title: othello
text: [_Retires to a little distance._]

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
I have no great devotion to the deed;
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
’Tis but a man gone. Forth, my sword; he dies.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
I have rubb’d this young quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain. Live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobb’d from him,
As gifts to Desdemona.
It must not be. If Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly. And besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril.
No, he must die. But so, I hear him coming.
nouns: rubb’d quat sense way gain restitution gold jewel gift beauty life peril
adjectives: young angry other large daily ugly much
verbs: grow kill kill make call bobb’d remain hath make unfold stand die hear come

title: othello
text:
RODERIGO.
I know his gait; ’tis he. Villain, thou diest!

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
That thrust had been mine enemy indeed,
But that my coat is better than thou know’st.
I will make proof of thine.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
’Tis he. O brave Iago, honest and just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend’s wrong!
Thou teachest me,—minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unbless’d fate hies. Strumpet, I come!
Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blotted;
Thy bed, lust-stain’d, shall with lust’s blood be spotted.
nouns: sense friend me,—minion fate hie heart charm thine eye bed lust stain’d lust blood
adjectives: brave honest such noble wrong teach dear dead
verbs: tis hast lie come blot spot

title: othello
text:
GRATIANO.
’Tis some mischance; the cry is very direful.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Two or three groan. It is a heavy night.
These may be counterfeits. Let’s think’t unsafe
To come in to the cry without more help.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
O treacherous villains!
[_To Lodovico and Gratiano._] What are you there?
Come in and give some help.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Kill men i’ the dark! Where be these bloody thieves?
How silent is this town! Ho! murder! murder!
What may you be? Are you of good or evil?
nouns: man dark thief town murder murder good evil

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
O notable strumpet! Cassio, may you suspect
Who they should be that have thus mangled you?

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash
To be a party in this injury.
Patience awhile, good Cassio. Come, come;
Lend me a light. Know we this face or no?
Alas, my friend and my dear countryman
Roderigo? No. Yes, sure; O heaven! Roderigo.
nouns: gentleman trash party injury light face no friend countryman heaven

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Signior Gratiano? I cry you gentle pardon.
These bloody accidents must excuse my manners,
That so neglected you.

title: othello
text:
O, that’s well said; the chair.
Some good man bear him carefully from hence,
I’ll fetch the general’s surgeon. [_To Bianca_] For you, mistress,
Save you your labour. He that lies slain here, Cassio,
Was my dear friend. What malice was between you?
nouns: chair man general surgeon mistress labour friend malice

title: othello
text:
Stay you, good gentlemen.—Look you pale, mistress?
Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?
Nay, if you stare, we shall hear more anon.
Behold her well. I pray you, look upon her.
Do you see, gentlemen? Nay, guiltiness will speak
Though tongues were out of use.
nouns: mistress gastness eye anon gentleman guiltiness tongue use
verbs: stay pale perceive stare hear behold pray look see speak

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Cassio hath here been set on in the dark
By Roderigo, and fellows that are ’scap’d.
He’s almost slain, and Roderigo dead.

title: othello
text:
BIANCA.
I am no strumpet, but of life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.

title: othello
text:
IAGO.
Kind gentlemen, let’s go see poor Cassio dress’d.
Come, mistress, you must tell’s another tale.
Emilia, run you to the citadel,
And tell my lord and lady what hath happ’d.
Will you go on afore? [_Aside._] This is the night
That either makes me or fordoes me quite.
nouns: gentleman dress’d mistress tale citadel lord night
verbs: let go see come tell run tell lady hath go make fordoe

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul,
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars!
It is the cause. Yet I’ll not shed her blood,
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow,
And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Yet she must die, else she’ll betray more men.
Put out the light, and then put out the light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again thy former light restore,
Should I repent me. But once put out thy light,
Thou cunning’st pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that Promethean heat
That can thy light relume. When I have pluck’d thy rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again,
It must needs wither. I’ll smell it on the tree.
nouns: cause cause soul star cause blood scar whiter skin snow alabaster man light light minister restore light pattern nature heat relume pluck’d growth tree
adjectives: smooth monumental more former light promethean light vital
verbs: let name chaste shed die betray put put quench flame repent put excel know rise give need smell

title: othello
text:
O, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her sword! One more, one more.
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And love thee after. One more, and this the last.
So sweet was ne’er so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel tears. This sorrow’s heavenly,
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.
nouns: breath sword ne’er tear sorrow love wake
adjectives: more thou dead last sweet fatal cruel
verbs: dost persuade break art kill love weep ’ strike doth

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Well, do it, and be brief, I will walk by.
I would not kill thy unprepared spirit,
No, heaven forfend! I would not kill thy soul.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
And yet I fear you, for you are fatal then
When your eyes roll so: why I should fear I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not, but yet I feel I fear.
verbs: fear roll fear know know feel fear

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
That death’s unnatural that kills for loving.
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame.
These are portents; but yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point on me.
nouns: death ala nether lip passion frame portent
verbs: kill love gnaw shake hope hope point

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Yes, presently:
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin.
For to deny each article with oath
Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.
nouns: sin article oath conception groan withal art

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
And have you mercy too! I never did
Offend you in my life,	 never lov’d Cassio
But with such general warranty of heaven
As I might love. I never gave him token.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
No, his mouth is stopp’d.
Honest Iago hath ta’en order for ’t.

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
O, my fear interprets! What, is he dead?

title: othello
text:
DESDEMONA.
Alas, he is betray’d, and I undone!

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
[_Within._] O, good my lord, I would speak a word with you!

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Yes. ’Tis Emilia, by and by. She’s dead.
’Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio’s death;
The noise was high.—Ha! no more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? Were’t good?
I think she stirs again; no. What’s best to do?
If she come in, she’ll sure speak to my wife.
My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife.
O, insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon, and that the affrighted globe
Should yawn at alteration.
nouns: death noise grave were’t wife wife wife wife wife hour methink eclipse sun moon globe alteration
adjectives: dead good good insupportable heavy huge affrighted
verbs: ’ tis come speak move come think stir ’ come speak yawn

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
O, my good lord, yonder’s foul murders done!

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
It is the very error of the moon,
She comes more nearer earth than she was wont
And makes men mad.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Not Cassio kill’d! Then murder’s out of tune,
And sweet revenge grows harsh.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Out, and alas! That was my lady’s voice.
Help! help, ho! help! O lady, speak again,
Sweet Desdemona! O sweet mistress, speak!
nouns: EMILIA lady voice help lady mistress

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Thou art rash as fire, to say
That she was false: O, she was heavenly true!

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
That she was false to wedlock?

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Ay, with Cassio. Nay, had she been true,
If heaven would make me such another world
Of one entire and perfect chrysolite,
I’d not have sold her for it.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Ay, ’twas he that told me first.
An honest man he is, and hates the slime
That sticks on filthy deeds.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
O mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love!
My husband say that she was false?
nouns: EMILIA mistress hath mock love husband

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
He, woman;
I say thy husband: dost understand the word?
My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.
nouns: woman husband dost word friend husband

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
If he say so, may his pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day! he lies to the heart.
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.
nouns: EMILIA soul grain day heart bargain

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Thou hast not half that power to do me harm
As I have to be hurt. O gull! O dolt!
As ignorant as dirt! Thou hast done a deed
(I care not for thy sword) I’ll make thee known,
Though I lost twenty lives. Help! help, ho! help!
The Moor hath kill’d my mistress! Murder, murder!
nouns: EMILIA hast power gull dolt dirt hast deed sword life help hath kill’d mistress murder murder
verbs: harm hurt do care make know lose

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Disprove this villain, if thou be’st a man.
He says thou told’st him that his wife was false.
I know thou didst not, thou’rt not such a villain.
Speak, for my heart is full.
nouns: EMILIA villain man thou wife villain heart
verbs: disprove be’st say told’st know didst speak

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
But did you ever tell him she was false?

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
You told a lie, an odious, damned lie;
Upon my soul, a lie; a wicked lie.
She false with Cassio? Did you say with Cassio?
nouns: EMILIA lie lie soul lie lie

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Nay, stare not, masters, it is true indeed.

title: othello
text:
GRATIANO.
’Tis a strange truth.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Villany, villany, villany!
I think upon’t, I think I smell’t; O villany!
I thought so then. I’ll kill myself for grief.
O villany, villany!
nouns: EMILIA villany villany villany grief villany villany

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak.
’Tis proper I obey him, but not now.
Perchance, Iago, I will ne’er go home.
verbs: let leave speak ti obey go

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
Nay, lay thee down and roar;
For thou hast kill’d the sweetest innocent
That e’er did lift up eye.

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
[_Rising._] O, she was foul!
I scarce did know you, uncle, there lies your niece,
Whose breath indeed these hands have newly stopp’d.
I know this act shows horrible and grim.

title: othello
text:
GRATIANO.
Poor Desdemona! I am glad thy father’s dead.
Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief
Shore his old thread in twain: did he live now,
This sight would make him do a desperate turn,
Yea, curse his better angel from his side,
And fall to reprobance.
nouns: match grief thread twain sight turn yea angel side reprobance
adjectives: glad dead mortal pure old desperate well

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
’Tis pitiful. But yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed; Cassio confess’d it,
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her; I saw it in his hand.
It was a handkerchief, an antique token
My father gave my mother.
nouns: act shame time work recognizance pledge love hand handkerchief father mother
verbs: ti know hath commit confess’d gratify give see token give

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
’Twill out, ’twill out. I peace?
No, I will speak as liberal as the north.
Let heaven and men and devils, let them all,
All, all, cry shame against me, yet I’ll speak.
verbs: twill twill peace speak let let cry speak

title: othello
text: [_Iago offers to stab his wife._]

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
O thou dull Moor, that handkerchief thou speak’st of
I found by fortune and did give my husband;
For often with a solemn earnestness,
More than indeed belong’d to such a trifle,
He begg’d of me to steal it.
nouns: EMILIA thou handkerchief thou fortune husband earnestness trifle

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO
Are there not stones in heaven
But what serve for thunder? Precious villain!

title: othello
text:
MONTANO.
’Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon,
Which I have here recover’d from the Moor.
Come, guard the door without, let him not pass,
But kill him rather. I’ll after that same villain,
For ’tis a damned slave.
nouns: villain weapon recover’d door villain tis slave
verbs: tis take come guard let pass kill

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I am not valiant neither,
But every puny whipster gets my sword.
But why should honour outlive honesty?
Let it go all.

title: othello
text:
EMILIA.
What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan,
And die in music.
[_Sings._] _Willow, willow, willow._
Moor, she was chaste. She lov’d thee, cruel Moor,
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true;
So speaking as I think, I die, I die.
nouns: EMILIA song lady swan music sing willow willow willow thee soul
verbs: hear play die come bliss speak speak think die die

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Behold, I have a weapon.
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier’s thigh: I have seen the day
That with this little arm and this good sword
I have made my way through more impediments
Than twenty times your stop. But, O vain boast!
Who can control his fate? ’Tis not so now.
Be not afraid, though you do see me weapon’d.
Here is my journey’s end, here is my butt,
And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Do you go back dismay’d? ’Tis a lost fear.
Man but a rush against Othello’s breast,
And he retires. Where should Othello go?
Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starr’d wench,
Pale as thy smock, when we shall meet at compt,
This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven,
And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl!
Even like thy chastity.
O cursed, cursed slave! Whip me, ye devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Blow me about in winds, roast me in sulphur,
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!
O Desdemon! Dead, Desdemon! dead! Oh, oh!
nouns: weapon soldier thigh day arm sword way impediment time stop vain boast fate weapon’d journey end butt sea mark sail dismay’d fear man rush breast look starr’d wench smock compt look thine soul fiend girl chastity slave ye devil possession sight wind sulphur gulfs fire
adjectives: little good more afraid utmost dost thou ill cold cold heavenly steep liquid dead
verbs: sustain see make control tis see go ti lose retire go meet hurl snatch curse curse whip blow roast wash

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
I am not sorry neither. I’d have thee live,
For in my sense ’tis happiness to die.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
O thou Othello, that wert once so good,
Fall’n in the practice of a damned slave,
What shall be said to thee?

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
Dear general, I never gave you cause.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
Now here’s another discontented paper,
Found in his pocket too; and this, it seems,
Roderigo meant to have sent this damned villain,
But that, belike, Iago in the interim
Came in and satisfied him.
verbs: ’ discontent find seem mean send come satisfy

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
O the pernicious caitiff!
How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief
That was my wife’s?

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
I found it in my chamber.
And he himself confess’d but even now,
That there he dropp’d it for a special purpose
Which wrought to his desire.

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
There is besides in Roderigo’s letter,
How he upbraids Iago, that he made him
Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came
That I was cast. And even but now he spake,
After long seeming dead, Iago hurt him,
Iago set him on.
verbs: upbraid make brave come cast spake seem hurt set

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
You must forsake this room, and go with us.
Your power and your command is taken off,
And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty
That can torment him much and hold him long,
It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest,
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian state. Come, bring away.
nouns: room power command rule slave cruelty prisoner rest nature fault state
verbs: forsake go take be torment hold close know come bring

title: othello
text:
OTHELLO.
Soft you; a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service, and they know’t.
No more of that. I pray you, in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of me as I am. Nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak
Of one that loved not wisely, but too well;
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought,
Perplex’d in the extreme; of one whose hand,
Like the base Judean, threw a pearl away
Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdu’d eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees
Their medicinal gum. Set you down this.
And say besides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant and a turban’d Turk
Beat a Venetian and traduc’d the state,
I took by the throat the circumcised dog,
And smote him, thus.
nouns: word state service letter deed aught malice one extreme hand pearl tribe subdu’d eye melting mood tear tree gum malignant turban’d traduc’d state throat dog
adjectives: soft more unlucky jealous base unused arabian medicinal
verbs: go do know’t pray relate speak extenuate set speak love work throw set say beat take circumcise smote

title: othello
text:
CASSIO.
This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon,
For he was great of heart.

title: othello
text:
LODOVICO.
[_To Iago._] O Spartan dog,
More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea,
Look on the tragic loading of this bed.
This is thy work. The object poisons sight,
Let it be hid. Gratiano, keep the house,
And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor,
For they succeed on you. To you, lord governor,
Remains the censure of this hellish villain.
The time, the place, the torture, O, enforce it!
Myself will straight aboard, and to the state
This heavy act with heavy heart relate.
nouns: dog anguish hunger sea loading bed work object poison sight house fortune governor censure villain time place torture state act heart relate
verbs: fall look let hide keep seize succeed remain enforce

title: coriolanus
text: *** START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE TRAGEDY OF CORIOLANUS ***

title: coriolanus
text:
Enter a company of mutinous Citizens, with staves, clubs, and other
weapons.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
First, you know Caius Martius is chief enemy to the people.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
Let us kill him, and we’ll have corn at our own price. Is’t a verdict?

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. What authority
surfeits on would relieve us. If they would yield us but the
superfluity while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us
humanely. But they think we are too dear. The leanness that afflicts
us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularize their
abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them. Let us revenge this with
our pikes ere we become rakes; for the gods know I speak this in hunger
for bread, not in thirst for revenge.
nouns: citizen patrician authority surfeit superfluity leanness object misery inventory abundance sufferance gain pike god hunger bread thirst revenge
verbs: account relieve yield guess relieve think afflict particularize let revenge become rake know speak

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
Against him first. He’s a very dog to the commonalty.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
Very well, and could be content to give him good report for’t, but that
he pays himself with being proud.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
I say unto you, what he hath done famously he did it to that end.
Though soft-conscienced men can be content to say it was for his
country, he did it to please his mother and to be partly proud, which
he is, even to the altitude of his virtue.
nouns: end man country mother altitude virtue
verbs: say hath do conscience say please

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND CITIZEN.
What he cannot help in his nature you account a vice in him. You must
in no way say he is covetous.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations. He hath faults,
with surplus, to tire in repetition. [_Shouts within_.] What shouts are
these? The other side o’ th’ city is risen. Why stay we prating here?
To th’ Capitol!
nouns: barren accusation fault surplus repetition side o th city
verbs: need hath tire shout shout rise stay prate th

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
He’s one honest enough. Would all the rest were so!

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
Our business is not unknown to th’ Senate. They have had inkling this
fortnight what we intend to do, which now we’ll show ’em in deeds. They
say poor suitors have strong breaths; they shall know we have strong
arms too.
verbs: th inkle intend show say know

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,
Will you undo yourselves?

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I tell you, friends, most charitable care
Have the patricians of you. For your wants,
Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against the Roman state, whose course will on
The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack,
You are transported by calamity
Thither where more attends you, and you slander
The helms o’ th’ state, who care for you like fathers,
When you curse them as enemies.
nouns: friend care patrician want suffering dearth stave state course way curb link impediment dearth god patrician knee arm calamity helm state father enemy
verbs: tell lift take crack appear make help transport attend slander care curse

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
Care for us? True, indeed! They ne’er cared for us yet. Suffer us to
famish, and their storehouses crammed with grain; make edicts for usury
to support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act established against
the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily to chain up and
restrain the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and there’s
all the love they bear us.
nouns: ne’er storehouse grain edict usury usurer act statute war love
verbs: care suffer famish cram make support repeal establish provide pierce chain restrain eat ’ bear

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Either you must confess yourselves wondrous malicious
Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you
A pretty tale. It may be you have heard it,
But since it serves my purpose, I will venture
To stale’t a little more.
verbs: confess accuse tell hear serve venture stale’t

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
There was a time when all the body’s members
Rebelled against the belly, thus accused it:
That only like a gulf it did remain
I’ th’ midst o’ th’ body, idle and unactive,
Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing
Like labour with the rest, where th’ other instruments
Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
And, mutually participate, did minister
Unto the appetite and affection common
Of the whole body. The belly answered—
nouns: time body member belly gulf th th body viand labour rest instrument instruct minister appetite affection body belly
adjectives: idle unactive other devise common whole
verbs: rebel accuse remain cupboarde bear see hear walk feel participate answer

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,
Which ne’er came from the lungs, but even thus—
For, look you, I may make the belly smile
As well as speak—it tauntingly replied
To th’ discontented members, the mutinous parts
That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you malign our senators for that
They are not such as you.
nouns: kind smile ne’er lung belly member part receipt senator
verbs: tell come look make smile speak reply th discontent envy malign

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
Your belly’s answer—what?
The kingly crowned head, the vigilant eye,
The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier,
Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter,
With other muniments and petty helps
Is this our fabric, if that they—
nouns: belly answer head eye counsellor heart arm soldier leg tongue trumpeter muniment help fabric

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
The former agents, if they did complain,
What could the belly answer?

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I will tell you,
If you’ll bestow a small—of what you have little—
Patience awhile, you’st hear the belly’s answer.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Note me this, good friend;
Your most grave belly was deliberate,
Not rash like his accusers, and thus answered:
“True is it, my incorporate friends,” quoth he,
“That I receive the general food at first
Which you do live upon; and fit it is,
Because I am the storehouse and the shop
Of the whole body. But, if you do remember,
I send it through the rivers of your blood
Even to the court, the heart, to th’ seat o’ th’ brain;
And, through the cranks and offices of man,
The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
From me receive that natural competency
Whereby they live. And though that all at once,
You, my good friends”—this says the belly, mark me—
nouns: friend belly accuser friend quoth food storehouse shop body river blood court heart seat th brain crank office man nerve vein competency belly
adjectives: good grave deliberate rash true incorporate general first whole strong small inferior natural good
verbs: note answer receive live fit remember send th receive live say mark

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
The senators of Rome are this good belly,
And you the mutinous members. For examine
Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly
Touching the weal o’ th’ common, you shall find
No public benefit which you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you
And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
You, the great toe of this assembly?
nouns: senator belly member examine counsel care thing weal th benefit way yourself toe assembly
verbs: digest touch find receive proceed come think

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
For that, being one o’ th’ lowest, basest, poorest,
Of this most wise rebellion, thou goest foremost.
Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run,
Lead’st first to win some vantage.
But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs.
Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;
The one side must have bale.
nouns: o th rebellion rascal art blood vantage bat club rat point battle side bale

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Thanks.—What’s the matter, you dissentious rogues,
That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,
Make yourselves scabs?
nouns: martiu matter rogue itch opinion scab

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
He that will give good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs,
That like nor peace nor war? The one affrights you;
The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you,
Where he should find you lions, finds you hares;
Where foxes, geese. You are no surer, no,
Than is the coal of fire upon the ice
Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
To make him worthy whose offence subdues him,
And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
A sick man’s appetite, who desires most that
Which would increase his evil. He that depends
Upon your favours swims with fins of lead,
And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust ye?
With every minute you do change a mind
And call him noble that was now your hate,
Him vile that was your garland. What’s the matter,
That in these several places of the city
You cry against the noble senate, who,
Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else
Would feed on one another?—What’s their seeking?
nouns: martiu word abhorring peace war one lion hare fox surer coal fire ice hailstone sun virtue offence justice greatness hate affection man appetite evil favour swims fin lead oak rush ye trust ye minute mind hate vile garland matter place city god seeking
adjectives: good other proud geese worthy sick noble several noble
verbs: give flatter cur like affright make trust find find make subdue curse deserve deserve desire increase depend hew hang change call ’ cry keep feed ’s

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
For corn at their own rates, whereof they say
The city is well stored.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Hang ’em! They say?
They’ll sit by th’ fire and presume to know
What’s done i’ th’ Capitol, who’s like to rise,
Who thrives and who declines; side factions and give out
Conjectural marriages, making parties strong
And feebling such as stand not in their liking
Below their cobbled shoes. They say there’s grain enough?
Would the nobility lay aside their ruth
And let me use my sword, I’d make a quarry
With thousands of these quartered slaves as high
As I could pick my lance.
nouns: martiu th fire i side faction marriage party shoe grain nobility ruth sword quarry thousand slave lance
verbs: hang say sit presume know ’ do ’ rise thrive decline give make feeble stand like cobble say ’ lay let use make quarter pick

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded;
For though abundantly they lack discretion,
Yet are they passing cowardly. But I beseech you,
What says the other troop?

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
They are dissolved. Hang ’em!
They said they were an-hungry, sighed forth proverbs
That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,
That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not
Corn for the rich men only. With these shreds
They vented their complainings, which being answered
And a petition granted them—a strange one,
To break the heart of generosity
And make bold power look pale—they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the horns o’ th’ moon,
Shouting their emulation.
nouns: martiu proverb hunger stone wall dog meat mouth god man shred complaining petition one heart generosity power cap horn th moon emulation
adjectives: hungry rich strange bold pale o
verbs: dissolve hang say sigh break eat make send vent answer grant break make look throw hang shout

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms,
Of their own choice. One’s Junius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I know not. ’Sdeath!
The rabble should have first unroofed the city
Ere so prevailed with me. It will in time
Win upon power and throw forth greater themes
For insurrection’s arguing.
nouns: martiu tribune wisdom choice rabble city time power theme insurrection arguing

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
I am glad on’t. Then we shall ha’ means to vent
Our musty superfluity.

title: coriolanus
text:
Enter Sicinius Velutus, Junius Brutus, two Tribunes; Cominius, Titus
Lartius with other Senators.

title: coriolanus
text: See, our best elders.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Martius, ’tis true that you have lately told us:
The Volsces are in arms.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Were half to half the world by th’ ears and he
Upon my party, I’d revolt, to make
Only my wars with him. He is a lion
That I am proud to hunt.
nouns: martiu half world th ear party war lion

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Sir, it is,
And I am constant.—Titus Lartius, thou
Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus’ face.
What, art thou stiff? Stand’st out?

title: coriolanus
text:
TITUS LARTIUS.
No, Caius Martius,
I’ll lean upon one crutch and fight with th’ other
Ere stay behind this business.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Your company to th’ Capitol, where I know
Our greatest friends attend us.

title: coriolanus
text:
TITUS LARTIUS.
Lead you on.
Follow Cominius. We must follow you;
Right worthy your priority.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Nay, let them follow.
The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither
To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutineers,
Your valour puts well forth. Pray follow.
nouns: corn rat thither garner mutineer valour follow
verbs: let follow take gnaw put pray

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
The present wars devour him! He is grown
Too proud to be so valiant.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Such a nature,
