Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
Which he treads on at noon. But I do wonder
His insolence can brook to be commanded
Under Cominius.
nouns: sicinius nature success shadow noon insolence
verbs: tickle disdain tread wonder brook command

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Fame, at the which he aims,
In whom already he’s well graced, cannot
Better be held nor more attained than by
A place below the first; for what miscarries
Shall be the General’s fault, though he perform
To th’ utmost of a man, and giddy censure
Will then cry out of Martius “O, if he
Had borne the business!”
nouns: place miscarrie fault utmost man censure business
verbs: aim ’ hold attain perform th cry bear

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Besides, if things go well,
Opinion that so sticks on Martius shall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Come.
Half all Cominius’ honours are to Martius,
Though Martius earned them not, and all his faults
To Martius shall be honours, though indeed
In aught he merit not.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Let’s hence and hear
How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,
More than in singularity, he goes
Upon this present action.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
So, your opinion is, Aufidius,
That they of Rome are entered in our counsels
And know how we proceed.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Is it not yours?
What ever have been thought on in this state
That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome
Had circumvention? ’Tis not four days gone
Since I heard thence. These are the words—I think
I have the letter here. Yes, here it is.
[_Reads_.] _They have pressed a power, but it is not known
Whether for east or west. The dearth is great.
The people mutinous; and, it is rumoured,
Cominius, Martius your old enemy,
Who is of Rome worse hated than of you,—
And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman,
These three lead on this preparation
Whither ’tis bent. Most likely ’tis for you.
Consider of it._
nouns: aufidiu your state circumvention day thence word letter power east west dearth people enemy lead preparation whither tis bent
verbs: think bring act tis go hear think read press know rumour hate tis consider

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Our army’s in the field.
We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To answer us.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Nor did you think it folly
To keep your great pretences veiled till when
They needs must show themselves, which, in the hatching,
It seemed, appeared to Rome. By the discovery
We shall be shortened in our aim, which was
To take in many towns ere almost Rome
Should know we were afoot.
nouns: aufidiu pretence hatching discovery aim town
verbs: think keep veil need show seem appear shorten take know

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SENATOR.
Noble Aufidius,
Take your commission; hie you to your bands.
Let us alone to guard Corioles.
If they set down before’s, for the remove
Bring up your army. But I think you’ll find
They’ve not prepared for us.
verbs: take hie let guard set bring think find ’ve prepare

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
O, doubt not that;
I speak from certainties. Nay, more,
Some parcels of their power are forth already,
And only hitherward. I leave your Honours.
If we and Caius Martius chance to meet,
’Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike
Till one can do no more.
nouns: aufidiu certainty parcel power hitherward chance
verbs: doubt speak leave meet swear strike

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
And keep your Honours safe!

title: coriolanus
text:
Enter Volumnia and Virgilia, mother and wife to Martius. They set them
down on two low stools and sew.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a more comfortable
sort. If my son were my husband, I should freelier rejoice in that
absence wherein he won honour than in the embracements of his bed where
he would show most love. When yet he was but tender-bodied and the only
son of my womb, when youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way,
when for a day of kings’ entreaties a mother should not sell him an
hour from her beholding, I, considering how honour would become such a
person—that it was no better than picture-like to hang by th’ wall, if
renown made it not stir—was pleased to let him seek danger where he was
like to find fame. To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he returned,
his brows bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not more in
joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had
proved himself a man.
nouns: daughter sort son husband absence honour embracement bed love tender son womb youth comeliness way day king mother hour beholding honour person picture like th wall danger fame war whence brow oak daughter joy hearing man child man
adjectives: comfortable most bodied only well renown pleased like cruel
verbs: pray sing express rejoice win show pluck gaze entreatie sell consider become hang make stir let seek find send return bind tell spring see prove

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Then his good report should have been my son; I therein would have
found issue. Hear me profess sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my
love alike and none less dear than thine and my good Martius, I had
rather had eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously
surfeit out of action.
nouns: report son issue dozen son love none thine country surfeit action

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Indeed you shall not.
Methinks I hear hither your husband’s drum,
See him pluck Aufidius down by th’ hair;
As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him.
Methinks I see him stamp thus and call thus:
“Come on, you cowards! You were got in fear,
Though you were born in Rome.” His bloody brow
With his mailed hand then wiping, forth he goes
Like to a harvestman that’s tasked to mow
Or all or lose his hire.
nouns: methink husband drum th hair child bear methink coward fear brow hand harvestman hire
verbs: hear see pluck shun see stamp call come get bear mail wipe go ’ task mow lose

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Away, you fool! It more becomes a man
Than gilt his trophy. The breasts of Hecuba,
When she did suckle Hector, looked not lovelier
Than Hector’s forehead when it spit forth blood
At Grecian sword, contemning.—Tell Valeria
We are fit to bid her welcome.
nouns: VOLUMNIA man trophy breast forehead blood sword welcome
verbs: fool become gild suckle look spit bid

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
I am glad to see your Ladyship.

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
I thank your Ladyship; well, good madam.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
O’ my word, the father’s son! I’ll swear ’tis a very pretty boy. O’ my
troth, I looked upon him o’ Wednesday half an hour together. H’as such
a confirmed countenance. I saw him run after a gilded butterfly, and
when he caught it, he let it go again, and after it again, and over and
over he comes, and up again, catched it again. Or whether his fall
enraged him or how ’twas, he did so set his teeth and tear it. O, I
warrant how he mammocked it!
nouns: o word father son tis boy troth o hour countenance butterfly fall tooth
verbs: swear look confirm see run catch let go come catch enrage twa set tear warrant mammocke

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
Indeed, la, ’tis a noble child.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
Come, lay aside your stitchery. I must have you play the idle huswife
with me this afternoon.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably. Come, you must go visit
the good lady that lies in.

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
I will wish her speedy strength and visit her with my prayers, but I
cannot go thither.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
You would be another Penelope. Yet they say all the yarn she spun in
Ulysses’ absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths. Come, I would your
cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave pricking it
for pity. Come, you shall go with us.
nouns: yarn absence moth cambric finger pity
verbs: say spin fill come leave prick come go

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
In truth, la, go with me, and I’ll tell you excellent news of your
husband.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
Verily, I do not jest with you. There came news from him last night.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
In earnest, it’s true. I heard a senator speak it. Thus it is: the
Volsces have an army forth, against whom Cominius the General is gone
with one part of our Roman power. Your lord and Titus Lartius are set
down before their city Corioles. They nothing doubt prevailing, and to
make it brief wars. This is true, on mine honour, and so, I pray, go
with us.
nouns: senator army part power lord city war honour
adjectives: earnest true roman brief true mine
verbs: ’ hear speak go set doubt prevail make pray go

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
Give me excuse, good madam. I will obey you in everything hereafter.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Let her alone, lady. As she is now, she will but disease our better
mirth.

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
In troth, I think she would.—Fare you well, then.—Come, good sweet
lady.—Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy solemness out o’ door, and go along
with us.

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
No, at a word, madam. Indeed I must not. I wish you much mirth.

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
So the good horse is mine.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Then shall we hear their ’larum, and they ours.
Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work,
That we with smoking swords may march from hence
To help our fielded friends!—Come, blow thy blast.
nouns: martiu larum prithee work smoking sword blast
verbs: hear our make march help field blow

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
No, nor a man that fears you less than he:
That’s lesser than a little.
[_Drum afar off_.]
Hark, our drums
Are bringing forth our youth. We’ll break our walls
Rather than they shall pound us up. Our gates,
Which yet seem shut, we have but pinned with rushes.
They’ll open of themselves.
[_Alarum far off_.]
Hark you, far off!
There is Aufidius. List what work he makes
Amongst your cloven army.
nouns: man drum youth wall gate rush list work army
adjectives: first less less little open cloven
verbs: fear ’ drum bring break pound seem shut pin make

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
They fear us not but issue forth their city.—
Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight
With hearts more proof than shields.—Advance, brave Titus.
They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,
Which makes me sweat with wrath.—Come on, my fellows!
He that retires, I’ll take him for a Volsce,
And he shall feel mine edge.
nouns: martiu city shield heart heart proof thought fellow edge
verbs: fear issue put fight disdain make sweat retire take feel

title: coriolanus
text: Enter Martius cursing, with Roman soldiers.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
All the contagion of the south light on you,
You shames of Rome! You herd of—Boils and plagues
Plaster you o’er, that you may be abhorred
Farther than seen, and one infect another
Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese,
That bear the shapes of men, how have you run
From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
All hurt behind. Backs red, and faces pale
With flight and agued fear! Mend, and charge home,
Or, by the fires of heaven, I’ll leave the foe
And make my wars on you. Look to’t. Come on!
If you’ll stand fast we’ll beat them to their wives,
As they us to our trenches. Follow’s!
nouns: martiu contagion light shame herd boil plague wind mile soul geese shape man slave ape back flight fear home fire foe war to’t wife trench
verbs: o’er abhor see infect bear run beat hurt face ague mend charge leave make look come stand beat

title: coriolanus
text:
So, now the gates are ope. Now prove good seconds!
’Tis for the followers fortune widens them,
Not for the fliers. Mark me, and do the like.
nouns: gate ope second follower fortune flier

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SOLDIER.
Following the fliers at the very heels,
With them he enters, who upon the sudden
Clapped to their gates. He is himself alone,
To answer all the city.

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
O noble fellow,
Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,
And when it bows, stand’st up! Thou art left, Martius.
A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,
Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier
Even to Cato’s wish, not fierce and terrible
Only in strokes, but with thy grim looks and
The thunderlike percussion of thy sounds
Thou mad’st thine enemies shake, as if the world
Were feverous and did tremble.
nouns: fellow senseless sword art carbuncle art jewel soldier wish stroke look percussion thine enemy world tremble
adjectives: noble thou entire big thou rich fierce terrible grim thunderlike feverous
verbs: lartius outdare bow leave wast sound shake

title: coriolanus
text: Enter certain Romans, with spoils.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD ROMAN.
A murrain on’t! I took this for silver.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
See here these movers that do prize their hours
At a cracked drachma. Cushions, leaden spoons,
Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would
Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,
Ere yet the fight be done, pack up. Down with them!
nouns: martiu mover hour drachma cushion leaden spoon iron hangman base slave fight
verbs: see prize crack doublet bury wear do pack

title: coriolanus
text:
And hark, what noise the General makes! To him!
There is the man of my soul’s hate, Aufidius,
Piercing our Romans. Then, valiant Titus, take
Convenient numbers to make good the city,
Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste
To help Cominius.
nouns: hark noise man soul hate number city spirit cominius
verbs: make pierce take make haste help

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
Worthy sir, thou bleed’st.
Thy exercise hath been too violent
For a second course of fight.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Sir, praise me not.
My work hath yet not warmed me. Fare you well.
The blood I drop is rather physical
Than dangerous to me. To Aufidius thus
I will appear and fight.
verbs: praise hath warm fare drop appear fight

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
Now the fair goddess Fortune
Fall deep in love with thee, and her great charms
Misguide thy opposers’ swords! Bold gentleman,
Prosperity be thy page!
nouns: goddess love charm opposer sword gentleman prosperity page

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Thy friend no less
Than those she placeth highest! So farewell.

title: coriolanus
text:
Go sound thy trumpet in the marketplace.
Call thither all the officers o’ th’ town,
Where they shall know our mind. Away!
nouns: trumpet marketplace thither officer th town mind

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Breathe you, my friends. Well fought! We are come off
Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands
Nor cowardly in retire. Believe me, sirs,
We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck,
By interims and conveying gusts we have heard
The charges of our friends. The Roman gods
Lead their successes as we wish our own,
That both our powers, with smiling fronts encount’ring,
May give you thankful sacrifice!
nouns: friend stand retire sir while interim gust charge friend god success power front sacrifice
verbs: breathe fight come believe charge strike convey hear lead wish smile encount’re give

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor
More than I know the sound of Martius’ tongue
From every meaner man.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your own.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
O, let me clip you
In arms as sound as when I wooed, in heart
As merry as when our nuptial day was done
And tapers burned to bedward!
nouns: martiu arm sound heart day taper bedward

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
As with a man busied about decrees,
Condemning some to death and some to exile;
Ransoming him or pitying, threat’ning the other;
Holding Corioles in the name of Rome
Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,
To let him slip at will.
nouns: martiu man decree death pitying name greyhound leash will
verbs: busy condemn exile ransom threat’ne hold fawn let slip

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Let him alone.
He did inform the truth. But for our gentlemen,
The common file—a plague! Tribunes for them!—
The mouse ne’er shunned the cat as they did budge
From rascals worse than they.
nouns: martiu truth gentleman file plague tribune mouse ne’er cat rascal

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
As I guess, Martius,
Their bands i’ th’ vaward are the Antiates,
Of their best trust; o’er them Aufidius,
Their very heart of hope.
nouns: band th vaward trust heart hope

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
I do beseech you,
By all the battles wherein we have fought,
By th’ blood we have shed together, by th’ vows we have made
To endure friends, that you directly set me
Against Aufidius and his Antiates,
And that you not delay the present, but,
Filling the air with swords advanced and darts,
We prove this very hour.
nouns: martiu beseech battle th blood th vow friend present air sword dart hour
verbs: fight shed make endure set delay fill prove

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Though I could wish
You were conducted to a gentle bath
And balms applied to you, yet dare I never
Deny your asking. Take your choice of those
That best can aid your action.
verbs: wish conduct apply dare deny take aid

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Those are they
That most are willing. If any such be here—
As it were sin to doubt—that love this painting
Wherein you see me smeared; if any fear
Lesser his person than an ill report;
If any think brave death outweighs bad life,
And that his country’s dearer than himself;
Let him alone, or so many so minded,
Wave thus to express his disposition
And follow Martius.
nouns: martiu be sin painting Wherein person report death life country dearer disposition
adjectives: most willing such ill brave bad many minded
verbs: doubt love see smear fear lesser think let wave express follow

title: coriolanus
text:
O, me alone! Make you a sword of me?
If these shows be not outward, which of you
But is four Volsces? None of you but is
Able to bear against the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number,
Though thanks to all, must I select from all.
The rest shall bear the business in some other fight,
As cause will be obeyed. Please you to march,
And I shall quickly draw out my command,
Which men are best inclined.
nouns: sword show volsce none shield number thank rest business fight cause command man
adjectives: outward able great certain other inclined
verbs: make bear select bear obey draw

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
March on, my fellows.
Make good this ostentation, and you shall
Divide in all with us.

title: coriolanus
text:
Titus Lartius, having set a guard upon Corioles, going with drum and
trumpet toward Cominius and Caius Martius, enters with a Lieutenant,
other Soldiers, and a Scout.

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
So, let the ports be guarded. Keep your duties
As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch
Those centuries to our aid; the rest will serve
For a short holding. If we lose the field,
We cannot keep the town.
nouns: port duty century aid rest holding field town
verbs: lartius let guard keep set send dispatch serve lose keep

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
Hence, and shut your gates upon’s.
Our guider, come. To th’ Roman camp conduct us.

title: coriolanus
text: Alarum, as in battle. Enter Martius and Aufidius at several doors.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
I’ll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee
Worse than a promise-breaker.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
We hate alike.
Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Let the first budger die the other’s slave,
And the gods doom him after!

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Within these three hours, Tullus,
Alone I fought in your Corioles’ walls,
And made what work I pleased. ’Tis not my blood
Wherein thou seest me masked. For thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to th’ highest.
nouns: martiu hour wall work blood thou revenge power
verbs: fight make please tis mask wrench th

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Wert thou the Hector
That was the whip of your bragged progeny,
Thou shouldst not scape me here.

title: coriolanus
text: [_Here they fight, and certain Volsces come to the aid of Aufidius._]

title: coriolanus
text:
Officious and not valiant, you have shamed me
In your condemned seconds.

title: coriolanus
text:
[_Martius fights till they be driven in breathless. Aufidius and
Martius exit, separately._]

title: coriolanus
text:
Alarum. A retreat is sounded. Flourish. Enter, at one door, Cominius
with the Romans; at another door, Martius, with his arm in a scarf.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
If I should tell thee o’er this thy day’s work,
Thou’t not believe thy deeds. But I’ll report it
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles;
Where great patricians shall attend and shrug,
I’ th’ end admire; where ladies shall be frighted
And, gladly quaked, hear more; where the dull tribunes,
That with the fusty plebeians hate thine honours,
Shall say against their hearts “We thank the gods
Our Rome hath such a soldier.”
Yet cam’st thou to a morsel of this feast,
Having fully dined before.
nouns: o’er day work deed senator tear smile patrician end admire lady tribune plebeian thine heart god soldier thou morsel feast
verbs: tell thou’t believe report mingle attend shrug fright quake hear hate honour say thank hath have dine

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
Pray now, no more. My mother,
Who has a charter to extol her blood,
When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
As you have done—that’s what I can;
Induced as you have been—that’s for my country.
He that has but effected his good will
Hath overta’en mine act.
nouns: martiu mother charter blood country overta’en act
verbs: pray extol praise grieve do do ’ ’ effect hath

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
You shall not be
The grave of your deserving. Rome must know
The value of her own. ’Twere a concealment
Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement,
To hide your doings and to silence that
Which, to the spire and top of praises vouched,
Would seem but modest. Therefore, I beseech you—
In sign of what you are, not to reward
What you have done—before our army hear me.
nouns: grave value theft traducement doing spire top praise sign army
verbs: deserve know twere hide silence vouch seem beseech reward do hear

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Should they not,
Well might they fester ’gainst ingratitude
And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses—
Whereof we have ta’en good and good store—of all
The treasure in this field achieved and city,
We render you the tenth, to be ta’en forth
Before the common distribution
At your only choice.
nouns: ingratitude death horse store treasure field city tenth distribution choice

title: coriolanus
text:
MARTIUS.
I thank you, general,
But cannot make my heart consent to take
A bribe to pay my sword. I do refuse it;
And stand upon my common part with those
That have beheld the doing.
nouns: martiu heart consent bribe sword part doing
verbs: thank make take pay refuse stand behold

title: coriolanus
text:
[_A long flourish. They all cry “Martius, Martius!” and cast up their
caps and lances. Cominius and Lartius stand bare._]

title: coriolanus
text:
May these same instruments which, you profane,
Never sound more! When drums and trumpets shall
I’ th’ field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be
Made all of false-faced soothing! When steel grows soft
Soft as the parasite’s silk, let him be made
An ovator for the wars! No more, I say.
For that I have not washed my nose that bled,
Or foiled some debile wretch—which, without note,
Here’s many else have done—you shout me forth
In acclamations hyperbolical,
As if I loved my little should be dieted
In praises sauced with lies.
nouns: instrument drum trumpet th field prove flatterer court city soothing steel parasite silk ovator war nose wretch note acclamation praise lie
adjectives: same more faced soft soft debile many hyperbolical little
verbs: profane sound let be make grow let make say wash bleed foil ’ do shout love diet sauce

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Too modest are you,
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us that give you truly. By your patience,
If ’gainst yourself you be incensed, we’ll put you,
Like one that means his proper harm, in manacles,
Then reason safely with you. Therefore be it known,
As to us to all the world, that Caius Martius
Wears this war’s garland, in token of the which
My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,
With all his trim belonging. And from this time,
For what he did before Corioles, call him,
With all th’ applause and clamour of the host,
Caius Martius Coriolanus! Bear
Th’ addition nobly ever!
nouns: report patience harm manacle reason world war garland token steed camp trim belonging time th applause clamour host addition
adjectives: modest cruel good grateful proper noble
verbs: give gainst incense put mean know wear know give call

title: coriolanus
text: [_Flourish. Trumpets sound, and drums._]

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I will go wash;
And when my face is fair, you shall perceive
Whether I blush or no. Howbeit, I thank you.
I mean to stride your steed and at all times
To undercrest your good addition
To th’ fairness of my power.
nouns: wash face steed time addition fairness power
verbs: go perceive blush thank mean stride undercrest th

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
So, to our tent,
Where, ere we do repose us, we will write
To Rome of our success.—You, Titus Lartius,
Must to Corioles back. Send us to Rome
The best, with whom we may articulate
For their own good and ours.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I sometime lay here in Corioles
At a poor man’s house; he used me kindly.
He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
But then Aufidius was within my view,
And wrath o’erwhelmed my pity. I request you
To give my poor host freedom.
nouns: man house prisoner view wrath pity host freedom
verbs: lie use cry see o’erwhelme request give

title: coriolanus
text:
A flourish. Cornets. Enter Tullus Aufidius, bloody, with two or three
soldiers.

title: coriolanus
text:
SOLDIER.
’Twill be delivered back on good condition.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Condition?
I would I were a Roman, for I cannot,
Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition?
What good condition can a treaty find
I’ th’ part that is at mercy? Five times, Martius,
I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me
And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter
As often as we eat. By th’ elements,
If e’er again I meet him beard to beard,
He’s mine or I am his. Mine emulation
Hath not that honour in’t it had; for where
I thought to crush him in an equal force,
True sword to sword, I’ll potch at him some way,
Or wrath or craft may get him.
nouns: aufidiu condition roman condition condition treaty th part mercy time th element e’er emulation honour force sword sword way wrath craft
verbs: find fight beat think encounter eat meet beard ’ think crush potch get

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour’s poisoned
With only suff’ring stain by him; for him
Shall fly out of itself. Nor sleep nor sanctuary,
Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol,
The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice,
Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up
Their rotten privilege and custom ’gainst
My hate to Martius. Where I find him, were it
At home, upon my brother’s guard, even there,
Against the hospitable canon, would I
Wash my fierce hand in’s heart. Go you to th’ city;
Learn how ’tis held and what they are that must
Be hostages for Rome.
nouns: aufidiu valour stain sleep fane prayer priest time sacrifice fury privilege custom hate home brother guard canon hand heart city hostage
adjectives: subtle suff’ring sanctuary naked sick rotten hospitable fierce
verbs: ’s poison fly embarquement lift find wash go th learn hold

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Ay, to devour him, as the hungry plebeians would the noble Martius.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
He’s a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two are old men; tell
me one thing that I shall ask you.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
He’s poor in no one fault, but stored with all.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
This is strange now. Do you two know how you are censured here in the
city, I mean of us o’ th’ right-hand file, do you?

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Because you talk of pride now, will you not be angry?

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Why, ’tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasion will rob
you of a great deal of patience. Give your dispositions the reins, and
be angry at your pleasures, at the least, if you take it as a pleasure
to you in being so. You blame Martius for being proud.
nouns: matter thief occasion deal patience disposition rein pleasure pleasure
adjectives: great little great angry least proud

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I know you can do very little alone, for your helps are many, or else
your actions would grow wondrous single. Your abilities are too
infantlike for doing much alone. You talk of pride. O that you could
turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks and make but an interior
survey of your good selves! O, that you could!
nouns: help action ability pride eye nape neck survey self
adjectives: many wondrous single infantlike interior good
verbs: know grow do talk turn make

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent,
testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I am known to be a humorous patrician and one that loves a cup of hot
wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in’t; said to be something
imperfect in favouring the first complaint, hasty and tinder-like upon
too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the
night than with the forehead of the morning. What I think I utter, and
spend my malice in my breath. Meeting two such wealsmen as you are—I
cannot call you Lycurguses—if the drink you give me touch my palate
adversely, I make a crooked face at it. I cannot say your Worships have
delivered the matter well when I find the ass in compound with the
major part of your syllables. And though I must be content to bear with
those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that
tell you have good faces. If you see this in the map of my microcosm,
follows it that I am known well enough too? What harm can your bisson
conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough,
too?
nouns: patrician one cup wine drop complaint tinder like motion one buttock night forehead morning malice breath wealsman drink palate face matter ass compound part syllable man face map microcosm harm bisson conspectuitie character
adjectives: humorous hot imperfect first hasty trivial such crooked major content reverend grave deadly good
verbs: know love allay say favour converse think utter spend meet call give touch make say deliver find bear say lie tell see follow know glean be know

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
You know neither me, yourselves, nor anything. You are ambitious for
poor knaves’ caps and legs. You wear out a good wholesome forenoon in
hearing a cause between an orange-wife and a faucet-seller, and then
rejourn the controversy of threepence to a second day of audience. When
you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be
pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers, set up the bloody
flag against all patience, and, in roaring for a chamber pot, dismiss
the controversy bleeding, the more entangled by your hearing. All the
peace you make in their cause is calling both the parties knaves. You
are a pair of strange ones.
nouns: yourself knave cap leg forenoon cause wife seller controversy threepence day audience matter party party colic face mummer flag patience chamber pot controversy hearing peace cause party pair one
adjectives: ambitious poor good wholesome orange faucet second bloody strange
verbs: know wear hear rejourn hear chance pinch make set roar dismiss bleed entangle make call knave

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Come, come. You are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the
table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Our very priests must become mockers if they shall encounter such
ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak best unto the purpose,
it is not worth the wagging of your beards, and your beards deserve not
so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher’s cushion or to be entombed
in an ass’s packsaddle. Yet you must be saying Martius is proud, who,
in a cheap estimation, is worth all your predecessors since Deucalion,
though peradventure some of the best of ’em were hereditary hangmen.
Good e’en to your Worships. More of your conversation would infect my
brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians. I will be bold to
take my leave of you.
nouns: priest mocker subject purpose wagging beard beard grave botcher ’s cushion ass packsaddle estimation predecessor peradventure hangman worship conversation brain herdsman plebeian leave
adjectives: very such ridiculous worth honourable proud cheap worth good hereditary good More beastly bold
verbs: become encounter speak deserve stuff entomb say infect take

title: coriolanus
text:
How now, my as fair as noble ladies—and the moon, were she earthly, no
nobler—whither do you follow your eyes so fast?

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I will make my very house reel tonight. A letter for me?

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
Yes, certain, there’s a letter for you; I saw it.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
A letter for me? It gives me an estate of seven years’ health, in which
time I will make a lip at the physician. The most sovereign
prescription in Galen is but empiricutic and, to this preservative, of
no better report than a horse drench. Is he not wounded? He was wont to
come home wounded.
nouns: letter estate year health time lip physician prescription preservative report horse drench

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
So do I too, if it be not too much. Brings he victory in his pocket,
the wounds become him.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
On’s brows, Menenius. He comes the third time home with the oaken
garland.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Good ladies, let’s go.—Yes, yes, yes. The Senate has letters from the
General, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war. He hath in
this action outdone his former deeds doubly.
nouns: lady go.—yes letter son name war action deed

title: coriolanus
text:
VALERIA.
In troth, there’s wondrous things spoke of him.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Wondrous? Ay, I warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.

title: coriolanus
text:
VIRGILIA.
The gods grant them true.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
True? I’ll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded? [_To the
Tribunes_.] God save your good Worships! Martius is coming home; he has
more cause to be proud.—Where is he wounded?

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
I’ th’ shoulder and i’ th’ left arm. There will be large cicatrices to
show the people when he shall stand for his place. He received in the
repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i’ th’ body.
nouns: th shoulder arm cicatrix people place repulse hurt th body

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
These are the ushers of Martius: before him he carries noise, and
behind him he leaves tears.
Death, that dark spirit, in’s nervy arm doth lie,
Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.
nouns: usher noise tear death spirit arm decline man

title: coriolanus
text:
Enter Cominius the General and Titus Lartius, between them Coriolanus
crowned with an oaken garland, with Captains and Soldiers and a Herald.
Trumpets sound.

title: coriolanus
text:
HERALD.
Know, Rome, that all alone Martius did fight
Within Corioles’ gates, where he hath won,
With fame, a name to Caius Martius; these
In honour follows “Coriolanus.”
Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
No more of this, it does offend my heart.
Pray now, no more.

title: coriolanus
text:
My gentle Martius, worthy Caius, and
By deed-achieving honour newly named—
What is it? Coriolanus must I call thee?
But, O, thy wife—

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
My gracious silence, hail.
Wouldst thou have laughed had I come coffined home,
That weep’st to see me triumph? Ah, my dear,
Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear
And mothers that lack sons.
nouns: silence hail thou triumph eye widow mother son
verbs: laugh come coffin see wear lack

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
And live you yet? [_To Valeria_] O my sweet lady, pardon.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
I know not where to turn. O, welcome home!
And welcome, general.—And you’re welcome all.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
A hundred thousand welcomes! I could weep,
And I could laugh; I am light and heavy. Welcome.
A curse begin at very root on’s heart
That is not glad to see thee! You are three
That Rome should dote on; yet, by the faith of men,
We have some old crab trees here at home that will not
Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors!
We call a nettle but a nettle, and
The faults of fools but folly.
nouns: welcome curse root heart faith man crab tree home relish warrior fault fool
adjectives: light heavy very glad old nettle nettle
verbs: weep laugh begin see dote graft call

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
[_To Volumnia and Virgilia_.] Your hand, and yours.
Ere in our own house I do shade my head,
The good patricians must be visited,
From whom I have received not only greetings,
But with them change of honours.
nouns: hand your house head patrician greeting change honour

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Know, good mother,
I had rather be their servant in my way
Than sway with them in theirs.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him. Your prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cry
While she chats him. The kitchen malkin pins
Her richest lockram ’bout her reechy neck,
Clamb’ring the walls to eye him. Stalls, bulks, windows
Are smothered up, leads filled, and ridges horsed
With variable complexions, all agreeing
In earnestness to see him. Seld-shown flamens
Do press among the popular throngs and puff
To win a vulgar station. Our veiled dames
Commit the war of white and damask in
Their nicely-gauded cheeks to th’ wanton spoil
Of Phoebus’ burning kisses. Such a pother,
As if that whatsoever god who leads him
Were slyly crept into his human powers
And gave him graceful posture.
nouns: tongue sight prattling nurse rapture baby kitchen malkin pin lockram neck wall stall bulk window ridge complexion earnestness seld flamen press throng puff station dame war cheek wanton spoil kiss pother power posture
adjectives: bleared rich reechy variable popular vulgar veiled human graceful
verbs: speak spectacle see let cry chat clamb’re eye smother lead fill horse agree see show win commit gaude th burn lead creep give

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
On the sudden
I warrant him consul.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
He cannot temp’rately transport his honours
From where he should begin and end, but will
Lose those he hath won.
verbs: transport begin end lose hath win

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Doubt not the commoners, for whom we stand,
But they, upon their ancient malice will forget
With the least cause these his new honours—which
That he will give them make as little question
As he is proud to do’t.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
So it must fall out
To him, or our authorities for an end.
We must suggest the people in what hatred
He still hath held them; that to’s power he would
Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders, and
Dispropertied their freedoms; holding them
In human action and capacity
Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
Than camels in their war, who have their provand
Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
For sinking under them.
nouns: authority end people hatred power mule pleader freedom action capacity soul fitness world camel war provand burden blow
verbs: fall suggest hath hold make silence dispropertie hold bear sink

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
This, as you say, suggested
At some time when his soaring insolence
Shall touch the people—which time shall not want
If it be put upon’t, and that’s as easy
As to set dogs on sheep—will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble, and their blaze
Shall darken him for ever.
nouns: sicinius time insolence people time dog sheep fire blaze
verbs: say suggest soar touch want put ’ set kindle shall darken

title: coriolanus
text:
MESSENGER.
You are sent for to the Capitol. ’Tis thought
That Martius shall be consul. I have seen
The dumb men throng to see him, and the blind
to hear him speak; matrons flung gloves,
Ladies and maids their scarves and handkerchiefs,
Upon him as he passed; the nobles bended
As to Jove’s statue, and the Commons made
A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts.
I never saw the like.
nouns: messenger consul man matron glove lady scarf handkerchief noble statue shower thunder cap shout
verbs: send think see see hear speak fling maid pass bend make see

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST OFFICER.
Come, come. They are almost here. How many stand for consulships?

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST OFFICER.
That’s a brave fellow, but he’s vengeance proud and loves not the
common people.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND OFFICER.
’Faith, there have been many great men that have flattered the people
who ne’er loved them; and there be many that they have loved they know
not wherefore; so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon
no better a ground. Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether
they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their
disposition and, out of his noble carelessness, lets them plainly
see’t.
nouns: man people ne’er ground knowledge disposition carelessness
adjectives: many great many wherefore well true noble
verbs: flatter love love know love know hate care love hate manifest let

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST OFFICER.
If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved
indifferently ’twixt doing them neither good nor harm; but he seeks
their hate with greater devotion than they can render it him and leaves
nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite. Now, to seem
to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that
which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.
nouns: love no harm hate devotion opposite malice displeasure people love
verbs: care wave twixt do seek render leave undo discover seem affect dislike flatter

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND OFFICER.
He hath deserved worthily of his country, and his ascent is not by such
easy degrees as those who, having been supple and courteous to the
people, bonnetted, without any further deed to have them at all into
their estimation and report; but he hath so planted his honours in
their eyes and his actions in their hearts that for their tongues to be
silent and not confess so much were a kind of ingrateful injury. To
report otherwise were a malice that, giving itself the lie, would pluck
reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.
nouns: country ascent degree people deed estimation report honours eye action heart tongue kind injury report malice lie reproof rebuke ear
adjectives: such easy supple courteous further silent much ingrateful
verbs: hath deserve have bonnette hath plant confess give pluck hear

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST OFFICER.
No more of him; he’s a worthy man. Make way. They are coming.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Having determined of the Volsces and
To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
As the main point of this our after-meeting,
To gratify his noble service that
Hath thus stood for his country. Therefore please you,
Most reverend and grave elders, to desire
The present consul and last general
In our well-found successes to report
A little of that worthy work performed
By Martius Caius Coriolanus, whom
We met here both to thank and to remember
With honours like himself.
nouns: point after meeting service country elder consul general success work honour
adjectives: main noble Most reverend grave present last little worthy
verbs: have determine send remain gratify stand desire find report perform meet thank remember

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Speak, good Cominius.
Leave nothing out for length, and make us think
Rather our state’s defective for requital,
Than we to stretch it out. Masters o’ th’ people,
We do request your kindest ears and, after,
Your loving motion toward the common body
To yield what passes here.
nouns: length state requital th people ear motion body
verbs: leave make think stretch request love yield pass

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
We are convented
Upon a pleasing treaty and have hearts
Inclinable to honour and advance
The theme of our assembly.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Which the rather
We shall be blest to do if he remember
A kinder value of the people than
He hath hereto prized them at.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
That’s off, that’s off!
I would you rather had been silent. Please you
To hear Cominius speak?

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Most willingly.
But yet my caution was more pertinent
Than the rebuke you give it.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Sit, Coriolanus. Never shame to hear
What you have nobly done.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Masters of the people,
Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter—
That’s thousand to one good one—when you now see
He had rather venture all his limbs for honour
Than one on’s ears to hear it?—Proceed, Cominius.
nouns: people multiplying spawn limb honour ear

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
I shall lack voice. The deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be uttered feebly. It is held
That valour is the chiefest virtue and
Most dignifies the haver; if it be,
The man I speak of cannot in the world
Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years,
When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the mark of others. Our then dictator,
Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
The bristled lips before him. He bestrid
An o’erpressed Roman and i’ th’ Consul’s view
Slew three opposers. Tarquin’s self he met
And struck him on his knee. In that day’s feats,
When he might act the woman in the scene,
He proved best man i’ th’ field and for his meed
Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
Man-entered thus, he waxed like a sea,
And in the brunt of seventeen battles since
He lurched all swords of the garland. For this last,
Before and in Corioles, let me say,
I cannot speak him home. He stopped the flyers
And by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror into sport. As weeds before
A vessel under sail, so men obeyed
And fell below his stem. His sword, Death’s stamp,
Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot
He was a thing of blood, whose every motion
Was timed with dying cries. Alone he entered
The mortal gate o’ th’ city, which he painted
With shunless destiny; aidless came off
And with a sudden reinforcement struck
Corioles like a planet. Now all’s his,
When by and by the din of war gan pierce
His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit
Requickened what in flesh was fatigate,
And to the battle came he, where he did
Run reeking o’er the lives of men as if
’Twere a perpetual spoil; and till we called
Both field and city ours, he never stood
To ease his breast with panting.
nouns: voice deed valour virtue dignifie haver man world year head mark other dictator praise chin lip roman view opposer self knee day feat woman scene man i th field meed brow oak pupil age man sea brunt battle sword garland flyer example coward terror sport weed vessel sail man stem sword stamp mark face thing blood motion cry gate th city shunless destiny aidless reinforcement planet din war pierce sense spirit flesh battle o’er life man spoil field city our breast panting
adjectives: chief Most amazonian bristled o’erpressed good last rare mortal sudden ready fatigate perpetual
verbs: lack utter hold be speak counterpoise make fight point see fight drive bestride meet strike act prove bind enter wax lurch let say speak stop make turn obey fall take foot time die enter paint come strike ’s double requickene come run reek twere call stand ease

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
He cannot but with measure fit the honours
Which we devise him.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Our spoils he kicked at;
And looked upon things precious as they were
The common muck of the world. He covets less
Than misery itself would give, rewards
His deeds with doing them, and is content
To spend the time to end it.
nouns: spoil thing muck world misery deed content time
verbs: kick look covet give reward do spend end

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased
To make thee consul.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I do beseech you
Let me o’erleap that custom, for I cannot
Put on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them
For my wounds’ sake to give their suffrage. Please you
That I may pass this doing.
nouns: beseech custom gown wound sake suffrage doing
verbs: let o’erleap put stand entreat give pass

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
To brag unto them, “thus I did, and thus!”
Show them th’ unaching scars which I should hide,
As if I had received them for the hire
Of their breath only!

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Do not stand upon’t.—
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
Our purpose to them, and to our noble consul
Wish we all joy and honour.
nouns: tribune people purpose consul joy honour

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CITIZEN.
We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no
power to do; for, if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we
are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them. So, if he
tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him our noble acceptance of
them. Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful
were to make a monster of the multitude, of the which we being members,
should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.
nouns: power power power wound deed tongue wound deed acceptance ingratitude multitude monster multitude member member
verbs: show tell put speak tell tell make bring

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once
we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the
many-headed multitude.
verbs: make serve stand stick call head

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CITIZEN.
We have been called so of many; not that our heads are some brown, some
black, some auburn, some bald, but that our wits are so diversely
coloured; and truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of one
skull, they would fly east, west, north, south, and their consent of
one direct way should be at once to all the points o’ th’ compass.
nouns: head auburn wit wit skull east north south consent way point o th compass

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CITIZEN.
To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts melted away with
rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience’ sake, to help to
get thee a wife.
nouns: fog part dew conscience sake wife

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CITIZEN.
Are you all resolved to give your voices? But that’s no matter; the
greater part carries it. I say, if he would incline to the people,
there was never a worthier man.

title: coriolanus
text:
Here he comes, and in the gown of humility. Mark his behaviour. We are
not to stay all together, but to come by him where he stands, by ones,
by twos, and by threes. He’s to make his requests by particulars,
wherein everyone of us has a single honour in giving him our own voices
with our own tongues. Therefore follow me, and I’ll direct you how you
shall go by him.
nouns: gown humility behaviour one two three request particular honour voice tongue
verbs: come mark stay come stand ’ make give follow direct go

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
O sir, you are not right. Have you not known
The worthiest men have done’t?

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
What must I say?
“I pray, sir”—plague upon’t! I cannot bring
My tongue to such a pace. “Look, sir, my wounds!
I got them in my country’s service when
Some certain of your brethren roared and ran
From th’ noise of our own drums.”
nouns: tongue pace sir wound country service brother th noise drum
verbs: say pray bring look get roar run

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
You’ll mar all.
I’ll leave you. Pray you speak to ’em, I pray you,
In wholesome manner.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Bid them wash their faces
And keep their teeth clean.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
No, sir, ’twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Kindly, sir, I pray, let me ha’t. I have wounds to show you, which
shall be yours in private.—Your good voice, sir. What say you?

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
A match, sir. There’s in all two worthy voices begged. I have your
alms. Adieu.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may
be consul, I have here the customary gown.

title: coriolanus
text:
FOURTH CITIZEN.
You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have been a rod to her
friends. You have not indeed loved the common people.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in
my love. I will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a
dearer estimation of them; ’tis a condition they account gentle. And
since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my
heart, I will practise the insinuating nod and be off to them most
counterfeitly. That is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some
popular man and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech
you, I may be consul.
nouns: love brother people dearer estimation condition wisdom choice hat heart nod bewitchment man desirer beseech consul
adjectives: virtuous common sworn gentle popular bountiful
verbs: account flatter earn tis account practise insinuate counterfeit give

title: coriolanus
text:
FOURTH CITIZEN.
You have received many wounds for your country.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I will make much of
your voices and so trouble you no farther.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Most sweet voices!
Better it is to die, better to starve,
Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
Why in this wolvish toge should I stand here
To beg of Hob and Dick that does appear
Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to’t.
What custom wills, in all things should we do’t?
The dust on antique time would lie unswept
And mountainous error be too highly heaped
For truth to o’erpeer. Rather than fool it so,
Let the high office and the honour go
To one that would do thus. I am half through;
The one part suffered, the other will I do.
nouns: voice hire toge vouche custom thing dust time error truth office honour part
adjectives: sweet well wolvish needless antique unswept mountainous heaped high other
verbs: die starve crave deserve stand beg appear call will lie o’erpeer fool let go suffer

title: coriolanus
text:
Here come more voices.
Your voices! For your voices I have fought;
Watched for your voices; for your voices bear
Of wounds two dozen odd. Battles thrice six
I have seen and heard of; for your voices have
Done many things, some less, some more. Your voices!
Indeed, I would be consul.
nouns: voice voice voice voice voice wound dozen battle thrice voice thing voice consul
verbs: come fight watch bear see hear do

title: coriolanus
text:
SIXTH CITIZEN.
He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man’s voice.

title: coriolanus
text:
SEVENTH CITIZEN.
Therefore let him be consul. The gods give him joy, and make him good
friend to the people!

title: coriolanus
text:
ALL THREE CITIZENS.
Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
You have stood your limitation, and the Tribunes
Endue you with the people’s voice. Remains
That in th’ official marks invested, you
Anon do meet the Senate.
nouns: limitation people voice remain th mark

title: coriolanus
text:
He has it now; and by his looks, methinks,
’Tis warm at his heart.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
With a proud heart he wore
His humble weeds. Will you dismiss the people?

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND CITIZEN.
Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice,
He mocked us when he begged our voices.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND CITIZEN.
Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says
He used us scornfully. He should have showed us
His marks of merit, wounds received for’s country.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CITIZEN.
He said he had wounds, which he could show in private,
And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,
“I would be consul,” says he; “aged custom,
But by your voices, will not so permit me;
Your voices therefore.” When we granted that,
Here was “I thank you for your voices. Thank you.
Your most sweet voices! Now you have left your voices,
I have no further with you.” Was not this mockery?
nouns: wound hat scorn consul custom voice voice voice voice voice mockery
verbs: say show wave say permit grant thank thank leave

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Why either were you ignorant to see’t
Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness
To yield your voices?

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Could you not have told him
As you were lessoned? When he had no power,
But was a petty servant to the state,
He was your enemy, ever spake against
Your liberties and the charters that you bear
I’ th’ body of the weal; and, now arriving
A place of potency and sway o’ th’ state,
If he should still malignantly remain
Fast foe to th’ plebeii, your voices might
Be curses to yourselves. You should have said
That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature
Would think upon you for your voices, and
Translate his malice towards you into love,
Standing your friendly lord.
nouns: power servant state enemy liberty charter th body weal place potency state foe plebeii voice curse yourself deed nature voice malice love
verbs: tell lessone spake bear arrive sway remain th say claim stand think translate stand

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Thus to have said,
As you were fore-advised, had touched his spirit
And tried his inclination; from him plucked
Either his gracious promise, which you might,
As cause had called you up, have held him to;
Or else it would have galled his surly nature,
Which easily endures not article
Tying him to aught. So putting him to rage,
You should have ta’en th’ advantage of his choler
And passed him unelected.
nouns: sicinius spirit inclination promise cause nature article advantage
verbs: say advise touch try pluck call hold gall endure tie aught put rage pass

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Did you perceive
He did solicit you in free contempt
When he did need your loves, and do you think
That his contempt shall not be bruising to you
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
No heart among you? Or had you tongues to cry
Against the rectorship of judgment?
nouns: contempt love contempt power body heart tongue rectorship judgment
verbs: perceive solicit need think bruise hath crush cry

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Have you ere now denied the asker, and now
Again, of him that did not ask but mock,
Bestow your sued-for tongues?

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends
They have chose a consul that will from them take
Their liberties, make them of no more voice
Than dogs that are as often beat for barking
As therefore kept to do so.
verbs: get tell choose take make beat bark keep

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Let them assemble
And, on a safer judgment, all revoke
Your ignorant election. Enforce his pride
And his old hate unto you. Besides, forget not
With what contempt he wore the humble weed,
How in his suit he scorned you; but your loves,
Thinking upon his services, took from you
Th’ apprehension of his present portance,
Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion
After the inveterate hate he bears you.
nouns: sicinius judgment election pride hate contempt weed suit love service th apprehension portance fashion inveterate
verbs: let assemble revoke enforce forget wear scorn think take hate bear

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Say you chose him
More after our commandment than as guided
By your own true affections, and that your minds,
Preoccupied with what you rather must do
Than what you should, made you against the grain
To voice him consul. Lay the fault on us.
nouns: sicinius commandment affection mind grain consul fault
verbs: say choose guide preoccupy make voice lay

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you,
How youngly he began to serve his country,
How long continued, and what stock he springs of,
The noble house o’ th’ Martians, from whence came
That Ancus Martius, Numa’s daughter’s son,
Who, after great Hostilius here was king,
Of the same house Publius and Quintus were,
That our best water brought by conduits hither;
And Censorinus, that was so surnamed,
And nobly named so, twice being censor,
Was his great ancestor.
nouns: lecture country stock house th whence daughter son king house water conduit censor ancestor
adjectives: noble great same good surnamed great
verbs: spare say read begin serve continue spring come bring name

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
One thus descended,
That hath beside well in his person wrought
To be set high in place, we did commend
To your remembrances; but you have found,
Scaling his present bearing with his past,
That he’s your fixed enemy, and revoke
Your sudden approbation.
nouns: sicinius person place remembrance bearing past enemy approbation
verbs: descend hath work set commend find scale ’ fix revoke

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Let them go on.
This mutiny were better put in hazard
Than stay, past doubt, for greater.
If, as his nature is, he fall in rage
With their refusal, both observe and answer
The vantage of his anger.
nouns: mutiny hazard doubt nature rage refusal vantage anger
verbs: let go put stay fall observe answer

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
To th’ Capitol, come.
We will be there before the stream o’ th’ people,
And this shall seem, as partly ’tis, their own,
Which we have goaded onward.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
So then the Volsces stand but as at first,
Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road
Upon’s again.

title: coriolanus
text:
LARTIUS.
How often he had met you sword to sword;
That of all things upon the earth he hated
Your person most; that he would pawn his fortunes
To hopeless restitution, so he might
Be called your vanquisher.
nouns: sword sword thing earth person fortune restitution vanquisher

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I wish I had a cause to seek him there,
To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.

title: coriolanus
text:
Behold, these are the tribunes of the people,
The tongues o’ th’ common mouth. I do despise them,
For they do prank them in authority
Against all noble sufferance.
nouns: tribune people tongue th mouth authority sufferance

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Tribunes, give way. He shall to the marketplace.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot,
To curb the will of the nobility.
Suffer’t, and live with such as cannot rule
Nor ever will be ruled.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Call’t not a plot.
The people cry you mocked them; and, of late,
When corn was given them gratis, you repined,
Scandaled the suppliants for the people, called them
Timepleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.
nouns: plot people corn gratis suppliant people flatterer foe nobleness
verbs: cry mock give repine scandale call

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds,
Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me
Your fellow tribune.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
You show too much of that
For which the people stir. If you will pass
To where you are bound, you must inquire your way,
Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit,
Or never be so noble as a consul,
Nor yoke with him for tribune.
verbs: show stir pass bind inquire yoke

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
The people are abused, set on. This palt’ring
Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus
Deserved this so dishonoured rub, laid falsely
I’ th’ plain way of his merit.
verbs: abuse set palt’re become deserve lay

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Now, as I live, I will.
My nobler friends, I crave their pardons. For
The mutable, rank-scented many, let them
Regard me, as I do not flatter, and
Therein behold themselves. I say again,
In soothing them we nourish ’gainst our senate
The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition,
Which we ourselves have ploughed for, sowed, and scattered
By mingling them with us, the honoured number,
Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that
Which they have given to beggars.
nouns: friend pardon rank cockle rebellion insolence sedition number virtue power beggar
verbs: live crave scent let regard flatter behold say soothe nourish plough sow scatter mingle lack give

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
No more words, we beseech you.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
How? No more?
As for my country I have shed my blood,
Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs
Coin words till their decay against those measles
Which we disdain should tetter us, yet sought
The very way to catch them.
nouns: country blood force lung word decay measle way
verbs: shed fear disdain tetter seek catch

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
“Shall remain”?
Hear you this Triton of the minnows? Mark you
His absolute “shall”?

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
“Shall”?
O good but most unwise patricians, why,
You grave but reckless senators, have you thus
Given Hydra leave to choose an officer,
That with his peremptory “shall,” being but
The horn and noise o’ th’ monster’s, wants not spirit
To say he’ll turn your current in a ditch
And make your channel his? If he have power,
Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learned,
Be not as common fools; if you are not,
Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians,
If they be senators; and they are no less
When, both your voices blended, the great’st taste
Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate,
And such a one as he, who puts his “shall,”
His popular “shall,” against a graver bench
Than ever frowned in Greece. By Jove himself,
It makes the consuls base! And my soul aches
To know, when two authorities are up,
Neither supreme, how soon confusion
May enter ’twixt the gap of both and take
The one by th’ other.
nouns: patrician senator officer shall horn noise th monster current ditch channel power ignorance none lenity fool cushion plebeian senator voice taste their magistrate one shall shall bench consul base soul authority confusion gap th
adjectives: good unwise grave reckless peremptory awake dangerous common Most popular graver supreme other
verbs: give leave choose want spirit say turn make vail learn let be blend palate choose put frown make ache know enter twixt take

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Though there the people had more absolute power,
I say they nourished disobedience, fed
The ruin of the state.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I’ll give my reasons,
More worthier than their voices. They know the corn
Was not our recompense, resting well assured
They ne’er did service for’t. Being pressed to th’ war,
Even when the navel of the state was touched,
They would not thread the gates. This kind of service
Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i’ th’ war,
Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they showed
Most valour, spoke not for them. Th’ accusation
Which they have often made against the Senate,
All cause unborn, could never be the native
Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?
How shall this bosom multitude digest
The senate’s courtesy? Let deeds express
What’s like to be their words: “We did request it;
We are the greater poll, and in true fear
They gave us our demands.” Thus we debase
The nature of our seats and make the rabble
Call our cares fears, which will in time
Break ope the locks o’ th’ Senate and bring in
The crows to peck the eagles.
nouns: reason voice corn recompense ne’er service for’t war navel state gate kind service corn gratis i th war mutiny revolt valour th accusation donation bosom multitude digest courtesy deed word poll fear demand nature seat care fear time ope lock crow eagle
adjectives: Most unborn native frank great true rabble
verbs: give know rest assure press th touch thread deserve show speak make cause let express ’ like request give debase make call bring peck

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
No, take more!
What may be sworn by, both divine and human,
Seal what I end withal! This double worship—
Where one part does disdain with cause, the other
Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom
Cannot conclude but by the yea and no
Of general ignorance—it must omit
Real necessities and give way the while
To unstable slightness. Purpose so barred, it follows
Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you—
You that will be less fearful than discreet,
That love the fundamental part of state
More than you doubt the change on’t, that prefer
A noble life before a long, and wish
To jump a body with a dangerous physic
That’s sure of death without it—at once pluck out
The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick
The sweet which is their poison. Your dishonour
Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state
Of that integrity which should become’t,
Not having the power to do the good it would
For th’ ill which doth control’t.
nouns: no withal worship part cause reason gentry title wisdom no ignorance necessity way while slightness purpose beseech part state change on’t life body physic death tongue poison judgment state integrity power good th ill doth control’t
adjectives: more divine human double other yea general real unstable barred fearful discreet fundamental More noble long dangerous sure multitudinous sweet dishonour true
verbs: take swear seal end disdain conclude omit give follow do purpose love doubt prefer wish jump ’ pluck let lick bereave have

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Thou wretch, despite o’erwhelm thee!
What should the people do with these bald tribunes,
On whom depending, their obedience fails
To th’ greater bench. In a rebellion,
When what’s not meet but what must be was law,
Then were they chosen. In a better hour,
Let what is meet be said it must be meet,
And throw their power i’ th’ dust.
nouns: wretch people tribune obedience bench rebellion law hour power th dust
verbs: depend fail th ’ meet be choose let meet say meet throw

title: coriolanus
text:
in whose name myself
Attach thee as a traitorous innovator,
A foe to th’ public weal. Obey, I charge thee,
And follow to thine answer.
nouns: name thee innovator foe weal thine answer

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
[_to Sicinius_.] Hence, rotten thing, or I shall shake thy bones
Out of thy garments.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
What is about to be? I am out of breath.
Confusion’s near. I cannot speak. You tribunes
To th’ people!—Coriolanus, patience!—
Speak, good Sicinius.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
You are at point to lose your liberties.
Martius would have all from you, Martius,
Whom late you have named for consul.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
That is the way to lay the city flat,
To bring the roof to the foundation
And bury all which yet distinctly ranges
In heaps and piles of ruin.
nouns: way city roof foundation heap pile ruin

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Or let us stand to our authority
Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,
Upon the part o’ th’ people, in whose power
We were elected theirs, Martius is worthy
Of present death.
nouns: authority pronounce part th people power death

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Be that you seem, truly your country’s friend,
And temp’rately proceed to what you would
Thus violently redress.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Sir, those cold ways,
That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous
Where the disease is violent.—Lay hands upon him,
And bear him to the rock.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Help Martius, help!
You that be noble, help him, young and old!

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Stand fast!
We have as many friends as enemies.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
The gods forbid!
I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house;
Leave us to cure this cause.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Begone!
Put not your worthy rage into your tongue.
One time will owe another.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
On fair ground
I could beat forty of them.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I could myself
Take up a brace o’ th’ best of them, yea, the two tribunes.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
But now ’tis odds beyond arithmetic,
And manhood is called foolery when it stands
Against a falling fabric. Will you hence,
Before the tag return, whose rage doth rend
Like interrupted waters, and o’erbear
What they are used to bear?
nouns: tis odd manhood foolery fabric tag return rage rend water
verbs: call stand fall o’erbear use bear

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Pray you, begone.
I’ll try whether my old wit be in request
With those that have but little. This must be patched
With cloth of any colour.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
His nature is too noble for the world.
He would not flatter Neptune for his trident
Or Jove for’s power to thunder. His heart’s his mouth;
What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent,
And, being angry, does forget that ever
He heard the name of death.
nouns: nature world trident power heart mouth breast tongue name death
verbs: flatter thunder ’ forge vent forget hear

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance,
Could he not speak ’em fair?

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands. He hath resisted law,
And therefore law shall scorn him further trial
Than the severity of the public power
Which he so sets at naught.
nouns: sicinius rock hand law law trial severity power naught

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
He shall well know
The noble tribunes are the people’s mouths,
And we their hands.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Do not cry havoc where you should but hunt
With modest warrant.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
If, by the Tribunes’ leave, and yours, good people,
I may be heard, I would crave a word or two,
The which shall turn you to no further harm
Than so much loss of time.
nouns: your people word harm loss time

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Speak briefly then,
For we are peremptory to dispatch
This viperous traitor. To eject him hence
Were but one danger, and to keep him here
Our certain death. Therefore it is decreed
He dies tonight.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Now the good gods forbid
That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
Towards her deserved children is enrolled
In Jove’s own book, like an unnatural dam
Should now eat up her own.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
O, he’s a limb that has but a disease—
Mortal to cut it off; to cure it easy.
What has he done to Rome that’s worthy death?
Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost—
Which I dare vouch is more than that he hath
By many an ounce—he dropt it for his country;
And what is left, to lose it by his country
Were to us all, that do’t and suffer it
A brand to th’ end o’ th’ world.
nouns: limb disease death enemy blood ounce country country brand end o th world
verbs: ’ cut cure do ’ kill hath lose dare hath dropt leave lose suffer th

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Merely awry. When he did love his country,
It honoured him.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
We’ll hear no more.
Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence,
Lest his infection, being of catching nature,
Spread further.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
One word more, one word!
This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find
The harm of unscanned swiftness, will too late,
Tie leaden pounds to’s heels. Proceed by process,
Lest parties—as he is beloved—break out
And sack great Rome with Romans.
nouns: word word tiger rage harm swiftness pound heel process party
adjectives: more unscanned late leaden beloved great
verbs: foot find tie proceed break sack

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Consider this: he has been bred i’ th’ wars
Since he could draw a sword, and is ill schooled
In bolted language; meal and bran together
He throws without distinction. Give me leave,
I’ll go to him and undertake to bring him
Where he shall answer by a lawful form,
In peace, to his utmost peril.
nouns: th war sword language meal distinction form peace peril
verbs: consider breed draw school bolt bran throw give leave go undertake bring answer

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
Noble tribunes,
It is the humane way: the other course
Will prove too bloody, and the end of it
Unknown to the beginning.
adjectives: first noble humane other bloody unknown

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Meet on the marketplace. We’ll attend you there,
Where if you bring not Martius, we’ll proceed
In our first way.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I’ll bring him to you.
[_To Senators_.] Let me desire your company. He must come,
Or what is worst will follow.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Let them pull all about mine ears, present me
Death on the wheel or at wild horses’ heels,
Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
That the precipitation might down stretch
Below the beam of sight, yet will I still
Be thus to them.
nouns: mine ear wheel horse heel hill rock precipitation beam sight

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I muse my mother
Does not approve me further, who was wont
To call them woollen vassals, things created
To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads
In congregations, to yawn, be still, and wonder
When one but of my ordinance stood up
To speak of peace or war.
