nouns: mother vassal thing groat head congregation ordinance peace war
verbs: muse approve call create buy sell show yawn wonder stand speak

title: coriolanus
text:
I talk of you.
Why did you wish me milder? Would you have me
False to my nature? Rather say I play
The man I am.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
You might have been enough the man you are
With striving less to be so. Lesser had been
The thwartings of your dispositions if
You had not showed them how ye were disposed
Ere they lacked power to cross you.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SENATOR.
There’s no remedy,
Unless, by not so doing, our good city
Cleave in the midst and perish.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Pray be counselled.
I have a heart as little apt as yours,
But yet a brain that leads my use of anger
To better vantage.
nouns: heart your brain use anger vantage

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Well said, noble woman.
Before he should thus stoop to th’ herd—but that
The violent fit o’ th’ time craves it as physic
For the whole state—I would put mine armour on,
Which I can scarcely bear.
nouns: woman herd fit o th time state mine armour
verbs: say stoop th crave put bear

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
You are too absolute,
Though therein you can never be too noble
But when extremities speak. I have heard you say
Honour and policy, like unsevered friends,
I’ th’ war do grow together. Grant that, and tell me
In peace what each of them by th’ other lose
That they combine not there.
nouns: extremity policy friend th war peace th
verbs: speak hear say grow tell lose combine

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
If it be honour in your wars to seem
The same you are not, which for your best ends
You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse
That it shall hold companionship in peace
With honour as in war, since that to both
It stands in like request?
nouns: war end policy companionship peace honour war request

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Because that now it lies you on to speak
To th’ people, not by your own instruction,
Nor by th’ matter which your heart prompts you,
But with such words that are but rooted in
Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables
Of no allowance to your bosom’s truth.
Now, this no more dishonours you at all
Than to take in a town with gentle words,
Which else would put you to your fortune and
The hazard of much blood.
I would dissemble with my nature where
My fortunes and my friends at stake required
I should do so in honour. I am in this
Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles;
And you will rather show our general louts
How you can frown than spend a fawn upon ’em
For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard
Of what that want might ruin.
nouns: VOLUMNIA people instruction th matter heart word tongue bastard syllable allowance bosom truth town word fortune hazard blood nature fortune friend stake honour wife son senator noble lout fawn inheritance love safeguard
verbs: lie speak th prompt root take put dissemble require show frown spend want ruin

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Noble lady!—
Come, go with us; speak fair. You may salve so,
Not what is dangerous present, but the loss
Of what is past.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
I prithee now, my son,
Go to them with this bonnet in thy hand,
And thus far having stretched it—here be with them—
Thy knee bussing the stones—for in such busines
Action is eloquence, and the eyes of th’ ignorant
More learned than the ears—waving thy head,
Which often thus correcting thy stout heart,
Now humble as the ripest mulberry
That will not hold the handling. Or say to them
Thou art their soldier and, being bred in broils,
Hast not the soft way, which thou dost confess
Were fit for thee to use, as they to claim,
In asking their good loves; but thou wilt frame
Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far
As thou hast power and person.
nouns: son bonnet hand knee stone busine eloquence eye th ear head heart mulberry handling soldier broil way thou love thou forsooth theirs hast power person
adjectives: such ignorant learned stout humble ripe soft fit good hereafter
verbs: prithee go have stretch buss wave correct hold say art breed dost use claim ask

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
This but done
Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours;
For they have pardons, being asked, as free
As words to little purpose.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Prithee now,
Go, and be ruled; although I know thou hadst rather
Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf
Than flatter him in a bower.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
I have been i’ th’ marketplace; and, sir, ’tis fit
You make strong party or defend yourself
By calmness or by absence. All’s in anger.
nouns: th marketplace tis fit party calmness absence anger

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce? Must I
With my base tongue give to my noble heart
A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do’t.
Yet, were there but this single plot to lose,
This mould of Martius, they to dust should grind it
And throw’t against the wind. To th’ marketplace!
You have put me now to such a part which never
I shall discharge to th’ life.
nouns: sconce base tongue heart lie plot mould dust throw’t wind marketplace part life
verbs: go show give bear lose grind th put discharge th

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said
My praises made thee first a soldier, so,
To have my praise for this, perform a part
Thou hast not done before.
nouns: son praise soldier praise part hast

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Well, I must do’t.
Away, my disposition, and possess me
Some harlot’s spirit! My throat of war be turned,
Which choired with my drum, into a pipe
Small as an eunuch or the virgin voice
That babies lulls asleep! The smiles of knaves
Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys’ tears take up
The glasses of my sight! A beggar’s tongue
Make motion through my lips, and my armed knees,
Who bowed but in my stirrup, bend like his
That hath received an alms! I will not do’t,
Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth
And, by my body’s action, teach my mind
A most inherent baseness.
nouns: disposition harlot spirit throat war drum pipe eunuch voice baby smile cheek schoolboy tear glass sight beggar ’s tongue motion lip knee stirrup hath alm truth body action mind baseness
verbs: possess turn choir lull take make bow bend receive surcease honour teach

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
At thy choice, then.
To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour
Than thou of them. Come all to ruin. Let
Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear
Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death
With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list.
Thy valiantness was mine; thou suck’dst it from me,
But owe thy pride thyself.
nouns: choice thee thou mother pride stoutness death heart thou thou list valiantness pride
verbs: beg come ruin let feel fear Thy mock suck’dst owe

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Away! The Tribunes do attend you. Arm yourself
To answer mildly, for they are prepared
With accusations, as I hear, more strong
Than are upon you yet.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
The word is “mildly.” Pray you, let us go.
Let them accuse me by invention, I
Will answer in mine honour.
verbs: pray let go let accuse answer

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
In this point charge him home, that he affects
Tyrannical power. If he evade us there,
Enforce him with his envy to the people,
And that the spoil got on the Antiates
Was ne’er distributed.
nouns: point power envy people spoil ne’er
verbs: charge affect evade enforce get distribute

title: coriolanus
text:
AEDILE.
With old Menenius, and those senators
That always favoured him.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Assemble presently the people hither;
And when they hear me say “It shall be so
I’ th’ right and strength o’ th’ commons,” be it either
For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them
If I say “Fine,” cry “Fine,” if “Death,” cry “Death,”
Insisting on the old prerogative
And power i’ th’ truth o’ th’ cause.
nouns: people th right strength o th common death fine banishment cry death cry death prerogative power th truth th cause
verbs: assemble hear say let say insist

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
And when such time they have begun to cry,
Let them not cease, but with a din confused
Enforce the present execution
Of what we chance to sentence.
verbs: begin cry let cease chance sentence

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Make them be strong and ready for this hint
When we shall hap to give’t them.

title: coriolanus
text: Enter Coriolanus, Menenius and Cominius with other Senators.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Ay, as an ostler, that for th’ poorest piece
Will bear the knave by th’ volume.—Th’ honoured gods
Keep Rome in safety and the chairs of justice
Supplied with worthy men! Plant love among’s!
Throng our large temples with the shows of peace
And not our streets with war!
nouns: ostler piece knave th god safety chair justice man plant love temple show peace street war

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
I do demand
If you submit you to the people’s voices,
Allow their officers, and are content
To suffer lawful censure for such faults
As shall be proved upon you.
nouns: people voice officer content censure fault

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Lo, citizens, he says he is content.
The warlike service he has done, consider. Think
Upon the wounds his body bears, which show
Like graves i’ th’ holy churchyard.
nouns: citizen content service wound body bear grave

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Consider further,
That when he speaks not like a citizen,
You find him like a soldier. Do not take
His rougher accents for malicious sounds,
But, as I say, such as become a soldier
Rather than envy you.
verbs: consider speak find take accent say become envy

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
What is the matter,
That, being passed for consul with full voice,
I am so dishonoured that the very hour
You take it off again?

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
We charge you that you have contrived to take
From Rome all seasoned office and to wind
Yourself into a power tyrannical,
For which you are a traitor to the people.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
The fires i’ th’ lowest hell fold in the people!
Call me their traitor? Thou injurious tribune!
Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths,
In thy hands clutched as many millions, in
Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say
“Thou liest” unto thee with a voice as free
As I do pray the gods.
nouns: fire people traitor tribune thine eye death hand million tongue number liest voice god
verbs: fold call sit clutch lie say pray

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Peace!
We need not put new matter to his charge.
What you have seen him do and heard him speak,
Beating your officers, cursing yourselves,
Opposing laws with strokes, and here defying
Those whose great power must try him—even this,
So criminal and in such capital kind,
Deserves th’ extremest death.
nouns: matter charge officer yourself law stroke power capital kind death
verbs: need put see hear speak beat curse oppose defy try deserve th

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I’ll know no further.
Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death,
Vagabond exile, flaying, pent to linger
But with a grain a day, I would not buy
Their mercy at the price of one fair word,
Nor check my courage for what they can give,
To have’t with saying “Good morrow.”
nouns: death exile flaying grain day mercy price word courage morrow
verbs: know let pronounce pen linger buy check give have’t say

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
For that he has,
As much as in him lies, from time to time
Envied against the people, seeking means
To pluck away their power, as now at last
Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence
Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers
That do distribute it, in the name o’ th’ people
And in the power of us the Tribunes, we,
Even from this instant, banish him our city
In peril of precipitation
From off the rock Tarpeian, never more
To enter our Rome gates. I’ th’ people’s name,
I say it shall be so.
nouns: sicinius time time people power stroke presence justice minister name th people power instant city peril precipitation rock gate th people name
verbs: lie envy seek mean pluck give distribute banish enter say

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Hear me, my masters and my common friends—

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
He’s sentenced. No more hearing.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Let me speak.
I have been consul and can show for Rome
Her enemies’ marks upon me. I do love
My country’s good with a respect more tender,
More holy and profound, than mine own life,
My dear wife’s estimate, her womb’s increase,
And treasure of my loins. Then if I would
Speak that—
nouns: consul enemy mark country respect life wife estimate womb increase treasure loin
adjectives: good tender holy profound own dear

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
There’s no more to be said, but he is banished
As enemy to the people and his country.
It shall be so.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
You common cry of curs, whose breath I hate
As reek o’ th’ rotten fens, whose loves I prize
As the dead carcasses of unburied men
That do corrupt my air, I banish you!
And here remain with your uncertainty;
Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts;
Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes,
Fan you into despair! Have the power still
To banish your defenders, till at length
Your ignorance—which finds not till it feels,
Making but reservation of yourselves,
Still your own foes—deliver you,
As most abated captives to some nation
That won you without blows! Despising
For you the city, thus I turn my back.
There is a world elsewhere.
nouns: cry cur breath reek th fen carcass man air uncertainty rumour heart enemy plume despair power defender length ignorance reservation yourself foe captive nation blow city back world
adjectives: common rotten dead unburied corrupt feeble own abated
verbs: hate love prize banish remain let shake nod banish find feel make deliver win despise turn

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Go see him out at gates, and follow him,
As he hath followed you, with all despite.
Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard
Attend us through the city.
verbs: go see follow hath follow give let attend

title: coriolanus
text:
ALL PLEBEIANS.
Come, come, let’s see him out at gates! Come!
The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.
verbs: come come let see come preserve come

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Come, leave your tears. A brief farewell. The beast
With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother,
Where is your ancient courage? You were used
To say extremities was the trier of spirits;
That common chances common men could bear;
That when the sea was calm, all boats alike
Showed mastership in floating; fortune’s blows
When most struck home, being gentle wounded craves
A noble cunning. You were used to load me
With precepts that would make invincible
The heart that conned them.
nouns: tear farewell beast head mother courage extremity trier spirit chance man sea boat mastership fortune crave cunning precept heart
adjectives: brief many ancient common common calm gentle wounded noble invincible
verbs: come leave butts use say bear show float blow strike use load make con

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
What, what, what!
I shall be loved when I am lacked. Nay, mother,
Resume that spirit when you were wont to say
If you had been the wife of Hercules,
Six of his labours you’d have done and saved
Your husband so much sweat.—Cominius,
Droop not. Adieu.—Farewell, my wife, my mother.
I’ll do well yet.—Thou old and true Menenius,
Thy tears are salter than a younger man’s
And venomous to thine eyes.—My sometime general,
I have seen thee stern, and thou hast oft beheld
Heart-hard’ning spectacles. Tell these sad women
’Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes
As ’tis to laugh at ’em.—My mother, you wot well
My hazards still have been your solace, and—
Believe’t not lightly—though I go alone,
Like to a lonely dragon that his fen
Makes feared and talked of more than seen, your son
Will or exceed the common or be caught
With cautelous baits and practice.
nouns: mother spirit wife labour husband wife mother tear man ’s heart spectacle woman stroke mother hazard solace dragon fen son bait practice
adjectives: much old true salter young venomous eyes.—my sometime general stern sad fond inevitable lonely more common cautelous
verbs: love lack resume say do save thine see hard’ne tell ti wail tis laugh wot go make fear talk see exceed catch

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
My first son,
Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile. Determine on some course
More than a wild exposture to each chance
That starts i’ th’ way before thee.
nouns: son whither wilt thou cominius course exposture chance th way

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
I’ll follow thee a month, devise with thee
Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us
And we of thee; so if the time thrust forth
A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send
O’er the vast world to seek a single man
And lose advantage, which doth ever cool
I’ th’ absence of the needer.
nouns: month shalt rest mayst time cause repeal world man advantage th absence needer
verbs: follow devise hear thrust send o’er seek lose

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Fare ye well.
Thou hast years upon thee, and thou art too full
Of the wars’ surfeits to go rove with one
That’s yet unbruised. Bring me but out at gate.—
Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and
My friends of noble touch. When I am forth,
Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come.
While I remain above the ground, you shall
Hear from me still, and never of me aught
But what is like me formerly.
nouns: ye hast year art war surfeit rove gate wife mother friend touch farewell ground aught
adjectives: thou full unbruised sweet dear noble
verbs: fare go ’ bring come bid smile pray come remain hear

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
That’s worthily
As any ear can hear. Come, let’s not weep.
If I could shake off but one seven years
From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
I’d with thee every foot.
nouns: ear year arm leg god foot

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Bid them home.
Say their great enemy is gone, and they
Stand in their ancient strength.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
They say she’s mad.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
O, you’re well met. The hoarded plague o’ th’ gods
Requite your love!

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Ay, fool, is that a shame? Note but this, fool.
Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship
To banish him that struck more blows for Rome
Than thou hast spoken words?
nouns: fool shame note fool man father foxship blow word

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
More noble blows than ever thou wise words,
And for Rome’s good. I’ll tell thee what—yet go.
Nay, but thou shalt stay too. I would my son
Were in Arabia and thy tribe before him,
His good sword in his hand.
nouns: VOLUMNIA blow word good shalt son tribe sword hand

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Bastards and all.
Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
I would he had continued to his country
As he began, and not unknit himself
The noble knot he made.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Now, pray, sir, get you gone.
You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this:
As far as doth the Capitol exceed
The meanest house in Rome, so far my son—
This lady’s husband here, this, do you see?—
Whom you have banished, does exceed you all.
verbs: get go do go hear exceed see banish exceed

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Take my prayers with you.
I would the gods had nothing else to do
But to confirm my curses. Could I meet ’em
But once a day, it would unclog my heart
Of what lies heavy to’t.
nouns: prayer god curse day heart to’t

title: coriolanus
text:
ROMAN.
I know you well, sir, and you know me. Your name I think is Adrian.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLSCE.
You had more beard when I last saw you, but your favour is well
approved by your tongue. What’s the news in Rome? I have a note from
the Volscian state to find you out there. You have well saved me a
day’s journey.
nouns: favour tongue news note state day journey

title: coriolanus
text:
ROMAN.
There hath been in Rome strange insurrections, the people against the
senators, patricians, and nobles.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLSCE.
Hath been? Is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so. They are in a
most warlike preparation and hope to come upon them in the heat of
their division.

title: coriolanus
text:
ROMAN.
The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing would make it flame
again; for the nobles receive so to heart the banishment of that worthy
Coriolanus that they are in a ripe aptness to take all power from the
people and to pluck from them their tribunes for ever. This lies
glowing, I can tell you, and is almost mature for the violent breaking
out.
nouns: blaze thing flame noble banishment aptness power people tribune breaking
adjectives: main past small worthy ripe mature violent
verbs: make receive heart take pluck lie glow tell

title: coriolanus
text:
ROMAN.
The day serves well for them now. I have heard it said the fittest time
to corrupt a man’s wife is when she’s fallen out with her husband. Your
noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his great opposer
Coriolanus being now in no request of his country.
nouns: day time man wife husband war opposer request country
verbs: serve hear say corrupt ’ fall appear

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLSCE.
He cannot choose. I am most fortunate thus accidentally to encounter
you. You have ended my business, and I will merrily accompany you home.

title: coriolanus
text:
ROMAN.
I shall between this and supper tell you most strange things from Rome,
all tending to the good of their adversaries. Have you an army ready,
say you?

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLSCE.
A most royal one. The centurions and their charges, distinctly
billeted, already in th’ entertainment, and to be on foot at an hour’s
warning.
nouns: one centurion charge th entertainment foot hour warning

title: coriolanus
text:
ROMAN.
I am joyful to hear of their readiness and am the man, I think, that
shall set them in present action. So, sir, heartily well met, and most
glad of your company.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLSCE.
You take my part from me, sir. I have the most cause to be glad of
yours.

title: coriolanus
text: Enter Coriolanus in mean apparel, disguised and muffled.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
A goodly city is this Antium. City,
’Tis I that made thy widows. Many an heir
Of these fair edifices ’fore my wars
Have I heard groan and drop. Then know me not,
Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones
In puny battle slay me.
nouns: city widow heir edifice war groan drop wife spit boy stone battle
verbs: tis make fore hear know slay

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Direct me, if it be your will,
Where great Aufidius lies. Is he in Antium?

title: coriolanus
text:
O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn,
Whose double bosoms seems to wear one heart,
Whose hours, whose bed, whose meal and exercise
Are still together, who twin, as ’twere, in love
Unseparable, shall within this hour,
On a dissension of a doit, break out
To bitterest enmity; so fellest foes,
Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep
To take the one the other, by some chance,
Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends
And interjoin their issues. So with me:
My birthplace hate I, and my love’s upon
This enemy town. I’ll enter. If he slay me,
He does fair justice; if he give me way,
I’ll do his country service.
nouns: world slippery turn friend bosom heart hour bed meal exercise love hour dissension enmity foe passion plot sleep one chance egg friend issue birthplace love enemy town justice way country service
adjectives: double doit bitter fellest other worth dear fair
verbs: swear seem wear twin twere break break take trick grow interjoin hate ’ enter slay give

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
Wine, wine, wine! What service is here? I think our fellows are asleep.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Where’s Cotus? My master calls for him. Cotus!

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
A goodly house. The feast smells well, but I
Appear not like a guest.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I have deserved no better entertainment
In being Coriolanus.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Whence are you, sir?—Has the porter his eyes in his head, that he gives
entrance to such companions?—Pray, get you out.
nouns: servingman porter eye head entrance companions?—pray

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Away? Get you away.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Now th’ art troublesome.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Are you so brave? I’ll have you talked with anon.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
A strange one as ever I looked on. I cannot get him out o’ th’ house.
Prithee call my master to him.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid the house.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other station. Here’s no place
for you. Pray you, avoid. Come.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
What, you will not?—Prithee, tell my master what a strange guest he has
here.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Here, sir. I’d have beaten him like a dog, but for disturbing the lords
within.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
[_Removing his muffler_.] If, Tullus,
Not yet thou know’st me, and, seeing me, dost not
Think me for the man I am, necessity
Commands me name myself.
verbs: remove see dost think command name

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Say, what’s thy name?
Thou has a grim appearance, and thy face
Bears a command in’t. Though thy tackle’s torn,
Thou show’st a noble vessel. What’s thy name?
nouns: aufidiu name appearance face command in’t tackle vessel name

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Prepare thy brow to frown. Know’st thou me yet?

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
My name is Caius Martius, who hath done
To thee particularly and to all the Volsces
Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may
My surname Coriolanus. The painful service,
The extreme dangers, and the drops of blood
Shed for my thankless country are requited
But with that surname, a good memory
And witness of the malice and displeasure
Which thou shouldst bear me. Only that name remains.
The cruelty and envy of the people,
Permitted by our dastard nobles, who
Have all forsook me, hath devoured the rest,
And suffered me by th’ voice of slaves to be
Whooped out of Rome. Now this extremity
Hath brought me to thy hearth, not out of hope—
Mistake me not—to save my life; for if
I had feared death, of all the men i’ th’ world
I would have ’voided thee, but in mere spite,
To be full quit of those my banishers,
Stand I before thee here. Then if thou hast
A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge
Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims
Of shame seen through thy country, speed thee straight
And make my misery serve thy turn. So use it
That my revengeful services may prove
As benefits to thee, for I will fight
Against my cankered country with the spleen
Of all the under fiends. But if so be
Thou dar’st not this, and that to prove more fortunes
Thou ’rt tired, then, in a word, I also am
Longer to live most weary, and present
My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice,
Which not to cut would show thee but a fool,
Since I have ever followed thee with hate,
Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country’s breast,
And cannot live but to thy shame, unless
It be to do thee service.
nouns: name hurt witness surname coriolanus service danger drop blood country surname memory witness malice displeasure shouldst name cruelty envy people dastard noble rest th voice slave extremity hope life death man th world spite quit banisher heart wreak revenge wrong maim shame country misery turn service benefit country spleen fiend fortune word throat malice fool hate tun blood country breast shame thee service
adjectives: great painful extreme thankless good i mere full wilt particular straight revengeful more tired weary ancient
verbs: hath do mischief thereto requite bear remain permit forsook devour suffer whoop bring mistake save fear void stand own stop see speed make serve use prove fight canker prove live present cut show follow draw live be

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
O Martius, Martius,
Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart
A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter
Should from yond cloud speak divine things
And say ’tis true, I’d not believe them more
Than thee, all-noble Martius. Let me twine
Mine arms about that body, whereagainst
My grained ash an hundred times hath broke
And scarred the moon with splinters. Here I clip
The anvil of my sword and do contest
As hotly and as nobly with thy love
As ever in ambitious strength I did
Contend against thy valour. Know thou first,
I loved the maid I married; never man
Sighed truer breath. But that I see thee here,
Thou noble thing, more dances my rapt heart
Than when I first my wedded mistress saw
Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars, I tell thee
We have a power on foot, and I had purpose
Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn
Or lose mine arm for’t. Thou hast beat me out
Twelve several times, and I have nightly since
Dreamt of encounters ’twixt thyself and me;
We have been down together in my sleep,
Unbuckling helms, fisting each other’s throat,
And waked half dead with nothing. Worthy Martius,
Had we no other quarrel else to Rome but that
Thou art thence banished, we would muster all
From twelve to seventy and, pouring war
Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome,
Like a bold flood o’erbear ’t. O, come, go in,
And take our friendly senators by th’ hands,
Who now are here, taking their leaves of me,
Who am prepared against your territories,
Though not for Rome itself.
nouns: aufidiu word heart root envy thing tis arm body whereagainst ash time hath moon splinter anvil sword love strength valour maid man truer breath thing rapt heart mistress saw threshold power foot purpose target brawn arm for’t hast time encounter sleep helm throat quarrel art thence war bowel flood senator th hand leave territory
adjectives: ancient divine true noble grained ambitious first noble more thou more mine several other dead other thou ungrateful bold friendly
verbs: speak weed speak say believe let twine break scar clip contest contend know love marry sigh see dance wed tell hew lose beat twixt unbuckle fiste wake banish muster pour come go take take prepare

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have
The leading of thine own revenges, take
Th’ one half of my commission and set down—
As best thou art experienced, since thou know’st
Thy country’s strength and weakness—thine own ways,
Whether to knock against the gates of Rome,
Or rudely visit them in parts remote
To fright them ere destroy. But come in.
Let me commend thee first to those that shall
Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!
And more a friend than e’er an enemy—
Yet, Martius, that was much. Your hand. Most welcome!
nouns: aufidiu sir wilt leading revenge half commission art country strength weakness way gate part destroy desire welcome friend enemy hand
adjectives: absolute thou thine own good thou thine own yea much Most
verbs: take set experience knock visit remote fright come let commend say e’er

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
Here’s a strange alteration!

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with a cudgel, and yet
my mind gave me his clothes made a false report of him.
nouns: servingman hand cudgel mind clothe report

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in him. He had, sir, a
kind of face, methought—I cannot tell how to term it.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
So did I, I’ll be sworn. He is simply the rarest man i’ th’ world.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
I think he is. But a greater soldier than he you wot one.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
Nay, it’s no matter for that.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
Nay, not so neither. But I take him to be the greater soldier.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that. For the defence of a
town our general is excellent.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST and SECOND SERVINGMAN.
What, what, what? Let’s partake.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
I do not say “thwack our general,” but he was always good enough for
him.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Come, we are fellows and friends. He was ever too hard for him; I have
heard him say so himself.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth on’t, before
Corioles; he scotched him and notched him like a carbonado.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
An he had been cannibally given, he might have boiled and eaten him
too.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
Why, he is so made on here within as if he were son and heir to Mars;
set at upper end o’ th’ table; no question asked him by any of the
senators but they stand bald before him. Our general himself makes a
mistress of him, sanctifies himself with’s hand, and turns up the white
o’ th’ eye to his discourse. But the bottom of the news is, our general
is cut i’ th’ middle and but one half of what he was yesterday, for the
other has half, by the entreaty and grant of the whole table. He’ll go,
he says, and sowl the porter of Rome gates by th’ ears. He will mow all
down before him and leave his passage polled.
nouns: son heir end o th table question senator general mistress hand th eye discourse bottom news th middle half yesterday half entreaty grant table porter gate th ear passage
adjectives: upper bald white general other whole
verbs: make set ask stand make sanctify turn cut go say sowl mow leave poll

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
And he’s as like to do’t as any man I can imagine.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
Do’t? He will do’t! For look you, sir, he has as many friends as
enemies, which friends, sir, as it were, durst not, look you, sir, show
themselves, as we term it, his friends whilest he’s in directitude.
nouns: friend enemy friend durst sir friend

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
Why then, we shall have a stirring world again. This peace is nothing
but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers.
nouns: servingman world peace iron increase tailor ballad maker

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
Let me have war, say I. It exceeds peace as far as day does night. It’s
sprightly walking, audible, and full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy,
lethargy; mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more bastard
children than war’s a destroyer of men.
nouns: war peace day night vent peace lethargy getter child war destroyer man
adjectives: first audible full apoplexy deaf sleepy insensible more bastard

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND SERVINGMAN.
’Tis so, and as war in some sort, may be said to be a ravisher, so it
cannot be denied but peace is a great maker of cuckolds.
nouns: servingman war sort ravisher peace maker cuckold

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST SERVINGMAN.
Ay, and it makes men hate one another.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD SERVINGMAN.
Reason: because they then less need one another. The wars for my money!
I hope to see Romans as cheap as Volscians. They are rising; they are
rising.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
We hear not of him, neither need we fear him.
His remedies are tame—the present peace,
And quietness of the people, which before
Were in wild hurry. Here do we make his friends
Blush that the world goes well, who rather had,
Though they themselves did suffer by’t, behold
Dissentious numbers pest’ring streets than see
Our tradesmen singing in their shops and going
About their functions friendly.
nouns: sicinius remedy peace quietness people hurry friend world number street tradesman shop function
adjectives: tame present wild behold dissentious friendly
verbs: hear need fear make go suffer pest’re see singe go

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
We stood to’t in good time.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Your Coriolanus is not much missed
But with his friends. The commonwealth doth stand,
And so would do were he more angry at it.
nouns: sicinius coriolanus friend commonwealth doth stand

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Farewell, kind neighbours. We wished Coriolanus
Had loved you as we did.

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
This is a happier and more comely time
Than when these fellows ran about the streets
Crying confusion.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Caius Martius was
A worthy officer i’ th’ war, but insolent,
O’ercome with pride, ambitious, past all thinking
Self-loving.
nouns: officer i th war insolent pride self

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
And affecting one sole throne, without assistance.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
The gods have well prevented it, and Rome
Sits safe and still without him.

title: coriolanus
text:
AEDILE.
Worthy tribunes,
There is a slave, whom we have put in prison,
Reports the Volsces with two several powers
Are entered in the Roman territories,
And with the deepest malice of the war
Destroy what lies before ’em.
nouns: tribune slave prison power territory malice war

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Cannot be?
We have record that very well it can,
And three examples of the like hath been
Within my age. But reason with the fellow
Before you punish him, where he heard this,
Lest you shall chance to whip your information
And beat the messenger who bids beware
Of what is to be dreaded.
nouns: record example hath age reason fellow information messenger
verbs: punish hear chance whip beat bid beware dread

title: coriolanus
text:
MESSENGER.
The nobles in great earnestness are going
All to the Senate House. Some news is coming
That turns their countenances.

title: coriolanus
text:
MESSENGER.
Yes, worthy sir,
The slave’s report is seconded, and more,
More fearful, is delivered.

title: coriolanus
text:
MESSENGER.
It is spoke freely out of many mouths—
How probable I do not know—that Martius,
Joined with Aufidius, leads a power ’gainst Rome
And vows revenge as spacious as between
The young’st and oldest thing.

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
Raised only that the weaker sort may wish
Good Martius home again.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND MESSENGER.
You are sent for to the Senate.
A fearful army, led by Caius Martius
Associated with Aufidius, rages
Upon our territories, and have already
O’erborne their way, consumed with fire and took
What lay before them.
nouns: messenger army rage territory way fire

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
O, you have made good work!

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
You have holp to ravish your own daughters and
To melt the city leads upon your pates,
To see your wives dishonoured to your noses—
nouns: holp daughter city pate wife nose

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Pray now, your news?—
You have made fair work, I fear me.—Pray, your news?
If Martius should be joined with Volscians—

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
If?
He is their god; he leads them like a thing
Made by some other deity than Nature,
That shapes man better; and they follow him
Against us brats with no less confidence
Than boys pursuing summer butterflies
Or butchers killing flies.
nouns: thing deity man brat confidence boy summer butterfly butcher fly
verbs: lead make shape follow pursue kill

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
You have made good work,
You and your apron-men, you that stood so much
Upon the voice of occupation and
The breath of garlic eaters!
nouns: work apron man voice occupation breath eater

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
As Hercules did shake down mellow fruit.
You have made fair work.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Ay, and you’ll look pale
Before you find it other. All the regions
Do smilingly revolt, and who resists
Are mocked for valiant ignorance
And perish constant fools. Who is’t can blame him?
Your enemies and his find something in him.
verbs: look find revolt resist mock blame find

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Who shall ask it?
The Tribunes cannot do’t for shame; the people
Deserve such pity of him as the wolf
Does of the shepherds. For his best friends, if they
Should say “Be good to Rome,” they charged him even
As those should do that had deserved his hate
And therein showed like enemies.
nouns: shame people pity wolf shepherd friend hate enemy
verbs: ask deserve say charge deserve show

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
’Tis true.
If he were putting to my house the brand
That should consume it, I have not the face
To say “Beseech you, cease.”—You have made fair hands,
You and your crafts! You have crafted fair!
nouns: house brand face cease hand craft
verbs: ti put consume say make craft

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
You have brought
A trembling upon Rome such as was never
S’ incapable of help.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
But I fear
They’ll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius,
The second name of men, obeys his points
As if he were his officer. Desperation
Is all the policy, strength, and defence
That Rome can make against them.
nouns: name man point officer desperation policy strength defence

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Here comes the clusters.—
And is Aufidius with him? You are they
That made the air unwholesome when you cast
Your stinking, greasy caps in hooting at
Coriolanus’ exile. Now he’s coming,
And not a hair upon a soldier’s head
Which will not prove a whip. As many coxcombs
As you threw caps up will he tumble down
And pay you for your voices. ’Tis no matter.
If he could burn us all into one coal
We have deserved it.
nouns: cluster air unwholesome stinking greasy cap exile hair soldier head whip coxcomb cap voice matter coal
verbs: come make cast hoot ’ come prove throw tumble pay burn deserve

title: coriolanus
text:
ALL CITIZENS.
Faith, we hear fearful news.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
For mine own part,
When I said banish him, I said ’twas pity.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CITIZEN.
And so did I. And, to say the truth, so did very many of us. That we
did we did for the best; and though we willingly consented to his
banishment, yet it was against our will.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
You have made good work, you and your cry!—
Shall’s to the Capitol?

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Go, masters, get you home. Be not dismayed.
These are a side that would be glad to have
This true which they so seem to fear. Go home,
And show no sign of fear.
verbs: go get dismay seem fear go show

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CITIZEN.
The gods be good to us! Come, masters, let’s home. I ever said we were
i’ th’ wrong when we banished him.

title: coriolanus
text:
LIEUTENANT.
I do not know what witchcraft’s in him, but
Your soldiers use him as the grace ’fore meat,
Their talk at table, and their thanks at end;
And you are dark’ned in this action, sir,
Even by your own.
nouns: LIEUTENANT witchcraft soldier grace fore meat talk table thank end action

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
I cannot help it now,
Unless by using means I lame the foot
Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier,
Even to my person, than I thought he would
When first I did embrace him. Yet his nature
In that’s no changeling, and I must excuse
What cannot be amended.
nouns: aufidiu mean foot design person nature
verbs: help use lame bear think embrace excuse amend

title: coriolanus
text:
LIEUTENANT.
Yet I wish, sir—
I mean for your particular—you had not
Joined in commission with him, but either
Had borne the action of yourself or else
To him had left it solely.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
I understand thee well, and be thou sure,
When he shall come to his account, he knows not
What I can urge against him, although it seems,
And so he thinks and is no less apparent
To th’ vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly,
And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state,
Fights dragonlike, and does achieve as soon
As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone
That which shall break his neck or hazard mine
Whene’er we come to our account.
nouns: aufidiu account eye thing husbandry state fight sword neck hazard mine account
adjectives: sure apparent vulgar good volscian dragonlike undone
verbs: understand come know urge seem think th bear show achieve draw hath leave break come

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
All places yield to him ere he sits down,
And the nobility of Rome are his;
The Senators and Patricians love him too.
The Tribunes are no soldiers, and their people
Will be as rash in the repeal as hasty
To expel him thence. I think he’ll be to Rome
As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it
By sovereignty of nature. First, he was
A noble servant to them, but he could not
Carry his honours even. Whether ’twas pride,
Which out of daily fortune ever taints
The happy man; whether defect of judgment,
To fail in the disposing of those chances
Which he was lord of; or whether nature,
Not to be other than one thing, not moving
From th’ casque to th’ cushion, but commanding peace
Even with the same austerity and garb
As he controlled the war; but one of these—
As he hath spices of them all—not all,
For I dare so far free him—made him feared,
So hated, and so banished. But he has a merit
To choke it in the utt’rance. So our virtues
Lie in th’ interpretation of the time,
And power, unto itself most commendable,
Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair
T’ extol what it hath done.
One fire drives out one fire, one nail one nail;
Rights by rights falter; strengths by strengths do fail.
Come, let’s away. When, Caius, Rome is thine,
Thou art poor’st of all; then shortly art thou mine.
nouns: aufidiu place nobility soldier people repeal thence osprey fish sovereignty nature servant honour pride fortune taint man defect judgment disposing chance nature thing th casque cushion peace austerity garb war spice merit utt’rance virtue lie th interpretation time power tomb chair fire fire nail nail right right falter strength strength thine art art thou mine
adjectives: rash hasty noble daily happy other same free hated commendable evident
verbs: yield sit love expel think take carry twa fail move th command control hath dare make fear banish choke extol hath do drive fail come let

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
No, I’ll not go. You hear what he hath said
Which was sometime his general, who loved him
In a most dear particular. He called me father,
But what o’ that? Go you that banished him;
A mile before his tent, fall down, and knee
The way into his mercy. Nay, if he coyed
To hear Cominius speak, I’ll keep at home.
nouns: general particular father o mile tent knee way mercy speak home
verbs: go hear hath say love call go banish fall coye hear keep

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
Yet one time he did call me by my name.
I urged our old acquaintance, and the drops
That we have bled together. “Coriolanus”
He would not answer to, forbade all names.
He was a kind of nothing, titleless,
Till he had forged himself a name i’ th’ fire
Of burning Rome.
nouns: time name acquaintance drop name kind titleless name th fire
verbs: call urge bleed answer forbid forge burn

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Why, so; you have made good work!
A pair of tribunes that have wracked Rome
To make coals cheap! A noble memory!

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
I minded him how royal ’twas to pardon
When it was less expected. He replied
It was a bare petition of a state
To one whom they had punished.
verbs: mind twa pardon expect reply punish

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
I offered to awaken his regard
For’s private friends. His answer to me was
He could not stay to pick them in a pile
Of noisome musty chaff. He said ’twas folly
For one poor grain or two to leave unburnt
And still to nose th’ offence.
nouns: regard friend answer pile noisome chaff folly grain nose th offence
verbs: offer awaken stay pick say twa leave

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
For one poor grain or two!
I am one of those! His mother, wife, his child,
And this brave fellow too, we are the grains;
You are the musty chaff, and you are smelt
Above the moon. We must be burnt for you.
nouns: grain mother wife child fellow grain chaff moon

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Nay, pray, be patient. If you refuse your aid
In this so-never-needed help, yet do not
Upbraid’s with our distress. But sure, if you
Would be your country’s pleader, your good tongue,
More than the instant army we can make,
Might stop our countryman.
nouns: aid help distress country pleader tongue army countryman

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Well, and say that Martius
Return me, as Cominius is returned, unheard,
What then? But as a discontented friend,
Grief-shot with his unkindness? Say’t be so?

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Yet your good will
Must have that thanks from Rome after the measure
As you intended well.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I’ll undertake’t.
I think he’ll hear me. Yet to bite his lip
And hum at good Cominius much unhearts me.
He was not taken well; he had not dined.
The veins unfilled, our blood is cold, and then
We pout upon the morning, are unapt
To give or to forgive; but when we have stuffed
These pipes and these conveyances of our blood
With wine and feeding, we have suppler souls
Than in our priestlike fasts. Therefore I’ll watch him
Till he be dieted to my request,
And then I’ll set upon him.
nouns: lip vein blood morning pipe conveyance blood wine feeding suppler soul priestlike fast request
verbs: think hear bite hum unheart take dine pout give forgive stuff watch diet set

title: coriolanus
text:
BRUTUS.
You know the very road into his kindness
And cannot lose your way.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Good faith, I’ll prove him,
Speed how it will. I shall ere long have knowledge
Of my success.

title: coriolanus
text:
COMINIUS.
I tell you, he does sit in gold, his eye
Red as ’twould burn Rome; and his injury
The jailer to his pity. I kneeled before him;
’Twas very faintly he said “Rise”; dismissed me
Thus with his speechless hand. What he would do
He sent in writing after me; what he
Would not, bound with an oath to yield to his
Conditions. So that all hope is vain
Unless his noble mother and his wife,
Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him
For mercy to his country. Therefore let’s hence
And with our fair entreaties haste them on.
nouns: gold eye injury jailer pity hand writing oath condition hope mother wife mercy country entreaty
verbs: tell sit burn kneel twa say dismiss send bind yield hear mean solicit let haste

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Good my friends,
If you have heard your general talk of Rome
And of his friends there, it is lots to blanks
My name hath touched your ears. It is Menenius.
nouns: friend talk friend lot blank name hath ear

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST WATCH.
Be it so; go back. The virtue of your name
Is not here passable.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I tell thee, fellow,
Thy general is my lover. I have been
The book of his good acts, whence men have read
His fame unparalleled happily amplified;
For I have ever verified my friends—
Of whom he’s chief—with all the size that verity
Would without lapsing suffer. Nay, sometimes,
Like to a bowl upon a subtle ground,
I have tumbled past the throw, and in his praise
Have almost stamped the leasing. Therefore, fellow,
I must have leave to pass.
nouns: lover book act man fame friend chief size verity lapsing suffer bowl ground throw praise leasing fellow
verbs: tell read unparallele amplify verify ’ tumble stamp leave pass

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST WATCH.
Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf as you have
uttered words in your own, you should not pass here, no, though it were
as virtuous to lie as to live chastely. Therefore, go back.
verbs: tell utter pass lie live go

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius, always factionary on the
party of your general.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND WATCH.
Howsoever you have been his liar, as you say you have, I am one that,
telling true under him, must say you cannot pass. Therefore go back.

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST WATCH.
Then you should hate Rome as he does. Can you, when you have pushed out
your gates the very defender of them, and, in a violent popular
ignorance given your enemy your shield, think to front his revenges
with the easy groans of old women, the virginal palms of your
daughters, or with the palsied intercession of such a decayed dotant as
you seem to be? Can you think to blow out the intended fire your city
is ready to flame in with such weak breath as this? No, you are
deceived. Therefore back to Rome and prepare for your execution. You
are condemned. Our general has sworn you out of reprieve and pardon.
nouns: gate defender ignorance enemy shield revenge groan woman palm daughter intercession dotant fire city breath execution general reprieve pardon
adjectives: very violent popular easy old virginal palsied decayed ready such weak
verbs: hate push give think front seem think blow intend flame deceive prepare condemn swear

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST WATCH.
My general cares not for you. Back, I say, go, lest I let forth your
half pint of blood. Back! That’s the utmost of your having. Back!

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
Now, you companion, I’ll say an errand for you. You shall know now that
I am in estimation; you shall perceive that a Jack guardant cannot
office me from my son Coriolanus. Guess but by my entertainment with
him if thou stand’st not i’ th’ state of hanging or of some death more
long in spectatorship and crueller in suffering; behold now presently,
and swoon for what’s to come upon thee. [_to Coriolanus_.] The glorious
gods sit in hourly synod about thy particular prosperity and love thee
no worse than thy old father Menenius does! O my son, my son! Thou art
preparing fire for us; look thee, here’s water to quench it. I was
hardly moved to come to thee; but being assured none but myself could
move thee, I have been blown out of your gates with sighs, and conjure
thee to pardon Rome and thy petitionary countrymen. The good gods
assuage thy wrath and turn the dregs of it upon this varlet here, this,
who, like a block, hath denied my access to thee.
nouns: companion errand estimation guardant son entertainment th state death spectatorship crueller suffering god prosperity father son son art fire water none thee gate sigh conjure countryman god wrath dreg varlet block hath access
adjectives: thou glorious hourly particular bad old thou petitionary good
verbs: say know perceive office guess hang behold swoon ’ come sit love prepare look ’ quench move come assure move blow pardon assuage turn deny

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Wife, mother, child, I know not. My affairs
Are servanted to others. Though I owe
My revenge properly, my remission lies
In Volscian breasts. That we have been familiar,
Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison rather
Than pity note how much. Therefore begone.
Mine ears against your suits are stronger than
Your gates against my force. Yet, for I loved thee,
Take this along; I writ it for thy sake,
nouns: mother child affair other revenge remission breast forgetfulness pity begone ear suit gate force thee sake
verbs: know servante owe lie poison note love take writ

title: coriolanus
text:
And would have sent it. Another word, Menenius,
I will not hear thee speak.—This man, Aufidius,
Was my beloved in Rome; yet thou behold’st.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
You keep a constant temper.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND WATCH.
’Tis a spell, you see, of much power. You know the way home again.

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I neither care for th’ world nor your general. For such things as you,
I can scarce think there’s any, you’re so slight. He that hath a will
to die by himself fears it not from another. Let your general do his
worst. For you, be that you are, long; and your misery increase with
your age! I say to you, as I was said to, away!
nouns: th world general thing will general misery age
verbs: care think ’ ’re hath die fear let increase say say

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST WATCH.
A noble fellow, I warrant him.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND WATCH.
The worthy fellow is our general. He is the rock, the oak not to be
wind-shaken.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
We will before the walls of Rome tomorrow
Set down our host. My partner in this action,
You must report to th’ Volscian lords how plainly
I have borne this business.
nouns: wall tomorrow host partner action business

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Only their ends
You have respected, stopped your ears against
The general suit of Rome; never admitted
A private whisper, no, not with such friends
That thought them sure of you.
nouns: aufidiu end ear suit whisper friend

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
This last old man,
Whom with cracked heart I have sent to Rome,
Loved me above the measure of a father,
Nay, godded me indeed. Their latest refuge
Was to send him, for whose old love I have—
Though I showed sourly to him—once more offered
The first conditions, which they did refuse
And cannot now accept, to grace him only
That thought he could do more. A very little
I have yielded to. Fresh embassies and suits,
Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter
Will I lend ear to.
nouns: man heart measure father refuge love condition embassy suit state friend ear
adjectives: last old late old first more little fresh private
verbs: crack send love godde send show offer refuse accept grace think yield lend

title: coriolanus
text:
Ha? What shout is this?
Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow
In the same time ’tis made? I will not.

title: coriolanus
text:
My wife comes foremost, then the honoured mold
Wherein this trunk was framed, and in her hand
The grandchild to her blood. But out, affection!
All bond and privilege of nature, break!
Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.
What is that curtsy worth? Or those doves’ eyes,
Which can make gods forsworn? I melt and am not
Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows,
As if Olympus to a molehill should
In supplication nod; and my young boy
Hath an aspect of intercession which
Great Nature cries “Deny not!” Let the Volsces
Plough Rome and harrow Italy, I’ll never
Be such a gosling to obey instinct, but stand
As if a man were author of himself,
And knew no other kin.
nouns: wife mold trunk hand grandchild blood affection bond privilege nature curtsy dove eye god earth other mother molehill supplication nod boy aspect intercession gosling instinct man author
adjectives: honoured virtuous obstinate worth strong young other
verbs: come frame break let make forswear melt bow cry let obey stand know

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Like a dull actor now,
I have forgot my part, and I am out,
Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh,
Forgive my tyranny, but do not say
For that, “Forgive our Romans.”

title: coriolanus
text:
O, a kiss
Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge!
Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss
I carried from thee, dear, and my true lip
Hath virgined it e’er since. You gods! I prate
And the most noble mother of the world
Leave unsaluted. Sink, my knee, i’ th’ earth;
nouns: kiss exile revenge queen lip e’er god mother world sink knee th earth
verbs: kiss carry virgine prate leave unsalute

title: coriolanus
text:
Of thy deep duty more impression show
Than that of common sons.

title: coriolanus
text:
Whilst with no softer cushion than the flint
I kneel before thee and unproperly
Show duty, as mistaken all this while
Between the child and parent.
nouns: cushion flint show duty while child parent

title: coriolanus
text:
Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach
Fillip the stars! Then let the mutinous winds
Strike the proud cedars ’gainst the fiery sun,
Murdering impossibility to make
What cannot be slight work.
nouns: pebble beach star wind cedar sun impossibility work

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
The noble sister of Publicola,
The moon of Rome, chaste as the icicle
That’s curdied by the frost from purest snow
And hangs on Dian’s temple!—Dear Valeria.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
This is a poor epitome of yours,
Which by th’ interpretation of full time
May show like all yourself.

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
The god of soldiers,
With the consent of supreme Jove, inform
Thy thoughts with nobleness, that thou mayst prove
To shame unvulnerable, and stick i’ th’ wars
Like a great seamark standing every flaw
And saving those that eye thee.
nouns: god soldier consent inform thought nobleness mayst th war seamark flaw eye thee

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
That’s my brave boy!

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I beseech you, peace;
Or, if you’d ask, remember this before:
The thing I have forsworn to grant may never
Be held by you denials. Do not bid me
Dismiss my soldiers or capitulate
Again with Rome’s mechanics. Tell me not
Wherein I seem unnatural; desire not
T’ allay my rages and revenges with
Your colder reasons.
nouns: peace thing denial soldier mechanic Wherein rage revenge reason
verbs: beseech ask remember forswear grant hold bid dismiss capitulate tell seem desire allay

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
O, no more, no more!
You have said you will not grant us anything;
For we have nothing else to ask but that
Which you deny already. Yet we will ask,
That if you fail in our request, the blame
May hang upon your hardness. Therefore hear us.
verbs: say grant ask deny ask fail hang hear

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark, for we’ll
Hear naught from Rome in private. Your request?

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment
And state of bodies would bewray what life
We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself
How more unfortunate than all living women
Are we come hither; since that thy sight, which should
Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance with comforts,
Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow,
Making the mother, wife, and child to see
The son, the husband, and the father tearing
His country’s bowels out. And to poor we
Thine enmity’s most capital. Thou barr’st us
Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort
That all but we enjoy. For how can we—
Alas, how can we—for our country pray,
Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory,
Whereto we are bound? Alack, or we must lose
The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person,
Our comfort in the country. We must find
An evident calamity, though we had
Our wish, which side should win, for either thou
Must as a foreign recreant be led
With manacles through our streets, or else
Triumphantly tread on thy country’s ruin
And bear the palm for having bravely shed
Thy wife and children’s blood. For myself, son,
I purpose not to wait on fortune till
These wars determine. If I cannot persuade thee
Rather to show a noble grace to both parts
Than seek the end of one, thou shalt no sooner
March to assault thy country than to tread—
Trust to’t, thou shalt not—on thy mother’s womb
That brought thee to this world.
nouns: raiment state body life exile woman sight eye joy heart comfort fear sorrow mother wife child son husband father country enmity capital prayer god comfort country pray victory country nurse person comfort country calamity wish side thou recreant manacle street tread country ruin palm wife child blood son fortune war grace part end thou shalt country mother womb world
adjectives: silent unfortunate poor most dear evident foreign noble
verbs: speak bewray lead think live come make flow dance constrain weep shake make see tear bowel enjoy bind bind lose find win lead bear have shed purpose wait determine persuade show seek assault tread bring

title: coriolanus
text:
YOUNG MARTIUS.
He shall not tread on me.
I’ll run away till I am bigger, but then I’ll fight.

title: coriolanus
text:
VOLUMNIA.
Nay, go not from us thus.
If it were so, that our request did tend
To save the Romans, thereby to destroy
The Volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us
As poisonous of your honour. No, our suit
Is that you reconcile them, while the Volsces
May say “This mercy we have showed,” the Romans
“This we received,” and each in either side
Give the all-hail to thee and cry, “Be blessed
For making up this peace!” Thou know’st, great son,
The end of war’s uncertain, but this certain,
That, if thou conquer Rome, the benefit
Which thou shalt thereby reap is such a name
Whose repetition will be dogged with curses,
Whose chronicle thus writ: “The man was noble,
But with his last attempt he wiped it out;
Destroyed his country, and his name remains
To th’ ensuing age abhorred.” Speak to me, son.
Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour
To imitate the graces of the gods,
To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o’ th’ air
And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt
That should but rive an oak. Why dost not speak?
Think’st thou it honourable for a noble man
Still to remember wrongs?—Daughter, speak you.
He cares not for your weeping.—Speak thou, boy.
Perhaps thy childishness will move him more
Than can our reasons.—There’s no man in the world
More bound to’s mother, yet here he lets me prate
Like one i’ th’ stocks. Thou hast never in thy life
Showed thy dear mother any courtesy
When she, poor hen, fond of no second brood,
Has clucked thee to the wars and safely home,
Loaden with honour. Say my request’s unjust
And spurn me back; but if it be not so,
Thou art not honest, and the gods will plague thee
That thou restrain’st from me the duty which
To a mother’s part belongs.—He turns away.—
Down, ladies! Let us shame him with our knees.
To his surname Coriolanus ’longs more pride
Than pity to our prayers. Down! An end.
nouns: request honour suit mercy side hail peace son end war benefit thou shalt name repetition curse chronicle man attempt country name age son hast strain honour grace god thunder cheek o th air sulphur bolt oak man weeping.—speak thou boy reasons.—there man world mother i th stock hast life mother courtesy brood war honour request art god duty mother part belongs.—he lady knee surname long pride pity prayer end
adjectives: poisonous great uncertain certain noble last fine wide honourable noble childishness bound dear poor fond second unjust honest thou more
verbs: go tend save destroy serve condemn reconcile say show receive give cry bless make reap dog writ wipe destroy remain th ensue abhor speak affect imitate tear charge rive speak remember speak care move ’s let prate show cluck say spurn be plague turn let shame

title: coriolanus
text:
This is the last. So we will home to Rome
And die among our neighbours.—Nay, behold’s.
This boy that cannot tell what he would have,
But kneels and holds up hands for fellowship,
Does reason our petition with more strength
Than thou hast to deny’t.—Come, let us go.
nouns: neighbours.—Nay boy kneel hand fellowship petition strength thou hast
verbs: home die tell hold reason deny’t.—come let go

title: coriolanus
text:
This fellow had a Volscian to his mother,
His wife is in Corioles, and his child
Like him by chance.—Yet give us our dispatch.
I am hushed until our city be afire,
And then I’ll speak a little.
nouns: fellow mother wife child chance.—yet dispatch city

title: coriolanus
text: [_He holds her by the hand, silent._]

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
O mother, mother!
What have you done? Behold, the heavens do ope,
The gods look down, and this unnatural scene
They laugh at. O my mother, mother, O!
You have won a happy victory to Rome,
But, for your son—believe it, O, believe it!—
Most dangerously you have with him prevailed,
If not most mortal to him. But let it come.—
Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars,
I’ll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius,
Were you in my stead, would you have heard
A mother less? Or granted less, Aufidius?
nouns: mother mother heaven ope god scene mother mother victory son war peace stead mother
adjectives: unnatural happy mortal true convenient good less less
verbs: do look laugh win believe believe prevail let come make frame hear grant

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
I dare be sworn you were.
And, sir, it is no little thing to make
Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir,
What peace you’ll make, advise me. For my part,
I’ll not to Rome, I’ll back with you; and pray you,
Stand to me in this cause.—O mother!—Wife!
nouns: sir thing eye compassion peace part mother!—wife
verbs: dare swear make sweat make advise pray stand

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
[_Aside_.] I am glad thou hast set thy mercy and thy honour
At difference in thee. Out of that I’ll work
Myself a former fortune.
nouns: aufidiu mercy honour difference thee fortune

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
[_To the Women_.] Ay, by and by;
But we’ll drink together, and you shall bear
A better witness back than words, which we,
On like conditions, will have countersealed.
Come, enter with us. Ladies, you deserve
To have a temple built you. All the swords
In Italy, and her confederate arms,
Could not have made this peace.
nouns: witness word condition lady temple sword arm peace
verbs: drink bear counterseale come enter deserve build make

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
If it be possible for you to displace it with your little finger, there
is some hope the ladies of Rome, especially his mother, may prevail
with him. But I say there is no hope in’t. Our throats are sentenced
and stay upon execution.
nouns: finger hope lady mother hope throat execution
verbs: be displace prevail say sentence stay

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Is’t possible that so short a time can alter the condition of a man?

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
There is differency between a grub and a butterfly, yet your butterfly
was a grub. This Martius is grown from man to dragon. He has wings;
he’s more than a creeping thing.
nouns: differency grub butterfly butterfly grub man dragon wing thing

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
So did he me; and he no more remembers his mother now than an
eight-year-old horse. The tartness of his face sours ripe grapes. When
he walks, he moves like an engine, and the ground shrinks before his
treading. He is able to pierce a corslet with his eye, talks like a
knell, and his hum is a battery. He sits in his state as a thing made
for Alexander. What he bids be done is finished with his bidding. He
wants nothing of a god but eternity and a heaven to throne in.
nouns: mother year horse tartness face grape engine ground treading corslet eye knell hum battery state thing bidding eternity heaven
verbs: remember sour walk move shrink pierce talk sit make bid do finish want throne

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
I paint him in the character. Mark what mercy his mother shall bring
from him. There is no more mercy in him than there is milk in a male
tiger. That shall our poor city find, and all this is long of you.
nouns: character mercy mother mercy milk tiger city find

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
No, in such a case the gods will not be good unto us. When we banished
him, we respected not them; and he returning to break our necks, they
respect not us.

title: coriolanus
text:
MESSENGER.
Sir, if you’d save your life, fly to your house.
The plebeians have got your fellow tribune
And hale him up and down, all swearing if
The Roman ladies bring not comfort home,
They’ll give him death by inches.
nouns: messenger life house plebeian fellow lady comfort home death inch
verbs: save fly get hale swear bring give

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND MESSENGER.
Good news, good news! The ladies have prevailed.
The Volscians are dislodged and Martius gone.
A merrier day did never yet greet Rome,
No, not th’ expulsion of the Tarquins.
nouns: messenger news news lady day no th expulsion

title: coriolanus
text:
SICINIUS.
Friend,
Art thou certain this is true? Is’t most certain?

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND MESSENGER.
As certain as I know the sun is fire.
Where have you lurked that you make doubt of it?
Ne’er through an arch so hurried the blown tide
As the recomforted through th’ gates. Why, hark you!
nouns: messenger sun fire doubt ne’er arch tide th gate
verbs: know lurk make hurry recomforte hark

title: coriolanus
text:
MENENIUS.
This is good news.
I will go meet the ladies. This Volumnia
Is worth of consuls, senators, patricians
A city full; of tribunes such as you
A sea and land full. You have prayed well today.
This morning for ten thousand of your throats
I’d not have given a doit. Hark, how they joy!
nouns: news lady consul senator patrician city tribune sea land today morning throat
adjectives: good worth full such full doit

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND MESSENGER.
Sir, we have all great cause to give great thanks.

title: coriolanus
text:
Enter two Senators, with Ladies (Volumnia, Virgilia, Valeria) passing
over the stage, with other Lords.

title: coriolanus
text:
SENATOR.
Behold our patroness, the life of Rome!
Call all your tribes together, praise the gods,
And make triumphant fires. Strew flowers before them,
Unshout the noise that banished Martius,
Repeal him with the welcome of his mother.
Cry “Welcome, ladies, welcome!”
nouns: patroness life tribe god fire flower noise welcome mother welcome lady
verbs: behold call praise make banish repeal

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Even so
As with a man by his own alms empoisoned
And with his charity slain.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND CONSPIRATOR.
Most noble sir,
If you do hold the same intent wherein
You wished us parties, we’ll deliver you
Of your great danger.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD CONSPIRATOR.
The people will remain uncertain whilst
’Twixt you there’s difference, but the fall of either
Makes the survivor heir of all.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
I know it,
And my pretext to strike at him admits
A good construction. I raised him, and I pawned
Mine honour for his truth, who being so heightened,
He watered his new plants with dews of flattery,
Seducing so my friends; and to this end,
He bowed his nature, never known before
But to be rough, unswayable, and free.
nouns: aufidiu pretext construction honour truth plant dew flattery friend end nature
verbs: know strike admit raise pawn heighten water seduce bow know

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
That I would have spoke of.
Being banished for’t, he came unto my hearth,
Presented to my knife his throat. I took him,
Made him joint servant with me, gave him way
In all his own desires; nay, let him choose
Out of my files, his projects to accomplish,
My best and freshest men; served his designments
In mine own person; holp to reap the fame
Which he did end all his; and took some pride
To do myself this wrong; till at the last
I seemed his follower, not partner; and
He waged me with his countenance as if
I had been mercenary.
nouns: aufidiu hearth knife throat servant way desire file project man designment person holp fame pride follower partner countenance
adjectives: joint own good fresh mine own wrong last mercenary
verbs: speak banish come present take make give let choose accomplish serve reap end take seem wage

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
So he did, my lord.
The army marvelled at it, and, in the last,
When he had carried Rome and that we looked
For no less spoil than glory—

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
There was it
For which my sinews shall be stretched upon him.
At a few drops of women’s rheum, which are
As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour
Of our great action. Therefore shall he die,
And I’ll renew me in his fall. But, hark!
nouns: aufidiu sinew drop woman rheum lie blood labour action fall hark

title: coriolanus
text: [_Drums and trumpets sound, with great shouts of the people._]

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST CONSPIRATOR.
Your native town you entered like a post
And had no welcomes home, but he returns
Splitting the air with noise.
nouns: town post welcome home air noise

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND CONSPIRATOR.
And patient fools,
Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear
With giving him glory.
nouns: conspirator fool child base throat glory

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Say no more.
Here come the lords.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
I have not deserved it.
But, worthy lords, have you with heed perused
What I have written to you?

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST LORD.
And grieve to hear’t.
What faults he made before the last, I think
Might have found easy fines, but there to end
Where he was to begin and give away
The benefit of our levies, answering us
With our own charge, making a treaty where
There was a yielding—this admits no excuse.
nouns: hear’t fault fine benefit levy charge treaty yielding excuse
verbs: grieve make think find end begin give answer make admit

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Hail, lords! I am returned your soldier,
No more infected with my country’s love
Than when I parted hence, but still subsisting
Under your great command. You are to know
That prosperously I have attempted, and
With bloody passage led your wars even to
The gates of Rome. Our spoils we have brought home
Doth more than counterpoise a full third part
The charges of the action. We have made peace
With no less honour to the Antiates
Than shame to th’ Romans, and we here deliver,
Subscribed by th’ Consuls and patricians,
Together with the seal o’ th’ Senate, what
We have compounded on.
nouns: lord soldier country love command passage war gate spoil home part charge action peace honour shame th consul patrician seal
verbs: return part subsist know attempt lead bring counterpoise make th deliver subscribe compound

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Read it not, noble lords,
But tell the traitor in the highest degree
He hath abused your powers.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Ay, Martius, Caius Martius. Dost thou think
I’ll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol’n name
Coriolanus, in Corioles?
You lords and heads o’ th’ state, perfidiously
He has betrayed your business and given up
For certain drops of salt your city Rome—
I say your city—to his wife and mother,
Breaking his oath and resolution like
A twist of rotten silk, never admitting
Counsel o’ th’ war, but at his nurse’s tears
He whined and roared away your victory,
That pages blushed at him and men of heart
Looked wond’ring each at other.
nouns: aufidiu thou robbery stol’n name lord head state business drop salt city city wife mother oath resolution twist silk th war nurse tear victory page man heart
verbs: think grace betray give say break admit whine roar blush look wond’re

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart
Too great for what contains it. “Boy”? O slave!—
Pardon me, lords, ’tis the first time that ever
I was forced to scold. Your judgments, my grave lords,
Must give this cur the lie; and his own notion—
Who wears my stripes impressed upon him, that
Must bear my beating to his grave—shall join
To thrust the lie unto him.
nouns: heart slave lord time judgment lord cur lie notion stripe beating grave lie
verbs: make contain tis force scold give wear bear join thrust

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
Cut me to pieces, Volsces. Men and lads,
Stain all your edges on me. “Boy”? False hound!
If you have writ your annals true, ’tis there,
That like an eagle in a dovecote, I
Fluttered your Volscians in Corioles,
Alone I did it. “Boy”!
nouns: piece man lad edge hound annal eagle dovecote

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
Why, noble lords,
Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune,
Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart,
’Fore your own eyes and ears?
nouns: aufidiu lord mind fortune shame eye ear

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND LORD.
Peace, ho! No outrage! Peace!
The man is noble, and his fame folds in
This orb o’ th’ Earth. His last offences to us
Shall have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius,
And trouble not the peace.
nouns: outrage peace man fame orb o th offence hearing trouble peace

title: coriolanus
text:
CORIOLANUS.
O that I had him,
With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe,
To use my lawful sword.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
My noble masters, hear me speak.

title: coriolanus
text:
THIRD LORD.
Tread not upon him.—Masters, all be quiet.—
Put up your swords.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
My lords, when you shall know—as in this rage,
Provoked by him, you cannot—the great danger
Which this man’s life did owe you, you’ll rejoice
That he is thus cut off. Please it your Honours
To call me to your senate, I’ll deliver
Myself your loyal servant, or endure
Your heaviest censure.
nouns: aufidiu lord rage danger man life servant censure
verbs: know provoke cannot owe rejoice cut call deliver endure

title: coriolanus
text:
FIRST LORD.
Bear from hence his body,
And mourn you for him. Let him be regarded
As the most noble corse that ever herald
Did follow to his urn.

title: coriolanus
text:
SECOND LORD.
His own impatience
Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame.
Let’s make the best of it.

title: coriolanus
text:
AUFIDIUS.
My rage is gone,
And I am struck with sorrow.—Take him up.
Help, three o’ th’ chiefest soldiers; I’ll be one.—
Beat thou the drum that it speak mournfully.—
Trail your steel pikes. Though in this city he
Hath widowed and unchilded many a one,
Which to this hour bewail the injury,
Yet he shall have a noble memory.
Assist.
nouns: aufidiu rage o th chiefest soldier thou drum steel city hour bewail injury memory
verbs: go strike sorrow.—take beat speak trail pike widow unchilde

title: coriolanus
text: [_Exeunt, bearing the body of Martius. A dead march sounded._]
